### 2 Samuel Chapters 11-15: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** 2 Samuel 11-15 narrates David's moral failure and its devastating family consequences. Chapter 11 presents the **Bathsheba affair**. "In the spring of the year, the time when kings go out to battle," David stays in Jerusalem while Joab besieges Rabbah (11:1). One evening, walking on his roof, David sees a beautiful woman bathing—**Bathsheba**, wife of **Uriah the Hittite** (one of David's mighty men). David sends for her; "he lay with her... Then she returned to her house" (11:4). She conceives and sends word to David. His cover-up attempts fail: he summons Uriah from battle, trying to send him home to his wife (explaining pregnancy), but Uriah refuses to enjoy domestic comfort while the ark and army camp in the field. David gets him drunk—Uriah still won't go home. Finally, David sends Uriah back with sealed orders for Joab: "Set Uriah in the forefront of the hardest fighting, and then draw back from him, that he may be struck down, and die" (11:15). Joab complies; Uriah dies along with other soldiers. After Bathsheba's mourning period, David marries her; she bears a son. "But **the thing that David had done displeased the LORD**" (11:27). Chapter 12 presents **Nathan's confrontation**. The prophet tells a parable: a rich man with many flocks takes a poor man's single beloved lamb to feed a guest. David rages against the rich man; Nathan replies: "**You are the man!**" (12:7). The divine indictment follows: Yahweh gave David everything; why did he despise Yahweh's word? "Now therefore **the sword shall never depart from your house**... I will raise up evil against you out of your own house... you did it secretly, but I will do this thing before all Israel" (12:10-12). David confesses: "I have sinned against the LORD." Nathan responds: "The LORD also has put away your sin; you shall not die. Nevertheless, because by this deed you have utterly scorned the LORD, the child who is born to you shall die" (12:13-14). The child sickens; David fasts, lies on the ground, refuses food. When the child dies (day seven), David rises, washes, worships, eats—servants are bewildered. David explains: "While the child was still alive, I fasted and wept... But now he is dead. Why should I fast? Can I bring him back again?" (12:22-23). David comforts Bathsheba; she conceives **Solomon** ("beloved of the LORD," also called Jedidiah). Joab summons David to finish conquering Rabbah; David takes the Ammonite crown (75 pounds of gold) and subjects the people to forced labor. Chapter 13 presents **Amnon's rape of Tamar**. David's son Amnon "loves" his half-sister Tamar (Absalom's full sister). Cousin Jonadab devises a scheme: Amnon feigns illness, requests Tamar serve him food privately. When alone, Amnon seizes her; she pleads ("do not do this outrageous thing in Israel"), proposes marriage (probably impossible by Leviticus 18:9, though she suggests otherwise), warns of consequences. Amnon rapes her, then "hated her with very great hatred, so that the hatred with which he hated her was greater than the love with which he had loved her" (13:15). He expels her; she tears her virgin's robe, puts ashes on her head, weeps. Brother **Absalom** takes her into his house: "has Amnon your brother been with you? Now hold your peace... do not take this to heart" (13:20). "But Absalom spoke to Amnon neither good nor bad, for Absalom hated Amnon because he had violated his sister Tamar" (13:22). King David is "very angry" but does nothing (LXX adds: "but he would not punish his son Amnon, because he loved him, since he was his firstborn"). Chapter 14 describes **Absalom's exile and return**. Two years pass; Absalom plots revenge. At sheepshearing festival, he invites all royal sons, instructs servants to kill Amnon when drunk. They do; other princes flee; initial report says "Absalom has struck down all the king's sons" (14:30). Jonadab clarifies only Amnon died—"this has been determined by Absalom from the day Amnon violated his sister" (13:32). Absalom flees to Geshur (his mother's father Talmai's kingdom) for three years. David mourns, yet "the spirit of the king longed to go out to Absalom" (13:39). Joab perceives this; he employs a **wise woman of Tekoa** with a fictitious case paralleling David's situation: her two sons quarreled, one killed the other, now the clan demands the survivor's execution for blood vengeance—she'll lose her remaining son. David grants protection; she presses the application: why doesn't David do the same for Absalom? David discerns Joab's involvement, permits Absalom's return but denies him royal presence. After two more years in Jerusalem without seeing David, Absalom forces Joab's attention by burning his barley field. Finally, David receives Absalom, kisses him. Chapter 15 presents **Absalom's rebellion**. Absalom cultivates popularity: chariot and runners (fifty men), intercepting people coming to the king for justice, lamenting David's inadequate judicial system ("Oh that I were judge in the land!"), greeting suppliants with kisses rather than letting them bow. "So Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel" (15:6). After four years (some manuscripts: forty), Absalom requests permission to fulfill a vow at Hebron. David grants it; Absalom sends secret messengers throughout Israel: "As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, then say, 'Absalom is king at Hebron!'" (15:10). Two hundred Jerusalem men accompany Absalom unknowingly; **Ahithophel** (David's counselor) joins the conspiracy. David receives word: "The hearts of the men of Israel have gone after Absalom" (15:13). David immediately flees Jerusalem with household and loyal servants (leaving ten concubines to keep the palace). His foreign bodyguard (Cherethites, Pelethites, Gittites) follows. David tries sending back **Ittai the Gittite** (recent arrival); Ittai insists on loyalty unto death. David crosses the Kidron; all weep. Priests **Zadok** and Abiathar bring the ark; David sends it back—"If I find favor in the eyes of the LORD, he will bring me back" (15:25). **Hushai the Archite** arrives; David sends him to Jerusalem to counter Ahithophel's counsel. David ascends the Mount of Olives, weeping, head covered, barefoot.

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** 2 Samuel 11-15 illuminates Iron Age court life and military practice. **Rabbah** (modern Amman, Jordan) was the Ammonite capital; its siege provides background for chapters 11-12; David's eventual capture and the massive royal crown demonstrate significant Ammonite wealth. The siege's extended duration (perhaps two years) matches ancient Near Eastern city siege patterns. **Rooftop observation** (11:2) reflects Iron Age domestic architecture: flat roofs used for domestic activities, drying goods, sleeping in hot weather; royal palace overlooking lower houses enabled David's view. **Purification from uncleanness** (11:4: "she had been purifying herself from her uncleanness") indicates menstrual purification completed, establishing she was not pregnant before David. **Uriah the Hittite** as one of David's mighty men (23:39) shows foreign mercenaries' integration into royal forces; "Hittite" may indicate Anatolian descent or simply Canaanite resident using the term loosely. **Bathing at home** (11:2) may involve mikveh-type purification facilities; Iron Age Jerusalem evidence of such facilities remains limited. **Sealed letters** (11:14-15) demonstrate literate bureaucracy; Uriah carries his own death warrant without knowing. **Crown of Milkom** (12:30, or "their king"; Milkom was Ammonite deity) weighing 75 pounds suggests either ceremonial display item or exaggeration. **Sheepshearing** (13:23-24) represented festive occasion requiring hospitality; the celebration provided cover for Absalom's assassination plan. **Geshur** (13:37-38), northeast of the Sea of Galilee, was small Aramean kingdom; David's marriage alliance (Maacah, Absalom's mother) provided refuge when needed. **Tekoa** (14:2) lies south of Bethlehem; wisdom traditions associated with this region. **Hebron's significance** for rebellion (15:7-12) recalls David's first capital and Judahite loyalties; Absalom's conspiracy originates where David began, exploiting traditional Judahite identity against Jerusalem centralization.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** 2 Samuel 11-15 reveals court intrigue, family dynamics, and honor culture. **Royal access to subjects** (11:3-4) demonstrates monarchic power; sending messengers, summoning individuals reflects absolute authority structure. **Messenger protocol** (11:19-25) shows how military news was reported—bad news required careful presentation. **Murder through military assignment** (11:14-17) uses plausible deniability; other soldiers dying alongside Uriah provides cover. **Mourning period** (11:26-27) observance indicates propriety concern even amid sin; David waits before marriage. **Prophetic parable** (12:1-4) uses story to disarm defenses, enabling self-condemnation before confrontation—a sophisticated technique. **Confession formula** (12:13: "I have sinned against the LORD") represents proper penitential response; Psalm 51's superscription connects it to this moment. **Fasting for the sick** (12:15-23) shows intercessory practice—attempting to influence divine decision through self-denial. **Post-death normalization** (12:20: washing, anointing, eating) demonstrates acceptance of God's will once judgment falls. **Sexual violence terminology** (13:12: "outrageous thing/folly in Israel," *nebalah*) uses same language as Dinah's rape (Genesis 34:7) and Gibeah outrage (Judges 19:23-24)—recognizing rape's social devastation. **Virgin's robe** (13:18-19: "long robe with sleeves") identifies unmarried royal daughters; Tamar's tearing signals violated status. **Blood vengeance** (13:28-29) operates by kinship obligation; Absalom waits two years but executes retribution his father failed to provide. **Wise woman intermediary** (14:1-24) shows women exercising political influence through indirect means; the Tekoa woman's sophistication parallels Abigail's counsel (1 Samuel 25). **Royal kiss** (14:33; 15:5) represents reconciliation or greeting; Absalom's democratic kissing undermines David's majesty. **Chariot and runners** (15:1) demonstrate royal pretension—Absalom acts like king before becoming one.

**Political Situation:** 2 Samuel 11-15 depicts David's moral failure triggering political catastrophe. **Royal absence from battle** (11:1: "David remained at Jerusalem") breaks pattern of leadership—the king who personally led armies now stays behind, creating idleness that enables sin. **Adultery as political act**: Bathsheba is wife of loyal warrior serving the king; taking her violates covenant relationships on multiple levels. **Murder conspiracy** (11:14-17) implicates Joab in royal crime; the commander follows orders, gaining leverage over David. **Nathan's intervention** demonstrates prophetic authority to confront royal power—Israel's kings are not above divine judgment. **Divine sentence** (12:10-12) announces consequences within David's own house: sword never departing, evil rising from within, public exposure of hidden sin. The narrative shows these judgments unfolding through Amnon, Absalom, and later Adonijah. **Justice failure** (13:21: David angry but not punishing Amnon) represents crucial abdication: the king who judges Israel cannot judge his own household. His moral compromise (Bathsheba-Uriah affair) disqualifies moral authority over sons. **Absalom's vengeance** fills the vacuum David's inaction creates—family violence replaces royal justice. **Exile and return tensions** (13:37-14:33) show David's emotional paralysis: longing for Absalom yet denying him presence, permitting return without reconciliation. **Absalom's propaganda campaign** (15:1-6) exploits northern/rural discontent with Jerusalem centralization; tribal grievances against Judahite-centered monarchy provide fuel. **Ahithophel's defection** (15:12) represents serious crisis—David's trusted counselor (and Bathsheba's grandfather, according to 2 Samuel 11:3; 23:34, connecting Eliam with Ahithophel) joining rebellion may indicate personal grievance. **David's flight** (15:13-30) demonstrates vulnerability: the mighty king who defeated all enemies flees before his own son, crossing Kidron like subsequent exiles, ascending Olivet in grief—a broken king facing consequences of his sin.

**Theological Themes:** 2 Samuel 11-15 develops profound theological perspectives on sin, judgment, and consequences. **Sin's progression** (chapter 11) traces idleness to lust to adultery to deception to murder—each step enabling the next, demonstrating how sin escalates. **Divine omniscience** (11:27: "the thing that David had done displeased the LORD") shows nothing is hidden from God; private sin has divine witness. **Prophetic confrontation** (12:1-15) demonstrates divine judgment mediated through prophetic office; kings are accountable to Yahweh's representatives. **Parable's power** (12:1-7) enables self-judgment before recognizing oneself as the guilty party; story penetrates defenses that direct accusation couldn't breach. **Confession and forgiveness** (12:13) shows immediate divine response to genuine repentance—"the LORD has put away your sin"—demonstrating grace available even for terrible sins. **Consequences persist despite forgiveness** (12:10-14): David is forgiven but consequences are not removed; his house will experience the violence he perpetrated. The distinction between forgiveness (eternal relationship restored) and consequences (temporal results continuing) becomes theologically significant. **Child's death** (12:14-23) raises difficult questions about collective punishment, innocent suffering, and divine justice; David's response models faith that accepts divine verdicts. **"Can I bring him back?"** (12:23) expresses theology of death's finality and hints at hope beyond death ("I shall go to him"). **Justice delayed** (13:21-39) shows how moral compromise disables moral authority; David's sin with Bathsheba prevents him from addressing Amnon's sin with Tamar. **Evil from within** (12:11; chapters 13-15) fulfills Nathan's sentence precisely: David's house produces the violence that punishes him—Absalom (from David) rebels as David took another's wife. **Divine sovereignty through human decisions** (15:31: David prays that Ahithophel's counsel be turned to foolishness): David appeals to God while sending Hushai to accomplish it humanly—prayer and action combine.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** 2 Samuel 11-15 creates extensive canonical connections. **Psalm 51's superscription** connects it to Nathan's confrontation—Israel's paradigmatic penitential psalm emerges from David's greatest failure, demonstrating how confession produces spiritual literature. **"Sword shall never depart"** (12:10) echoes throughout subsequent narrative: Amnon murdered, Absalom murdered (chapter 18), Adonijah executed (1 Kings 2), Solomon's succession bloodshed. **Bathsheba's role** continues: mother of Solomon, influential in succession (1 Kings 1:11-31), her children listed (1 Chronicles 3:5). **Nathan** emerges as significant prophet: confronting David here, later supporting Solomon's succession (1 Kings 1). **Tamar's rape** parallels Genesis 34 (Dinah) and Judges 19 (Levite's concubine)—sexual violence as social catastrophe triggering larger conflicts. **Absalom's revenge** follows blood-vengeance patterns while also critiquing David's justice failure. **David's flight** anticipates Jerusalem's later falls: crossing Kidron, abandoning the city, weeping on Olivet—imagery that resonates through Jeremiah's lamentations and Jesus's Gethsemane agony (same location). **Ark remaining in Jerusalem** (15:24-29) shows David's faith that God determines outcomes, not manipulated cult objects—contrasting with Israelites bringing ark to battle (1 Samuel 4). **Mount of Olives** (15:30) becomes significant location: Ezekiel's glory departs there (Ezekiel 11:23); Zechariah places eschatological theophany there (Zechariah 14:4); Jesus's teaching, betrayal, ascension occur there (Matthew 24-26; Acts 1). **Hushai versus Ahithophel** (chapters 15-17) shows wisdom traditions in political conflict; Ahithophel's counsel "as if one consulted the oracle of God" (16:23) versus Hushai's ultimately successful counterplan demonstrates God working through human wisdom. **Sin's generational impact** structures the "Succession Narrative" (chapters 9-20; 1 Kings 1-2): David's sin shapes everything that follows, yet God's purposes ultimately triumph through Solomon.

### 2 Samuel Chapters 16-20: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** 2 Samuel 16-20 narrates Absalom's rebellion's climax and aftermath. Chapter 16 shows David's humiliating flight continuing. **Ziba**, Mephibosheth's servant, meets David with provisions, claiming Mephibosheth stayed in Jerusalem hoping Israel would restore Saul's kingdom to him. David impulsively grants Ziba all Mephibosheth's property. As David descends toward the Jordan, **Shimei** (Saul's relative from Bahurim) curses him, throws stones: "Get out, get out, you man of blood, you worthless man! The LORD has avenged on you all the blood of the house of Saul... the LORD has given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. See, your evil is on you, for you are a man of blood!" (16:7-8). Abishai offers to kill Shimei; David refuses—"Let him alone... perhaps the LORD will look on the wrong done to me" (16:11-12). David accepts the cursing as possibly deserved. In Jerusalem, Absalom receives **Hushai** (who claims to serve whomever Yahweh and Israel have chosen). **Ahithophel** advises Absalom to take David's concubines publicly—"Go in to your father's concubines... all Israel will hear that you have made yourself a stench to your father, and the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened" (16:21). Absalom does so on the roof, fulfilling Nathan's prophecy (12:11-12). Chapter 17 presents the **battle of counselors**. Ahithophel advises immediate pursuit with 12,000 men while David is weary and frightened: "I will strike down only the king" (17:2)—end the war quickly by targeting David alone. Hushai counters: David and his men are mighty, experienced warriors; they won't be found easily; any initial setback will demoralize Absalom's forces. Instead, gather all Israel and overwhelm them with numbers, with Absalom himself leading. Hushai's counsel wins—"For the LORD had ordained to defeat the good counsel of Ahithophel, so that the LORD might bring harm upon Absalom" (17:14). Hushai sends word to David through priests' sons Jonathan and Ahimaaz (who hide in a well, protected by a woman's deception). David crosses the Jordan that night. **Ahithophel**, seeing his counsel rejected and foreseeing failure, goes home, puts his house in order, and hangs himself (17:23). David reaches **Mahanaim** (where Ish-bosheth once ruled); supporters bring provisions. Absalom crosses the Jordan; **Amasa** commands his army. Chapter 18 presents **Absalom's death**. David organizes his forces under Joab, Abishai, and Ittai; the army insists David stay behind ("you are worth ten thousand of us," 18:3). David publicly commands all three commanders: "**Deal gently for my sake with the young man Absalom**" (18:5). Battle occurs in the forest of Ephraim; David's men prevail; 20,000 die, "the forest devoured more people that day than the sword" (18:8). Absalom, riding a mule, passes under an oak; his head catches in the branches, leaving him suspended. A soldier reports to Joab but wouldn't strike him; Joab responds: "I will not waste time like this with you" (18:14), takes three javelins, and thrusts them into Absalom's heart while he's still alive. Ten young men surround and kill Absalom. Joab sounds the trumpet; pursuit ends. They throw Absalom into a pit in the forest, heap stones over him. Two runners race to tell David; **Ahimaaz** arrives first but avoids bad news; the **Cushite** reports Absalom's death. David's lament is devastating: "**O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!**" (18:33). Chapter 19 shows victory turned to mourning. David's grief demoralizes the army: "the victory that day was turned into mourning" (19:2). **Joab** harshly confronts David: "You have today covered with shame the faces of all your servants... you love those who hate you and hate those who love you... if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead today, then you would be pleased" (19:5-6). He threatens: if David doesn't acknowledge the army, none will remain by morning. David goes to the gate. Israel and Judah debate who should restore David; Judah moves first. David appoints **Amasa** as commander (replacing Joab—political reward for bringing Judah over). Crossing back, David meets **Shimei** (who begs forgiveness—David spares him), **Mephibosheth** (who claims Ziba lied, showing he mourned throughout; David divides property between them, prompting Mephibosheth: "let him take it all," since David has returned safely), and elderly **Barzillai** (who supplied David at Mahanaim, refuses reward, sends his son Chimham instead). Conflict erupts between Israel and Judah over who has greater claim to David—portending future division. Chapter 20 narrates **Sheba's rebellion**. **Sheba** (Benjaminite) sounds trumpet: "We have no portion in David... every man to his tents, O Israel!" (20:1). Israel follows Sheba; Judah remains loyal. David returns to Jerusalem, confines the ten concubines Absalom violated—they live "as widows" (20:3). David orders Amasa to mobilize Judah within three days; Amasa delays. David sends Abishai (not Joab) to pursue Sheba before he finds fortified cities. Joab's forces join; at Gibeon, Joab greets Amasa with "Is it well with you, my brother?" and stabs him with concealed sword (20:9-10)—killing his replacement as he killed Abner. Joab assumes command, pursues Sheba to **Abel of Beth-maacah** (far north). During siege, a **wise woman** negotiates: why destroy "a mother in Israel"? She offers Sheba's head; the city throws it over the wall; Joab withdraws. Administrative list concludes: Joab (army), Benaiah (bodyguard), Adoram (forced labor), Jehoshaphat (recorder), Sheva (secretary), Zadok and Abiathar (priests), **Ira the Jairite** (David's priest).

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** 2 Samuel 16-20 illuminates Iron Age political structures and military practices. **Bahurim** (likely near Jerusalem's eastern approach) appears repeatedly in David narratives; Shimei's curse indicates Saulide sentiment surviving there. **Concubine appropriation** (16:21-22) as succession claim matches ancient Near Eastern practice; Absalom's public act (on the roof, visible to all) makes the breach with David irreparable. **Forest of Ephraim** (18:6) in Transjordan (despite Ephraim being west of Jordan) presents geographical puzzle; perhaps Ephraimite settlers or lost location. **Mahanaim** (possibly Tell edh-Dhahab el-Gharbi) served multiple times as refuge/capital east of Jordan—for Ish-bosheth (2:8) and now David. **Abel of Beth-maacah** (Tell Abil el-Qamh) in the far north near Dan shows excavation evidence of Iron Age occupation; its description as "mother in Israel" (20:19) indicates significant city status. **Forced labor administrator** (20:24: Adoram/Adoniram) appears—the position continues under Solomon (1 Kings 4:6; 5:14) and sparks rebellion under Rehoboam (1 Kings 12:18), showing continuity of unpopular institution. **Administrative list evolution** (8:15-18; 20:23-26) shows bureaucratic development; comparing lists reveals changes (Ira the Jairite as David's priest—possibly personal chaplain distinct from Zadok/Abiathar's temple role). **Pit burial under stones** (18:17) for rebels/criminals (cf. Achan, Joshua 7:26) denies honorable interment; Absalom's monument (18:18) he built in life ironically contrasts with his shameful burial in death.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** 2 Samuel 16-20 reveals power dynamics, honor/shame culture, and political rituals. **Provision for fleeing king** (16:1-2: Ziba's supplies) demonstrates political investment—supporting David during crisis hopes for future reward. **False accusation** (16:3: Ziba's claim about Mephibosheth) shows palace intrigue; David's hasty judgment (granting property without hearing Mephibosheth) proves problematic. **Cursing and stone-throwing** (16:5-13) represents extreme insult; David's acceptance interprets it through theological lens—perhaps deserved, perhaps convertible to blessing. **Taking royal concubines** (16:21-22) publicly claims succession; the tent on the roof maximizes visibility, making reconciliation impossible. **Counsel as warfare** (chapter 17): Ahithophel versus Hushai shows wisdom traditions' political application; the description of Ahithophel's counsel as "oracle of God" (16:23) highlights the stakes. **Well-hiding and woman's deception** (17:18-20) parallels Rahab's protection of spies (Joshua 2)—women protecting fugitives through clever speech. **Suicide** (17:23: Ahithophel) represents rational response to anticipated defeat—putting house in order before death shows deliberation rather than impulse. **"Deal gently"** command (18:5) reflects David's tragic love for rebellious son—publicly known, creating complications when Joab kills Absalom. **Head caught in tree** (18:9) may invoke earlier curse (14:26 mentions Absalom's heavy hair); the specific tree (*elah*, oak/terebinth) has cultic associations. **Messenger hesitancy** (18:19-32: Ahimaaz avoiding the news) shows cultural reluctance to bring bad news to powerful people. **Excessive mourning** (18:33-19:4) demonstrates David's emotional extremity; Joab's rebuke indicates such grief is politically dysfunctional. **Crossing Jordan** rituals (chapter 19) involve formal restoration: enemies pardoned, allies rewarded, king reinstalled—reversing the flight sequence. **"Mother in Israel"** (20:19) as city designation indicates protective/nurturing role; the wise woman negotiates communal survival through eloquence. **Head over the wall** (20:22) resolves siege through targeted execution—city sacrifices one to save many.

**Political Situation:** 2 Samuel 16-20 depicts civil war's resolution and ongoing tensions. **Absalom's consolidation** (taking concubines, gathering forces) shows rebellion's seriousness; David is genuinely displaced, his kingship threatened. **Counsel as determinative** (chapter 17): the choice between Ahithophel's swift strike and Hushai's delayed massing determines outcome; God works through human deliberation. **Ahithophel's suicide** anticipates defeat—his reputation depends on successful counsel; failure means disgrace. **Forest casualties** (18:8) suggest ambush warfare; David's experienced guerrilla fighters excel in broken terrain versus Absalom's less-trained forces. **Absalom's death** ends rebellion but complicates David: Joab disobeys direct orders, yet eliminates the threat. David's grief alienates the victorious army, requiring Joab's harsh intervention. **Amasa's appointment** (19:13) rewards Judah for support while punishing Joab—but Joab eliminates Amasa as he did Abner, remaining indispensable despite being formally replaced. **Israel-Judah tension** (19:41-43) foreshadows division: both claim priority with David; the argument anticipates the schism under Rehoboam. **Sheba's rebellion** (chapter 20) represents immediate north-south fracture: "We have no portion in David"—the same language Jeroboam later uses (1 Kings 12:16). **Wise woman's diplomacy** (20:16-22) resolves crisis through negotiation—preserving city by surrendering rebel. **Administrative stabilization** (20:23-26) indicates restoration of government; Joab's return to command shows David's inability to remove him despite murders of Abner, Absalom (effectively), and Amasa.

**Theological Themes:** 2 Samuel 16-20 develops crucial theological perspectives. **Divine sovereignty through human means** (17:14: "the LORD had ordained to defeat... Ahithophel's counsel") shows God working through human decisions without overriding human agency. **Suffering as potentially deserved** (16:10-12: David accepting Shimei's curse) models humility under affliction—perhaps God has sent this; perhaps blessing will follow. **Nathan's prophecy fulfilled** (16:22 fulfills 12:11-12): concubines taken publicly, evil rising from David's house—divine word proves reliable. **Absalom's death as judgment** responds to his crimes (fratricide, rebellion, possibly rape by implication of taking concubines); yet David mourns—judgment doesn't eliminate parental love. **Father's tragic love** (18:33) shows how deeply David loves despite Absalom's wickedness; the tension between justice (rebellion deserves death) and love (mourning the dead son) remains unresolved. **Wisdom versus folly** (chapter 17) presents Hushai's counsel prevailing through divine intervention; human wisdom serves God's purposes when God ordains it. **Pride's fall** (Absalom's capture in the tree, caught by his renowned hair, suspended helplessly) suggests poetic justice; the beautiful, ambitious prince dies shamefully. **Forgiveness and consequences** (Shimei pardoned, Mephibosheth's lands partially restored) shows David's clemency—but 1 Kings 2:8-9 reveals David instructs Solomon to execute Shimei eventually. **Community preservation** (20:16-22: wise woman saving Abel) values collective survival over individual; Sheba's head buys the city's safety.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** 2 Samuel 16-20 creates extensive canonical connections. **Ahithophel's counsel/suicide** parallels Judas's betrayal of Jesus and subsequent suicide (Matthew 27:5); both trusted advisors betray their lord and hang themselves. **"No portion in David"** (20:1) becomes Jeroboam's rallying cry (1 Kings 12:16); Sheba's rebellion previews the permanent division. **Joab's murders** (Abner, 3:27; Absalom, 18:14; Amasa, 20:10) accumulate, explaining David's deathbed instruction (1 Kings 2:5-6); Solomon executes Joab for these deaths. **Shimei's pardon** (19:23) is conditional; Solomon eventually executes him (1 Kings 2:8-9, 36-46). **Absalom's memorial pillar** (18:18) in the King's Valley (perhaps Kidron) becomes ironic monument—built because he had no son to remember him, contrasting with his father's eternal dynasty. **David crossing Kidron** (15:23) in flight, then returning, prefigures Jesus crossing Kidron toward Gethsemane (John 18:1)—both kings facing betrayal and death, though with different outcomes. **Wise woman of Abel** parallels wise woman of Tekoa (14:2); both use eloquence for political ends, representing female wisdom tradition. **Administrative lists** provide framework for Solomon's bureaucracy (1 Kings 4:1-6); Adoram's forced labor continuity shows institutional development. **Barzillai's loyalty** is remembered: his descendant claims this relationship when returning from exile (Ezra 2:61; Nehemiah 7:63). **Absalom's grave** under stones echoes Achan's burial (Joshua 7:26); rebels and covenant-breakers receive shameful interment. **Forest of Ephraim battle** (18:6-8) shows divine intervention through natural means—terrain defeats the rebellion as much as military prowess.

### 2 Samuel Chapters 21-24: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** 2 Samuel 21-24 forms an appendix collecting materials from David's reign. Chapter 21 begins with **three-year famine**; David seeks Yahweh, who reveals: "There is bloodguilt on Saul and on his house, because he put the Gibeonites to death" (21:1). David consults the Gibeonites (whom Saul had apparently massacred despite Joshua's ancient covenant, Joshua 9); they demand seven of Saul's sons. David gives them two sons of Rizpah (Saul's concubine) and five sons of Merab (Saul's daughter, given instead of to David, 1 Samuel 18:19). The Gibeonites hang them "on the mountain before the LORD" (21:9) at barley harvest's beginning. **Rizpah** guards the bodies from birds and beasts from harvest until the rains come—preventing desecration through months-long vigil. David, told of her devotion, retrieves Saul's and Jonathan's bones from Jabesh-gilead (1 Samuel 31:11-13), buries all properly in Kish's tomb at Zela in Benjamin. "After that, God responded to the plea for the land" (21:14). The chapter concludes with **Philistine giant accounts** (21:15-22): David nearly killed by Ishbi-benob (spear weighing 300 shekels of bronze) but rescued by Abishai—prompting his men: "You shall no longer go out with us to battle, lest you quench the lamp of Israel" (21:17). Subsequent battles at Gob kill Saph (another giant), Goliath of Gath's brother whose spear shaft was "like a weaver's beam" (killed by Elhanan—creating tension with 1 Samuel 17), and a six-fingered/six-toed giant killed by Jonathan (David's nephew). "These four were descended from the giants in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants" (21:22). Chapter 22 presents **David's song of deliverance**, nearly identical to Psalm 18. It celebrates rescue from all enemies and from Saul: "The LORD is my rock and my fortress and my deliverer" (22:2). Poetic imagery describes divine intervention: shaking earth, smoke and fire from God's nostrils, bowing heavens, riding cherubim and wind, thundering from heaven. David claims integrity: "I was blameless before him, and I kept myself from guilt. So the LORD has rewarded me according to my righteousness" (22:24-25). The song acknowledges God's faithfulness, military training, and ultimate victory. Chapter 23 opens with **"David's last words"** (23:1-7), presenting him as "the sweet psalmist of Israel" declaring covenant confidence: "my house is secure with God... will he not bring to fruition my salvation and grant my every desire?" (23:5 NIV). The chapter then lists **David's mighty men** (23:8-39): "the Three" (Josheb-basshebeth who killed 800 at once; Eleazar who fought Philistines until his hand froze to his sword; Shammah who defended a lentil field alone), an episode of three breaking through Philistine lines to get David water from Bethlehem's well (which David pours out as offering rather than drink), "the Thirty" (Abishai and Benaiah highlighted, then the complete roster of thirty-seven warriors including Uriah the Hittite—noted without comment after the Bathsheba narrative). Chapter 24 presents **David's census and the plague**. David commands Joab to number Israel and Judah. Joab objects ("Why should it be a cause of guilt to Israel?" 24:3) but obeys, traveling nine months and twenty days, returning count of 800,000 men in Israel, 500,000 in Judah. Afterward, "David's heart struck him" (24:10); he confesses: "I have sinned greatly... I have done very foolishly." Prophet **Gad** offers three punishments: three years of famine, three months fleeing enemies, or three days of pestilence. David chooses pestilence: "let us fall into the hand of the LORD, for his mercy is great; but let me not fall into the hand of man" (24:14). Plague kills 70,000 from Dan to Beersheba. When the destroying angel reaches Jerusalem, stretching out his hand, the LORD relents: "It is enough; now stay your hand" (24:16). The angel stands at the **threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite**. David sees the angel, pleads for Israel: "I have sinned... but these sheep, what have they done? Please let your hand be against me and against my father's house" (24:17). Gad instructs David to build an altar there. Araunah offers the site, oxen, and wood freely; David refuses: "I will not offer burnt offerings to the LORD my God that cost me nothing" (24:24). He pays fifty shekels of silver, builds the altar, sacrifices; "the LORD responded to the plea for the land, and the plague was averted from Israel" (24:25). This threshing floor becomes the temple site (1 Chronicles 21:28-22:1).

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** 2 Samuel 21-24 illuminates Iron Age religious practices and David's era. **Gibeonite treaty** (Joshua 9) establishes ancient covenant; Saul's violation (not recorded elsewhere in Samuel-Kings) represents serious breach requiring expiation. **Hanging/exposure** (21:6, 9) as execution method differs from later Hebrew practice; "before the LORD" suggests cultic dimension. **Barley harvest** to rainfall (21:9-10) indicates April-October span—Rizpah's vigil lasting perhaps six months demonstrates extraordinary maternal devotion. **Zela in Benjamin** (21:14) as Kish's family tomb indicates ancestral burial location. **Giant traditions** (21:15-22) connect to pre-Israelite inhabitants (Rephaim, Anakim); the "Elhanan killed Goliath" tradition (21:19) contradicts 1 Samuel 17; Chronicles harmonizes by making Elhanan kill "Lahmi the brother of Goliath" (1 Chronicles 20:5). **"Weaver's beam" spear shaft** appears in both Goliath (1 Samuel 17:7) and this giant, suggesting formulaic description of exceptional weapons. **Psalm 18/2 Samuel 22** verbatim correspondence (with minor variations) demonstrates psalmic material's integration into narrative. **"Last words"** genre (23:1-7) appears in patriarchal blessings (Genesis 49) and Moses's blessing (Deuteronomy 33). **Mighty men lists** (23:8-39) preserve military records; names, exploits, and enumeration ("thirty-seven in all" despite being called "the Thirty") reflect archival material. **Census prohibition** (24:1, 10) may relate to trust in God versus military strength; Numbers 1 and 26 present divinely commanded censuses, making this prohibition context-specific. **Threshing floor of Araunah** (24:18-25) becomes temple site (2 Chronicles 3:1 identifies it as Mount Moriah); Araunah's Jebusite identity shows continuity with pre-Davidic Jerusalem population. **Fifty shekels of silver** (24:24) contrasts with 1 Chronicles 21:25's "600 shekels of gold for the site"—possibly reflecting different scope (immediate floor versus larger temple area) or textual variation.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** 2 Samuel 21-24 reveals blood vengeance, cultic practice, and military honor. **Bloodguilt requiring satisfaction** (21:1-9) shows communal responsibility for covenant violation; Saul's sin affects his descendants and all Israel until expiated. **Seven victims** (21:6, 9) suggests sacred number for expiation. **Exposure at harvest** (21:9-10) may connect to fertility concerns—famine and harvest intertwined with proper relationship to God. **Rizpah's vigil** (21:10) represents maternal/familial duty to prevent body desecration; her sackcloth indicates mourning; her persistence prompts David's proper burial response. **Proper burial resolving crisis** (21:14) shows interment's importance; divine response follows honorable treatment of dead. **"Lamp of Israel"** (21:17) as David's title shows his irreplaceable significance; protective concern for the king supersedes his desire for combat glory. **Warrior praise** (chapter 23) reflects honor culture—individual exploits remembered, named, celebrated; heroic deeds earn permanent memorial. **Water from Bethlehem's well** (23:15-17) refused by David because obtaining it risked lives—blood metaphorically, poured out as libation rather than consumed for personal pleasure. **Census as sin** (24:1, 10) raises questions: what makes numbering wrong? Possibilities include trusting military strength over God, exposing people to divine scrutiny, taxation/conscription implications. **Divine anger preceding census** (24:1: "the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he incited David") creates theological difficulty; 1 Chronicles 21:1 attributes incitement to "Satan"—theological development between texts. **Choice of punishments** (24:12-13) shows prophetic role in presenting divine options; David's reasoning (preferring divine to human hands) trusts God's mercy. **Refusing free sacrifice** (24:24) establishes principle: worship must cost the worshipper; offerings shouldn't be others' expense.

**Political Situation:** 2 Samuel 21-24 depicts closure to David's reign. **Famine response** (chapter 21) shows king's responsibility for land's welfare; David must address covenant violation even from previous dynasty. **Gibeonite satisfaction** involving Saul's descendants eliminates potential rivals while fulfilling justice—politically convenient yet presented as religiously necessary. **Mephibosheth's exclusion** (21:7) from those given to Gibeonites honors Jonathan-David covenant—political and religious obligations in tension, resolved by protecting the one David personally covenanted with. **"Lamp of Israel" prohibition** (21:17) indicates political transition: David too valuable for combat; the warrior-king becomes administrator-king. **Mighty men roster** (chapter 23) represents David's military elite—the 600 from wilderness years (1 Samuel 22, 27) professionalized into royal bodyguard and officer corps. Including "Uriah the Hittite" (23:39) last without comment creates ironic memorial—the man David murdered for his wife memorialized among David's heroes. **Census motivation** remains debated: military assessment? taxation preparation? simply royal pride? Joab's reluctance suggests political danger in numbering. **Plague as political crisis** (24:13-17) threatens the population David spent his reign securing; his offer to bear punishment personally shows kingly responsibility. **Temple site acquisition** (24:18-25) resolves plague while establishing Jerusalem's cultic future; the Jebusite seller and Davidic purchaser demonstrate legitimate transfer—David doesn't confiscate but pays, establishing legal foundation for temple site.

**Theological Themes:** 2 Samuel 21-24 develops crucial theological perspectives. **Corporate responsibility** (chapter 21): Saul's sin affects Israel; descendants bear consequences; covenant violation requires communal satisfaction. This raises modern concerns but reflects ancient understanding of corporate personality. **Divine response to proper action** (21:14; 24:25): famine and plague end when humans act rightly—burial, sacrifice. **"The LORD... incited David"** (24:1) versus "Satan... incited David" (1 Chronicles 21:1) shows theological development: Israel initially attributed all causation to Yahweh (including evil); later tradition distinguished divine permission from satanic agency. Both maintain God's sovereignty differently. **"Let us fall into the hand of the LORD"** (24:14) expresses confidence in divine mercy exceeding human mercy—a significant theological affirmation. **Conscience as divine voice** (24:10: "David's heart struck him") shows internal moral awareness operating after the fact; David recognizes sin through conscience. **Innocent suffering** (24:17: "these sheep, what have they done?") acknowledges the theodicy problem: 70,000 die for David's sin. David's offer to substitute himself (which God doesn't accept) shows willingness to bear consequences personally. **Costly worship** (24:24) establishes principle: sacrifice must cost the offerer; true worship involves giving what matters, not what's convenient. **Temple site origin** (24:25 leading to 1 Chronicles 21-22) shows salvation and judgment meeting at one location: where plague stopped, temple rises; where death threatened, worship begins. **David's song** (chapter 22) summarizes theology of deliverance: God rescues the righteous, rewards integrity, defeats enemies, establishes kings—the perspective of successful reign looking back gratefully. **"Last words"** (23:1-7) affirm covenant confidence: despite failures, David trusts God's promise; his house is secure despite household disasters.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** 2 Samuel 21-24 creates extensive canonical connections. **Gibeonite treaty** from Joshua 9 demonstrates covenant's binding force across generations; Saul's violation wasn't recorded but affects descendants—showing narrative gaps don't mean events didn't occur. **Rizpah** appears earlier (3:7) in Abner's scandal; her devotion here provides sympathetic portrait of Saul's concubine. **Temple site identification** (24:18-25; 1 Chronicles 21:28-22:1; 2 Chronicles 3:1) connects David's altar to Solomon's temple to Mount Moriah (Abraham's near-sacrifice of Isaac, Genesis 22:2)—one location accruing sacred significance across centuries. **Psalm 18/2 Samuel 22** correspondence demonstrates psalmic material's historical setting claims; the psalm's Davidic superscription claims this narrative context. **"Sweet psalmist of Israel"** (23:1) establishes David's psalmic association, underlying the Psalter's Davidic attributions. **Mighty men** lists connect to 1 Chronicles 11:10-47; individual warriors' exploits shape military memory. **"Elhanan killed Goliath"** (21:19) creates famous difficulty with 1 Samuel 17; explanations include two Goliaths, textual corruption, or conflicting traditions about giant-slaying. **Census/plague narrative** parallels Numbers 11, 16, 25 where Israelite sin brings plague; David's response (altar, sacrifice) provides proper resolution. **Threshing floor purchase** establishes legal precedent for temple site, ensuring no claims against it; David buying rather than taking demonstrates legitimate acquisition. **Joab's reluctance** regarding census (24:3) adds to his complex characterization—sometimes morally superior to David (here), sometimes brutally expedient (killing Abner, Absalom, Amasa). **"These sheep"** language (24:17) connects to David the shepherd; he remains shepherd even as king, responsible for flock's welfare. **Chronicles' theological development** visible in 24:1 versus 1 Chronicles 21:1 shows ongoing reflection on divine causation and evil's agency within biblical tradition itself.

---
## 1 Kings

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** The book of 1 Kings covers approximately 970-850 BCE, from Solomon's accession through the divided monarchy's first decades. The book spans Solomon's entire reign (ca. 970-930 BCE, chapters 1-11) and the early divided kingdom period (ca. 930-850 BCE, chapters 12-22), ending with Ahab's death and Jehoshaphat's continued reign. This corresponds to Iron Age IIA-B archaeologically, a period of significant state formation in the Levant. The book's composition, however, dates much later. As part of the Deuteronomistic History, 1 Kings was compiled/edited during the late 7th century BCE (Josiah's reign) or 6th century BCE (Babylonian exile), incorporating earlier sources. These sources likely included: the "Book of the Acts of Solomon" (11:41), "Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel" (14:19 and frequently), "Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah" (14:29 and frequently), temple records, and prophetic traditions (Elijah and Elisha cycles). The archaeological debate over Solomon's kingdom remains intense: traditional scholars attribute monumental architecture at Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer to Solomon (matching 1 Kings 9:15), while minimalist scholars (Finkelstein) redate these structures to the 9th century Omride dynasty, suggesting Solomon's kingdom was more modest than biblical portrayal.

**Author and Audience:** Like the broader Deuteronomistic History, 1 Kings reflects Deuteronomistic editorial shaping, though incorporating earlier sources. The repetitive formulas introducing and concluding each king's reign ("In the Xth year of king Y of Judah, king Z began to reign over Israel...he did evil/right in the sight of the LORD...") suggest compilation from official chronicles. The theological evaluation of each king according to Deuteronomic standards (exclusive Yahweh worship at Jerusalem temple versus idolatry and high places) reveals editorial perspective. The intended audience would be exilic or post-exilic Jews seeking to understand why the kingdoms fell: the Deuteronomistic theology explains exile as covenant judgment for persistent idolatry, beginning with Solomon's apostasy through foreign wives (chapter 11) and continuing through the northern kingdom's Baal worship and southern kingdom's syncretism. The book validates centralized Jerusalem worship while condemning alternative sanctuaries (Bethel, Dan). The prophetic traditions (Elijah confronting Ahab and Baal worship) establish prophetic authority to call kings to covenant accountability. The contrast between Solomon's early wisdom and later apostasy demonstrates that even divinely blessed kings fail when abandoning exclusive Yahwism.

**Key Themes:** The book develops several theological themes structuring its historical narrative. Temple centralization appears paramount: Solomon's temple construction (chapters 5-8) establishes Jerusalem as the exclusive legitimate worship site, fulfilling David's desire and God's promise. The temple dedication prayer (chapter 8) emphasizes that even this magnificent structure cannot contain God, yet serves as focal point for prayer and covenant relationship. The theme of covenant obedience versus idolatry drives the narrative: Solomon's apostasy through foreign wives and their deities (chapter 11) brings divine judgment—kingdom division. The Deuteronomistic theology evaluates every king by faithfulness to exclusive Yahweh worship: southern kings are measured against David (the ideal, though flawed), northern kings condemned for continuing "the sin of Jeroboam" (golden calves at Bethel and Dan). Prophetic authority challenging royal power continues from Samuel-Nathan tradition: the prophet Ahijah announces kingdom division (11:29-39), unnamed prophets condemn Jeroboam (13:1-10; 14:1-18), and Elijah confronts Ahab's Baal worship (chapters 17-19, 21), establishing that prophets speak divine word to which kings must submit. Divine sovereignty working through historical events appears throughout: God divides the kingdom as judgment, preserves Davidic dynasty for covenant promises' sake, controls international affairs. Wisdom as divine gift appears in Solomon's early reign but proves insufficient without covenant faithfulness.

**Archaeological Relevance:** Archaeological evidence relating to 1 Kings events presents complex testimony. Solomon's building activities remain debated: the monumental six-chambered gates and casemate walls at Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer were traditionally attributed to Solomon based on 1 Kings 9:15, but minimalist scholars now attribute some to the 9th-century Omride dynasty. Recent excavations support earlier (10th-century) dating for some structures, though debate continues. Jerusalem temple archaeology is unavailable due to the Temple Mount's sensitivity, but comparative evidence from Phoenician and Syrian temples illuminates the description in 1 Kings 6-7. The temple's tripartite structure (porch, holy place, holy of holies) matches Syro-Phoenician architectural patterns. The Gezer calendar (10th century) evidences administrative literacy consistent with Solomonic bureaucracy. For the divided kingdom period, the Mesha Stele (9th century) provides Moabite perspective on conflicts with Israel, mentioning Omri. Tel Dan Stele fragment (9th century) references the "House of David" and possibly Jehoram, confirming Davidic dynasty and northern-southern conflicts. Samaria excavations reveal Omride-era palatial architecture and the "Samaria Ostraca" documenting administrative systems. Excavations at Tel Jezreel reveal substantial 9th-century fortress, likely Ahab's "second capital." Phoenician influence evident in material culture aligns with Hiram-Solomon partnership and Jezebel's Phoenician origin. The Elijah narratives' references to Baal worship are illuminated by Phoenician religious practices known from archaeological and textual evidence (Ugaritic texts).

**Structure:** The book contains 22 chapters divided into three major sections: (1) Solomon's reign (chapters 1-11): succession struggle, Solomon established as king, wisdom and wealth, temple and palace construction, Queen of Sheba visit, Solomon's apostasy through foreign wives, prophetic announcement of kingdom division; (2) Kingdom division and early rulers (chapters 12-16): Rehoboam's folly and northern secession, Jeroboam's golden calves at Bethel and Dan, succession of northern kings (Jeroboam, Nadab, Baasha, Elah, Zimri, Omri, Ahab) and southern kings (Rehoboam, Abijam, Asa, Jehoshaphat begins), each evaluated deuteronomistically; (3) Elijah cycle (chapters 17-22): Elijah confronts Ahab and Baal worship, drought and Mount Carmel contest, flight to Horeb, Naboth's vineyard, Ahab's wars with Aram, Ahab's death. The structure demonstrates theological interpretation of history: Solomon's glory results from divine blessing but his apostasy brings judgment (kingdom division); northern kingdom's persistent apostasy through Jeroboam's cultic innovations and Ahab's Baal worship provokes prophetic opposition; southern kingdom maintains Davidic dynasty and Jerusalem temple but struggles with high places and syncretism. The alternating accounts of northern and southern kings, synchronized chronologically, shows their interrelated yet distinct histories. Prophetic narratives (especially Elijah) interrupt royal annals, demonstrating prophetic authority over royal power in covenant enforcement. The book ends mid-narrative (Ahab's death), continuing seamlessly into 2 Kings, showing that 1-2 Kings originally formed single work divided later for scroll length.

### 1 Kings Chapter 1

Now king David was old
and stricken in years; and they covered him with clothes, but he gat no heat.
Wherefore his servants said unto him, Let there be sought for my lord the king a young virgin: and let her stand before the king, and let her cherish him, and let her lie in thy bosom, that my lord the king may get heat.
So they sought for a fair damsel throughout all the coasts of Israel, and found Abishag a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.
And the damsel
was very fair, and cherished the king, and ministered to him: but the king knew her not.
Then Adonijah the son of Haggith exalted himself, saying, I will be king: and he prepared him chariots and horsemen, and fifty men to run before him.
And his father had not displeased him at any time in saying, Why hast thou done so? and he also
was a very goodly
man; and
his mother bare him after Absalom.
And he conferred with Joab the son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest: and they following Adonijah helped
him.
But Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and Nathan the prophet, and Shimei, and Rei, and the mighty men which
belonged
 to David, were not with Adonijah.
And Adonijah slew sheep and oxen and fat cattle by the stone of Zoheleth, which
is by En-rogel, and called all his brethren the king’s sons, and all the men of Judah the king’s servants:
But Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah, and the mighty men, and Solomon his brother, he called not.
Wherefore Nathan spake unto Bath-sheba the mother of Solomon, saying, Hast thou not heard that Adonijah the son of Haggith doth reign, and David our lord knoweth
it not?
Now therefore come, let me, I pray thee, give thee counsel, that thou mayest save thine own life, and the life of thy son Solomon.
Go and get thee in unto king David, and say unto him, Didst not thou, my lord, O king, swear unto thine handmaid, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne? why then doth Adonijah reign?
Behold, while thou yet talkest there with the king, I also will come in after thee, and confirm thy words.
And Bath-sheba went in unto the king into the chamber: and the king was very old; and Abishag the Shunammite ministered unto the king.
And Bath-sheba bowed, and did obeisance unto the king. And the king said, What wouldest thou?
And she said unto him, My lord, thou swarest by the LORD thy God unto thine handmaid,
saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne.
And now, behold, Adonijah reigneth; and now, my lord the king, thou knowest
it not:
And he hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the sons of the king, and Abiathar the priest, and Joab the captain of the host: but Solomon thy servant hath he not called.
And thou, my lord, O king, the eyes of all Israel
are upon thee, that thou shouldest tell them who shall sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.
Otherwise it shall come to pass, when my lord the king shall sleep with his fathers, that I and my son Solomon shall be counted offenders.
And, lo, while she yet talked with the king, Nathan the prophet also came in.
And they told the king, saying, Behold Nathan the prophet. And when he was come in before the king, he bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground.
And Nathan said, My lord, O king, hast thou said, Adonijah shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne?
For he is gone down this day, and hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the king’s sons, and the captains of the host, and Abiathar the priest; and, behold, they eat and drink before him, and say, God save king Adonijah.
But me,
even me thy servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and thy servant Solomon, hath he not called.
Is this thing done by my lord the king, and thou hast not shewed
it unto thy servant, who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?
Then king David answered and said, Call me Bath-sheba. And she came into the king’s presence, and stood before the king.
And the king sware, and said,
As the LORD liveth, that hath redeemed my soul out of all distress,
Even as I sware unto thee by the LORD God of Israel, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne in my stead; even so will I certainly do this day.
Then Bath-sheba bowed with
her face to the earth, and did reverence to the king, and said, Let my lord king David live for ever.
And king David said, Call me Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada. And they came before the king.
The king also said unto them, Take with you the servants of your lord, and cause Solomon my son to ride upon mine own mule, and bring him down to Gihon:
And let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there king over Israel: and blow ye with the trumpet, and say, God save king Solomon.
Then ye shall come up after him, that he may come and sit upon my throne; for he shall be king in my stead: and I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and over Judah.
And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada answered the king, and said, Amen: the LORD God of my lord the king say so
too.
As the LORD hath been with my lord the king, even so be he with Solomon, and make his throne greater than the throne of my lord king David.
So Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, went down, and caused Solomon to ride upon king David’s mule, and brought him to Gihon.
And Zadok the priest took an horn of oil out of the tabernacle, and anointed Solomon. And they blew the trumpet; and all the people said, God save king Solomon.
And all the people came up after him, and the people piped with pipes, and rejoiced with great joy, so that the earth rent with the sound of them.
And Adonijah and all the guests that
were with him heard
it as they had made an end of eating. And when Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he said, Wherefore
is this noise of the city being in an uproar?
And while he yet spake, behold, Jonathan the son of Abiathar the priest came: and Adonijah said unto him, Come in; for thou
art a valiant man, and bringest good tidings.
And Jonathan answered and said to Adonijah, Verily our lord king David hath made Solomon king.
And the king hath sent with him Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and they have caused him to ride upon the king’s mule:
And Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king in Gihon: and they are come up from thence rejoicing, so that the city rang again. This
is the noise that ye have heard.
And also Solomon sitteth on the throne of the kingdom.
And moreover the king’s servants came to bless our lord king David, saying, God make the name of Solomon better than thy name, and make his throne greater than thy throne. And the king bowed himself upon the bed.
And also thus said the king, Blessed
be the LORD God of Israel, which hath given
one to sit on my throne this day, mine eyes even seeing
it.
And all the guests that
were with Adonijah were afraid, and rose up, and went every man his way.
And Adonijah feared because of Solomon, and arose, and went, and caught hold on the horns of the altar.
And it was told Solomon, saying, Behold, Adonijah feareth king Solomon: for, lo, he hath caught hold on the horns of the altar, saying, Let king Solomon swear unto me to day that he will not slay his servant with the sword.
And Solomon said, If he will shew himself a worthy man, there shall not an hair of him fall to the earth: but if wickedness shall be found in him, he shall die.
So king Solomon sent, and they brought him down from the altar. And he came and bowed himself to king Solomon: and Solomon said unto him, Go to thine house.


### 1 Kings Chapter 2

Now the days of David drew nigh that he should die; and he charged Solomon his son, saying,
I go the way of all the earth: be thou strong therefore, and shew thyself a man;
And keep the charge of the LORD thy God, to walk in his ways, to keep his statutes, and his commandments, and his judgments, and his testimonies, as it is written in the law of Moses, that thou mayest prosper in all that thou doest, and whithersoever thou turnest thyself:
That the LORD may continue his word which he spake concerning me, saying, If thy children take heed to their way, to walk before me in truth with all their heart and with all their soul, there shall not fail thee (said he) a man on the throne of Israel.
Moreover thou knowest also what Joab the son of Zeruiah did to me,
and what he did to the two captains of the hosts of Israel, unto Abner the son of Ner, and unto Amasa the son of Jether, whom he slew, and shed the blood of war in peace, and put the blood of war upon his girdle that
was about his loins, and in his shoes that
were on his feet.
Do therefore according to thy wisdom, and let not his hoar head go down to the grave in peace.
But shew kindness unto the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and let them be of those that eat at thy table: for so they came to me when I fled because of Absalom thy brother.
And, behold,
thou hast with thee Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite of Bahurim, which cursed me with a grievous curse in the day when I went to Mahanaim: but he came down to meet me at Jordan, and I sware to him by the LORD, saying, I will not put thee to death with the sword.
Now therefore hold him not guiltless: for thou
art a wise man, and knowest what thou oughtest to do unto him; but his hoar head bring thou down to the grave with blood.
So David slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David.
And the days that David reigned over Israel
were forty years: seven years reigned he in Hebron, and thirty and three years reigned he in Jerusalem.
Then sat Solomon upon the throne of David his father; and his kingdom was established greatly.
And Adonijah the son of Haggith came to Bath-sheba the mother of Solomon. And she said, Comest thou peaceably? And he said, Peaceably.
He said moreover, I have somewhat to say unto thee. And she said, Say on.
And he said, Thou knowest that the kingdom was mine, and
that
 all Israel set their faces on me, that I should reign: howbeit the kingdom is turned about, and is become my brother’s: for it was his from the LORD.
And now I ask one petition of thee, deny me not. And she said unto him, Say on.
And he said, Speak, I pray thee, unto Solomon the king, (for he will not say thee nay,) that he give me Abishag the Shunammite to wife.
And Bath-sheba said, Well; I will speak for thee unto the king.
Bath-sheba therefore went unto king Solomon, to speak unto him for Adonijah. And the king rose up to meet her, and bowed himself unto her, and sat down on his throne, and caused a seat to be set for the king’s mother; and she sat on his right hand.
Then she said, I desire one small petition of thee;
I pray thee,
 say me not nay. And the king said unto her, Ask on, my mother: for I will not say thee nay.
And she said, Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to Adonijah thy brother to wife.
And king Solomon answered and said unto his mother, And why dost thou ask Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? ask for him the kingdom also; for he
is mine elder brother; even for him, and for Abiathar the priest, and for Joab the son of Zeruiah.
Then king Solomon sware by the LORD, saying, God do so to me, and more also, if Adonijah have not spoken this word against his own life.
Now therefore,
as the LORD liveth, which hath established me, and set me on the throne of David my father, and who hath made me an house, as he promised, Adonijah shall be put to death this day.
And king Solomon sent by the hand of Benaiah the son of Jehoiada; and he fell upon him that he died.
And unto Abiathar the priest said the king, Get thee to Anathoth, unto thine own fields; for thou
art worthy of death: but I will not at this time put thee to death, because thou barest the ark of the Lord GOD before David my father, and because thou hast been afflicted in all wherein my father was afflicted.
So Solomon thrust out Abiathar from being priest unto the LORD; that he might fulfil the word of the LORD, which he spake concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh.
Then tidings came to Joab: for Joab had turned after Adonijah, though he turned not after Absalom. And Joab fled unto the tabernacle of the LORD, and caught hold on the horns of the altar.
And it was told king Solomon that Joab was fled unto the tabernacle of the LORD; and, behold,
he is by the altar. Then Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, saying, Go, fall upon him.
And Benaiah came to the tabernacle of the LORD, and said unto him, Thus saith the king, Come forth. And he said, Nay; but I will die here. And Benaiah brought the king word again, saying, Thus said Joab, and thus he answered me.
And the king said unto him, Do as he hath said, and fall upon him, and bury him; that thou mayest take away the innocent blood, which Joab shed, from me, and from the house of my father.
And the LORD shall return his blood upon his own head, who fell upon two men more righteous and better than he, and slew them with the sword, my father David not knowing
thereof, to wit, Abner the son of Ner, captain of the host of Israel, and Amasa the son of Jether, captain of the host of Judah.
Their blood shall therefore return upon the head of Joab, and upon the head of his seed for ever: but upon David, and upon his seed, and upon his house, and upon his throne, shall there be peace for ever from the LORD.
So Benaiah the son of Jehoiada went up, and fell upon him, and slew him: and he was buried in his own house in the wilderness.
And the king put Benaiah the son of Jehoiada in his room over the host: and Zadok the priest did the king put in the room of Abiathar.
And the king sent and called for Shimei, and said unto him, Build thee an house in Jerusalem, and dwell there, and go not forth thence any whither.
For it shall be,
that on the day thou goest out, and passest over the brook Kidron, thou shalt know for certain that thou shalt surely die: thy blood shall be upon thine own head.
And Shimei said unto the king, The saying
is good: as my lord the king hath said, so will thy servant do. And Shimei dwelt in Jerusalem many days.
And it came to pass at the end of three years, that two of the servants of Shimei ran away unto Achish son of Maachah king of Gath. And they told Shimei, saying, Behold, thy servants
be in Gath.
And Shimei arose, and saddled his ass, and went to Gath to Achish to seek his servants: and Shimei went, and brought his servants from Gath.
And it was told Solomon that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath, and was come again.
And the king sent and called for Shimei, and said unto him, Did I not make thee to swear by the LORD, and protested unto thee, saying, Know for a certain, on the day thou goest out, and walkest abroad any whither, that thou shalt surely die? and thou saidst unto me, The word
that I have heard
is good.
Why then hast thou not kept the oath of the LORD, and the commandment that I have charged thee with?
The king said moreover to Shimei, Thou knowest all the wickedness which thine heart is privy to, that thou didst to David my father: therefore the LORD shall return thy wickedness upon thine own head;
And king Solomon
shall be blessed, and the throne of David shall be established before the LORD for ever.
So the king commanded Benaiah the son of Jehoiada; which went out, and fell upon him, that he died. And the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon.

And Solomon loved the LORD, walking in the statutes of David his father: only he sacrificed and burnt incense in high places.
And the king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there; for that
was
 the great high place: a thousand burnt offerings did Solomon offer upon that altar.
In Gibeon the LORD appeared to Solomon in a dream by night: and God said, Ask what I shall give thee.
And Solomon said, Thou hast shewed unto thy servant David my father great mercy, according as he walked before thee in truth, and in righteousness, and in uprightness of heart with thee; and thou hast kept for him this great kindness, that thou hast given him a son to sit on his throne, as
it is
 this day.
And now, O LORD my God, thou hast made thy servant king instead of David my father: and I
am but a little child: I know not
how
 to go out or come in.
And thy servant

Give therefore thy servant an understanding heart to judge thy people, that I may discern between good and bad: for who is able to judge this thy so great a people?
And the speech pleased the Lord, that Solomon had asked this thing.
And God said unto him, Because thou hast asked this thing, and hast not asked for thyself long life; neither hast asked riches for thyself, nor hast asked the life of thine enemies; but hast asked for thyself understanding to discern judgment;
Behold, I have done according to thy words: lo, I have given thee a wise and an understanding heart; so that there was none like thee before thee, neither after thee shall any arise like unto thee.
And I have also given thee that which thou hast not asked, both riches, and honour: so that there shall not be any among the kings like unto thee all thy days.
And if thou wilt walk in my ways, to keep my statutes and my commandments, as thy father David did walk, then I will lengthen thy days.
And Solomon awoke; and, behold,
it was a dream. And he came to Jerusalem, and stood before the ark of the covenant of the LORD, and offered up burnt offerings, and offered peace offerings, and made a feast to all his servants.
Then came there two women,
that were harlots, unto the king, and stood before him.
And the one woman said, O my lord, I and this woman dwell in one house; and I was delivered of a child with her in the house.
And it came to pass the third day after that I was delivered, that this woman was delivered also: and we
were together;
there was
 no stranger with us in the house, save we two in the house.
And this woman’s child died in the night; because she overlaid it.
And she arose at midnight, and took my son from beside me, while thine handmaid slept, and laid it in her bosom, and laid her dead child in my bosom.
And when I rose in the morning to give my child suck, behold, it was dead: but when I had considered it in the morning, behold, it was not my son, which I did bear.
And the other woman said, Nay; but the living
is my son, and the dead
is thy son. And this said, No; but the dead
is
 thy son, and the living
is my son. Thus they spake before the king.
Then said the king, The one saith, This
is my son that liveth, and thy son
is the dead: and the other saith, Nay; but thy son
is the dead, and my son
is the living.
And the king said, Bring me a sword. And they brought a sword before the king.
And the king said, Divide the living child in two, and give half to the one, and half to the other.
Then spake the woman whose the living child
was unto the king, for her bowels yearned upon her son, and she said, O my lord, give her the living child, and in no wise slay it. But the other said, Let it be neither mine nor thine,
but divide
it.
Then the king answered and said, Give her the living child, and in no wise slay it: she
is the mother thereof.
And all Israel heard of the judgment which the king had judged; and they feared the king: for they saw that the wisdom of God
was in him, to do judgment.
