### Psalms Chapters 121-125: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** This section continues the Songs of Ascents with some of the Psalter's most beloved expressions of pilgrimage faith and divine protection. Psalm 121 opens with the famous words "I lift up my eyes to the hills—from where does my help come? My help comes from the LORD, who made heaven and earth." This psalm's comprehensive protection promises—YHWH who "will not slumber," who guards "your going out and your coming in"—made it central to Jewish and Christian devotion. Psalm 122 celebrates arrival in Jerusalem: "I was glad when they said to me, 'Let us go to the house of the LORD!' Our feet have been standing within your gates, O Jerusalem!" Psalm 123 expresses humble dependence: "To you I lift up my eyes, O you who are enthroned in the heavens! Behold, as the eyes of servants look to the hand of their master... so our eyes look to the LORD." Psalm 124 offers communal thanksgiving for deliverance: "If it had not been the LORD who was on our side... then they would have swallowed us up alive." Psalm 125 declares trust's security: "Those who trust in the LORD are like Mount Zion, which cannot be moved, but abides forever."

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** Psalm 121's "hills" (*hārîm*) may reference the surrounding mountains visible from pilgrimage routes approaching Jerusalem, or possibly the hills where pagan high places operated—making the psalm a polemic clarifying that help comes not from hill-shrines but from YHWH. Archaeological surveys of ancient roads to Jerusalem confirm the dramatic elevation changes pilgrims experienced. Psalm 122's detailed Jerusalem description—"built as a city that is bound firmly together," with its gates, houses, and thrones—reflects knowledge of the physical city. The reference to "thrones for judgment, the thrones of the house of David" connects to the judicial function of the royal palace complex excavated in Jerusalem. Psalm 124's imagery of flood waters and escaped birds reflects common ancient Near Eastern metaphors found in both Israelite and Mesopotamian literature. The "snare" (*paḥ*) from which the bird escapes references trapping practices documented archaeologically through trap remains and artistic depictions.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** Psalm 121's antiphonal structure—questions followed by answers—suggests liturgical dialogue, perhaps between pilgrims and priests or Levites at way-stations or city gates. The comprehensive protection formula ("your going out and your coming in") uses merism (opposites expressing totality), covering all life activities. Psalm 122's prayer for Jerusalem's peace (*šə'alû šəlôm yərûšālayim*) plays on the traditional etymology of Jerusalem as "foundation of peace." The psalm models how pilgrimage culminated in blessing the sacred city. Psalm 123's servant-master imagery reflects hierarchical social structures while using them to express spiritual dependence. The "hand of their master" from which servants receive direction and provision illuminates the metaphor. Psalm 124's congregation-involving structure ("Let Israel now say") shows how psalms engaged communities in responsive affirmation of their shared story. Psalm 125's comparison of the faithful to Mount Zion "surrounded by mountains" reflects Jerusalem's topography where higher hills on several sides create natural amphitheater.

**Political Situation:** Psalm 122's prayer for Jerusalem's "prosperity" (*šālôm*) within its "walls" and "security" within its "towers" reflects concern for the city's physical and political welfare during periods when these were threatened—whether by Assyrian siege, Babylonian destruction, or post-exilic vulnerability. The reference to tribal assemblies ("to which the tribes go up") suggests either nostalgic remembrance of united monarchy or continuing pilgrimage practices despite political division. Psalm 123's confession of having "had more than enough of contempt" from "those who are at ease" and "the proud" may reflect class tensions within Judah or subjection to foreign powers whose elite scorned Israel. Psalm 124's military imagery—enemies who would have "swallowed us up alive," "flood" and "torrent" that would have swept them away—suggests specific historical deliverance, perhaps from one of the sieges or invasions documented in Kings and Chronicles. Psalm 125's distinction between the righteous who remain secure and the wicked whose "scepter" will not rest on the righteous' land addresses political leadership concerns.

**Theological Themes:** Psalm 121 develops comprehensive providence theology: YHWH as Creator ("who made heaven and earth") provides protection exceeding any earthly guardian. The fourfold "keep" (*šāmar*) emphasizes divine vigilance, while "neither slumber nor sleep" contrasts with pagan gods (compare Elijah's mockery on Carmel: "perhaps he is sleeping," 1 Kings 18:27). Psalm 122's love for Jerusalem models how particular places become spiritually significant through divine presence and communal worship. The psalm's prayer for peace uses the root š-l-m five times, making peace the psalm's theological center. Psalm 123's humble posture—eyes lifted to the enthroned Lord—embodies the dependent trust the Psalter consistently commends. Psalm 124's counterfactual meditation—"if the LORD had not been on our side"—prompts gratitude by imagining alternative outcomes: deliverance recognition requires acknowledging that disaster was genuinely possible. Psalm 125's Zion theology makes the mountain not merely metaphor but paradigm: as Zion cannot be moved, neither can those who trust in YHWH.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** Psalm 121's protection promises have comforted countless Jewish and Christian communities; its use at funerals ("your going out") and benedictions ("from this time forth and forevermore") extends its liturgical reach. Psalm 122's Jerusalem love ("Pray for the peace of Jerusalem") has sustained Jewish attachment to the city through millennia of diaspora and continues to shape both Jewish and Christian Zion theology. The psalm's tribal assembly reference connects worship to Israel's foundational identity. Psalm 123's humble waiting posture models spiritual formation: eyes fixed on the Lord until "he has mercy upon us." Psalm 124's "our help is in the name of the LORD" became a traditional Christian invocation; its theology of grace prevents triumphalism by making survival dependent on divine intervention rather than human strength. Psalm 125's promise that "the scepter of wickedness shall not rest on the land allotted to the righteous" addresses the persistent problem of unjust rule, trusting in ultimate divine governance that limits evil's duration. The section's progression from individual journey (121) through Jerusalem arrival (122) and communal dependence (123-124) to Zion security (125) traces the pilgrimage experience from road to destination to settled confidence.

### Psalms Chapters 126-130: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** This section continues the Songs of Ascents with themes of restoration, divine blessing, and penitential hope. Psalm 126 celebrates return from exile with dream-like joy: "When the LORD restored the fortunes of Zion, we were like those who dream. Then our mouth was filled with laughter." Yet it also pleads for complete restoration: "Those who sow in tears shall reap with shouts of joy!" Psalm 127, attributed to Solomon, teaches divine dependence: "Unless the LORD builds the house, those who build it labor in vain... It is in vain that you rise up early and go late to rest... for he gives to his beloved sleep." Psalm 128 offers blessing for the God-fearing household: "Your wife will be like a fruitful vine... your children will be like olive shoots around your table." Psalm 129 remembers affliction while trusting in vindication: "Greatly have they afflicted me from my youth—let Israel now say—yet they have not prevailed against me." Psalm 130—the famous "De Profundis"—cries from the depths: "Out of the depths I cry to you, O LORD... If you, O LORD, should mark iniquities, O Lord, who could stand? But with you there is forgiveness."

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** Psalm 126's reference to "restored the fortunes of Zion" (*šûb šəbût ṣiyyôn*) most naturally references the return from Babylonian exile under Cyrus's decree (538 BCE), documented in the Cyrus Cylinder and Ezra 1. The return's partial nature—disappointment alongside hope—matches Ezra-Nehemiah's portrait of a community still yearning for full restoration. The "streams in the Negeb" imagery references the wadis of southern Judah that filled dramatically during winter rains—hope that seemed impossible could suddenly materialize. Psalm 127's Solomonic attribution connects it to wisdom literature's concern with proper priorities; Solomon's own temple-building and family life provide context (ironic given his later failures). Psalm 128's agricultural imagery—vine, olive shoots, table—reflects Iron Age Judean household economy documented through archaeological recovery of oil presses, grape vine cultivation evidence, and domestic architecture at sites like Tell Beit Mirsim and Gibeon.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** Psalm 126's agricultural metaphor—sowing in tears, reaping with joy—reflects the emotional investment Palestinian farmers made in planting during uncertain seasons. The "sheaves" (*'ălummōt*) brought home represents successful harvest. Ancient Near Eastern parallels include Mesopotamian prayers for agricultural success. Psalm 127's assertion that "children are a heritage from the LORD" (*naḥălat YHWH bānîm*) reflects the high valuation of offspring in societies without social security systems; children provided labor, carried on family name, and cared for aging parents. The "arrows in the hand of a warrior" metaphor connects family to defense. Psalm 128's domestic scene—wife as fruitful vine within the house, children as olive shoots around the table—uses botanical imagery to express flourishing family life. The olive tree's productivity for centuries made it a symbol of lasting prosperity. Psalm 130's "watching for the morning" (*šōmərîm labōqer*) references night watchmen awaiting dawn—a common ancient Near Eastern image for expectant hope.

**Political Situation:** Psalm 126's setting in the return period addresses the complex emotions of restoration: initial joy ("like those who dream") followed by recognition of unfinished work ("Restore our fortunes"). The returnees faced ruined city, hostile neighbors (Sanballat, Tobiah), and internal conflicts documented in Ezra-Nehemiah. The prayer for streams in the Negeb voices hope that the seemingly impossible could happen. Psalm 127's "unless the LORD builds the house" and "guards the city" addresses leadership anxieties: whether rebuilding temple, wall, or community, human effort alone was insufficient. The attribution to Solomon ironically evokes both his architectural achievements and the eventual kingdom division. Psalm 129's memory of affliction "from my youth" treats Israel corporately, referencing Egyptian slavery, wilderness testing, conquest resistance, and ongoing foreign threats. The plea that enemies be "like grass on the housetops" that withers addresses agricultural societies' experience with shallow-rooted growth that couldn't survive. Psalm 130's individual voice represents communal experience; personal sin mirrors national unfaithfulness that led to exile.

**Theological Themes:** Psalm 126's hope theology combines gratitude for past deliverance with longing for future completion. The transformation of tears to joy represents a pattern applicable to individual and communal experience. Psalm 127's trust theology challenges human self-reliance: working "early" and "late" accomplishes nothing without divine blessing. The surprise that God "gives to his beloved sleep" suggests rest, not relentless striving, characterizes faithful life. Psalm 128's blessing theology connects fear of the LORD to concrete prosperity—not abstractly but in household flourishing visible in spouse, children, and table. This represents "practical" wisdom's confidence that righteousness leads to blessing. Psalm 129's theology of suffering affirms that affliction may be severe ("Plowers plowed upon my back; they made long their furrows") without being ultimate ("The LORD is righteous; he has cut the cords of the wicked"). Psalm 130's penitential theology reaches the Psalter's depths: the "depths" (*ma'ămāqqîm*) represent both literal crisis and spiritual despair. The revolutionary claim that "with the LORD there is steadfast love, and with him is plentiful redemption" grounds hope in divine character rather than human merit.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** Psalm 126's joy-amid-incompleteness describes not only the return from Babylon but patterns throughout biblical history—every deliverance proves partial until eschatological fulfillment. The psalm's influence on hope theology extends through Isaiah's new exodus imagery to Christian resurrection hope. Psalm 127's household wisdom connects the Songs of Ascents to daily life; pilgrimage and domestic responsibility interpenetrate. The psalm's child-blessing became central to Jewish understanding of family as divine gift. Psalm 128's vision of blessing "all the days of your life" and seeing "your children's children" establishes multigenerational framework for understanding faithfulness. The closing "Peace be upon Israel!" connects household to nation. Psalm 129's agricultural imprecation—enemies becoming like rootless grass—uses creation order against those who oppose God's people. Psalm 130 became central to Christian penitential practice: one of the seven penitential psalms (6, 32, 38, 51, 102, 130, 143), used in Ash Wednesday and funeral liturgies. Its waiting-for-the-Lord theology (*qiwwîtî*, "I wait") became paradigmatic for faithful patience. The section's movement from communal restoration (126) through household trust (127-128) and national endurance (129) to individual penitence (130) demonstrates faith's multiple dimensions.

### Psalms Chapters 131-135: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** This section concludes the Songs of Ascents and transitions to the Psalter's final Hallelujah collection. Psalm 131—remarkably brief (3 verses)—expresses profound humility: "O LORD, my heart is not lifted up; my eyes are not raised too high... But I have calmed and quieted my soul, like a weaned child with its mother." Psalm 132—the longest Song of Ascents—celebrates David's oath to bring the ark to Jerusalem and God's reciprocal covenant promises: "The LORD swore to David a sure oath... 'One of the sons of your body I will set on your throne.'" Psalm 133 celebrates community: "Behold, how good and pleasant it is when brothers dwell in unity! It is like the precious oil on the head... like the dew of Hermon." Psalm 134 provides fitting conclusion to the pilgrimage collection: "Lift up your hands to the holy place and bless the LORD!... May the LORD bless you from Zion." Psalm 135 begins the Hallelujah praise: "Praise the LORD! Praise the name of the LORD... The LORD is great... Whatever the LORD pleases, he does."

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** Psalm 132's detailed ark narrative parallels 2 Samuel 6-7 and 1 Chronicles 13-17, documenting the ark's transfer from Kiriath-jearim to Jerusalem. The reference to "Ephrathah" (Bethlehem region) and "fields of Jaar" (Kiriath-jearim) reflects geographical knowledge of central hill country. Archaeological investigation of Kiriath-jearim (Tel el-Jib) has revealed Iron Age occupation. The psalm's Davidic covenant language ("your sons will sit on your throne forever") connects to Nathan's oracle (2 Samuel 7). Psalm 133's oil and dew imagery draws on Levitical anointing practices (Exodus 29:7; Leviticus 8:12) and Palestine's Mediterranean climate where heavy dew provides essential summer moisture. Mount Hermon's (2,814 meters) snow produces moisture that sustains northern regions—a meteorological reality underlying the metaphor. Psalm 135's historical recital—striking Egypt, defeating Sihon and Og, giving Canaan as inheritance—summarizes Numbers 21-Deuteronomy 3 events corroborated through archaeological evidence from Transjordan.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** Psalm 131's weaned child imagery (*gamûl*) reflects ancient Israelite practice where children nursed until age two or three (compare 1 Samuel 1:22-24). The weaned child no longer demands nourishment but rests contentedly—a powerful metaphor for spiritual maturation from demanding to trusting. Psalm 132's royal procession vocabulary—"Arise, O LORD, to your resting place, you and the ark of your might"—echoes Numbers 10:35-36's ark movement formula, suggesting liturgical reenactment of the ark's Jerusalem entry. The priests "clothed with righteousness" and "saints who shout for joy" describe procession participants. Psalm 133's oil flowing "down on the beard, on the beard of Aaron, running down on the collar of his robes" describes generous anointing that exceeded the head to soak garments—extravagant grace imagery. Psalm 134's night setting ("who stand by night in the house of the LORD") references Levitical night watches (1 Chronicles 9:33), with worshipers blessing God and receiving blessing "from Zion."

**Political Situation:** Psalm 132's extensive Davidic covenant exposition addresses the monarchy's legitimacy and the temple's significance. The reciprocal oaths—David's vow to find a dwelling for YHWH, God's vow to establish David's dynasty—grounded both royal and temple institutions in covenant relationship. Post-exilic use would have evoked both nostalgia for monarchic glory and hope for messianic restoration. The conditional element ("If your sons keep my covenant") explained monarchic failure without abandoning hope. Psalm 133's celebration of fraternal unity may address northern-southern division or post-exilic tensions between returnees and those who remained. The ideal of "brothers dwelling together" speaks against faction and division. Psalm 135's rehearsal of conquest victories—defeating Egyptian firstborn, Amorite and Bashan kings—served identity formation: Israel's land was divine gift secured through divine warfare, not human military prowess. The idol polemic (vv. 15-18) parallels Psalm 115, challenging foreign gods' pretensions.

**Theological Themes:** Psalm 131's brevity belies its profundity: spiritual maturity involves letting go of matters too great or marvelous (*niplā'ōt*)—accepting appropriate limits on understanding. The psalm models contemplative stillness (*dōməmî*) counter to anxious striving. Psalm 132's covenant theology holds together Davidic dynasty and Zion temple as twin divine gifts: God chose David and chose Zion, making both central to salvation history. The clothing metaphor—priests with salvation, saints with joy—presents divine gifts as garments worn by worshipers. Psalm 133's unity theology uses sensory imagery (fragrant oil, cooling dew) to make abstract harmony concrete and desirable. The theological claim that "there the LORD has commanded the blessing, life forevermore" makes unity not merely desirable but divinely mandated. Psalm 135's theology of divine freedom ("Whatever the LORD pleases, he does, in heaven and on earth") grounds praise in sovereignty. The idol contrast—images with mouths that cannot speak, eyes that cannot see—emphasizes YHWH's living reality against inert representations.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** Psalm 131's humility provides crucial counterweight to psalms of confident assertion; together they model healthy spirituality combining trust and surrender. Psalm 132's Davidic covenant summary became foundational for messianic expectation: every unfaithful king highlighted the promise's unfulfilled dimensions, building anticipation for the ideal king to come. The psalm's use in 2 Chronicles 6:41-42 at Solomon's temple dedication demonstrates liturgical function. Psalm 133's unity ideal influenced Christian understanding of church fellowship; the oil-dew imagery informed baptismal and confirmation symbolism. The phrase "life forevermore" (*ḥayyîm 'ad-hā'ôlām*) connects unity to eschatological hope. Psalm 134's night-blessing conclusion to the Songs of Ascents mirrors their beginning (120)—the pilgrimage cycle complete, worshiper blessed to return home. Psalm 135 transitions from pilgrimage to pure praise, preparing for the final Hallelujah collection (146-150). The section's movement from humility (131) through covenant celebration (132) and fraternal unity (133) to mutual blessing (134) and comprehensive praise (135) models mature covenant spirituality that prepares for the Psalter's concluding crescendo.

For thou hast possessed my reins: thou hast covered me in my mother’s womb.
I will praise thee; for I am fearfully
and wonderfully made: marvellous
are thy works; and
that my soul knoweth right well.
My substance was not hid from thee, when I was made in secret,
and curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth.
Thine eyes did see my substance, yet being unperfect; and in thy book all
my members were written,
which in continuance were fashioned, when
as yet there was none of them.
How precious also are thy thoughts unto me, O God! how great is the sum of them!
            If I should count them, they are more in number than the sand: when I awake, I am still with thee.
Surely thou wilt slay the wicked, O God: depart from me therefore, ye bloody men.
For they speak against thee wickedly,
and thine enemies take
thy name in vain.
Do not I hate them, O LORD, that hate thee? and am not I grieved with those that rise up against thee?
I hate them with perfect hatred: I count them mine enemies.
Search me, O God, and know my heart: try me, and know my thoughts:
And see if
there be any wicked way in me, and lead me in the way everlasting.

### Psalms Chapters 136-140: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** This section contains some of the Psalter's most distinctive and memorable compositions. Psalm 136—the "Great Hallel"—is unique in its responsive structure: every half-verse receives the refrain "for his steadfast love endures forever" (*kî lə'ôlām ḥasdô*). The psalm recites creation and exodus history through this liturgical lens. Psalm 137 voices the anguished memory of exile: "By the rivers of Babylon—there we sat down and there we wept when we remembered Zion... How could we sing the LORD's song in a foreign land?" Its haunting beauty and shocking imprecation against Babylon coexist. Psalm 138, attributed to David, declares confident thanksgiving: "I give you thanks, O LORD, with my whole heart; before the gods I sing your praise." Psalm 139 presents the Psalter's most profound meditation on divine omniscience and omnipresence: "O LORD, you have searched me and known me... Where shall I go from your Spirit? Or where shall I flee from your presence?" Psalm 140 returns to lament, praying for protection against violent enemies: "Deliver me, O LORD, from evil men; preserve me from violent men."

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** Psalm 136's creation-exodus structure summarizes Israel's foundational narrative: creating sun, moon, and stars (vv. 7-9), striking Egypt's firstborn (v. 10), dividing the Red Sea (v. 13), and giving Canaan as inheritance (vv. 21-22). This parallels ancient Near Eastern creation-kingship texts where divine victory over chaos established right to rule. Psalm 137's Babylonian rivers setting references the Euphrates, Tigris, and the extensive canal systems of Mesopotamia where exiled Judeans settled. Archaeological evidence from Nippur and Babylonian administrative texts confirms Jewish communities in exile. The reference to "willows" (*'ărābîm*) matches botanical evidence of riparian vegetation in Mesopotamia. Psalm 139's language of divine formation in the womb ("you knitted me together... I was being made in secret") reflects ancient Near Eastern understanding of embryonic development, while its claim that God's thoughts outnumber "the sand" uses the uncountability topos found in Egyptian and Mesopotamian literature.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** Psalm 136's antiphonal structure models ancient Israelite worship: a leader recited the historical narrative while congregation responded with the refrain. This call-and-response pattern appears in both Israelite and broader ancient Near Eastern worship contexts. Psalm 137's reference to captors demanding "songs of Zion" reveals how distinctive Israel's worship appeared to Babylonian observers. The hanging of lyres on willows—refusing to perform—constitutes liturgical resistance. The memory oath ("If I forget you, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget its skill") demonstrates how exile intensified Jerusalem attachment. Psalm 139's meditation on divine knowledge extends to most private moments: "you discern my thoughts from afar... Even before a word is on my tongue, behold, O LORD, you know it altogether." This reflects Israel's developed understanding of YHWH as knowing inner thoughts, not merely observing external behavior. Psalm 140's "evil men" whose "tongues are sharp as a serpent's" connects to wisdom tradition's concern with dangerous speech.

**Political Situation:** Psalm 136's rehearsal of exodus and conquest served political-theological purposes: Israel's land was divine gift, enemies were divinely defeated, and the "heritage" (*naḥălâ*) belonged to Israel by YHWH's decree—counter-claims notwithstanding. Psalm 137 directly addresses the Babylonian exile's political trauma. The request that God "remember" (*zəkōr*) Edom's behavior "on the day of Jerusalem" references Edom's complicity in Jerusalem's fall (compare Obadiah). The shocking imprecation—"Blessed shall he be who takes your little ones and dashes them against the rock!"—voices the horror of what Babylon had done to Judah (compare 2 Kings 25:7), committing vengeance to God rather than taking it personally. Psalm 138's mention of singing "before the gods" (*neged 'ĕlōhîm*) may reference divine council beings or, polemically, impotent foreign deities. The assertion that "all the kings of the earth shall give you thanks" expresses hope that Israel's God would receive universal acknowledgment. Psalm 140's prayer against those who "plan evil things in their heart" addresses ongoing political conspiracy and violence.

**Theological Themes:** Psalm 136's refrain theology makes *ḥesed* (steadfast love/covenant faithfulness) the interpretive lens for all reality: creation expresses *ḥesed*, exodus demonstrates *ḥesed*, conquest fulfills *ḥesed*. The 26-fold repetition drives home that everything proceeds from divine covenant love. Psalm 137's theology of memory and hope holds together genuine grief, honest rage, and ultimately faith—the exile lament becomes worship through its very articulation. Psalm 138's confidence that "though I walk in the midst of trouble, you preserve my life" combines present difficulty with assured deliverance. Psalm 139's theology of divine knowledge reaches maximal expression: God knows thoughts, words, movements, embryonic development, the count of days—nothing escapes divine awareness. Rather than feeling oppressed by such knowledge, the psalmist finds comfort: "How precious to me are your thoughts, O God!" The psalm moves from describing divine omniscience to requesting divine judgment: "Search me, O God, and know my heart... see if there be any grievous way in me." Psalm 140's trust theology commits both protection and vindication to God.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** Psalm 136's Great Hallel became central to Jewish Passover celebration; its historical recital format influenced subsequent liturgical commemorations. The refrain's Christian adaptation—"For His mercy endures forever"—made it one of the most widely sung biblical phrases. Psalm 137's raw honesty about exile shaped Jewish and Christian understanding of how faith processes trauma. The psalm's influence extends through spirituals, classical music, and liberation theology. Psalm 138's royal thanksgiving anticipates the ultimate king whose "glory and praise" would extend universally. Psalm 139's profound theology of divine knowledge became foundational for Christian understanding of providence, predestination, and the sanctity of life (the womb passages influence abortion ethics discussions). The psalm's closing petition—"lead me in the way everlasting"—uses language applied by Christians to eternal life. Psalm 140's identification of the "violent man" (*'îš ḥămāsîm*) contributes to the righteous-wicked contrast central to wisdom and prophetic traditions. The section's movement from liturgical history (136) through exilic lament (137) and personal thanksgiving (138) to divine knowledge (139) and protection prayer (140) demonstrates the Psalter's theological breadth.

### Psalms Chapter 141

Let my prayer be set forth before thee
as incense;
and

it shall be a kindness: and let him reprove me;

But mine eyes

### Psalms Chapters 141-145: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** This section presents a final Davidic collection before the concluding Hallelujah sequence. Psalm 141 offers evening prayer: "Let my prayer be counted as incense before you, and the lifting up of my hands as the evening sacrifice!" The psalm petitions for speech discipline: "Set a guard, O LORD, over my mouth." Psalm 142's superscription places David "in the cave" (1 Samuel 22 or 24): "With my voice I cry out to the LORD... I pour out my complaint before him... No one cares for my soul." Psalm 143—the seventh penitential psalm—pleads for deliverance: "In your faithfulness answer me, in your righteousness!... Do not enter into judgment with your servant, for no one living is righteous before you." Psalm 144 celebrates divine warrior strength: "Blessed be the LORD, my rock, who trains my hands for war, and my fingers for battle." Psalm 145—David's final attributed psalm—offers comprehensive alphabetic praise: "I will extol you, my God and King, and bless your name forever and ever... Great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised."

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** Psalm 141's incense imagery connects prayer to temple ritual; incense altars have been found at numerous Israelite sites including Arad, Megiddo, and Ta'anach, confirming widespread incense use in worship. The evening sacrifice (*minḥat 'ereb*) occurred at twilight, making sunset a designated prayer time (compare Daniel 6:10). Psalm 142's cave setting evokes the Judean wilderness caves that provided refuge for fugitives and outlaws; archaeological exploration of caves near En-Gedi has revealed Iron Age occupation evidence. Psalm 144's warrior language—"my rock," "my fortress," "shield," "battle"—uses imagery consistent with Iron Age military terminology. The bow, sword, and "strange children" whose "right hand is a right hand of falsehood" reflect warfare realities. Psalm 145's acrostic structure (like Psalms 111, 112, 119) demonstrates scribal sophistication; interestingly, the Dead Sea Scrolls (11QPsa) preserve a nun verse missing from the Masoretic Text, suggesting textual traditions varied.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** Psalm 141's prayer-as-incense metaphor (*qəṭōret*) reflects the understanding that prayer ascends to God like fragrant smoke—a concept attested in both Israelite and broader ancient Near Eastern worship. The raised hands (*maśśə'at kappāy*) represent the standard ancient prayer posture with palms upward. Psalm 142's "cave" setting recalls how caves served as refuges throughout Israelite history (Judges 6:2; 1 Samuel 13:6), becoming metaphors for distress and isolation. The psalm's first-person intensity ("I cry... I pour out... I tell") models individual lament. Psalm 143's confession that "no one living is righteous before you" articulates human inability to meet divine standards, preparing for reliance on God's righteousness rather than self-justification. Psalm 144's celebration of progeny and prosperity—"our sons like plants... our daughters like corner pillars... our barns full"—reflects the integrated understanding of blessing encompassing family, agriculture, and livestock. Psalm 145's daily praise structure influenced Jewish liturgical practice; the psalm is recited three times daily in traditional Jewish prayer (Ashrei).

**Political Situation:** Psalm 142's cave experience connects to David's political vulnerability as Saul's fugitive. The confession "No one cares for my soul" (*'ên dôrēš lənafšî*) voices the isolation of those caught in political conflicts where previous allies abandon them. Psalm 143's appeal that God not enter "into judgment" suggests the psalmist faces accusations, whether from human or divine courts. The declaration that enemies have "crushed my life to the ground... made me sit in darkness" evokes imprisonment or siege. Psalm 144's warrior rhetoric—training hands for war, subduing peoples, receiving deliverance in battle—reflects royal military functions. The contrast between divine permanence and human transience ("Man is like a breath; his days are like a passing shadow") provides perspective on political ambitions. Psalm 144's vision of societal blessing—prosperous children, full barns, secure streets where "there is no breaching or going out or cry of alarm"—describes the king's ultimate responsibility to establish shalom. Psalm 145's universal kingdom theology ("Your kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and your dominion endures throughout all generations") transcends any particular political arrangement.

**Theological Themes:** Psalm 141's request that righteous rebuke be received as blessing ("Let a righteous man strike me—it is a kindness; let him rebuke me—it is oil for my head") reflects wisdom's value for correction. Psalm 142's theology of divine "portion" (*ḥelqî*)—"You are my refuge, my portion in the land of the living"—uses land-inheritance language for spiritual relationship: God is the psalmist's inheritance. Psalm 143's final penitential psalm summarizes the collection's theology: human unworthiness, divine faithfulness, plea for deliverance based on God's character rather than human merit. The request "Teach me to do your will" connects righteousness to instruction, not mere command. Psalm 144 develops the theology of divine condescension: "What is man that you regard him, or the son of man that you think of him?"—echoing Psalm 8 but applied to military-political deliverance. Psalm 145's theology celebrates divine kingship, compassion, and faithfulness: "The LORD is gracious and merciful, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love. The LORD is good to all, and his mercy is over all that he has made."

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** Psalm 141's evening prayer function shaped Jewish and Christian liturgical hours; the incense-prayer connection continues in both traditions (compare Revelation 5:8; 8:3-4). Psalm 142's isolation lament provided paradigm for countless individuals who felt abandoned; Jesus' cry of dereliction from the cross echoes this tradition. Psalm 143's confession influenced Pauline hamartiology: the assertion "no one living is righteous before you" anticipates Romans 3:20's conclusion that no one is justified by law observance. Psalm 144's vision of comprehensive societal blessing—family prosperity, agricultural abundance, urban security—provides template for understanding "the good life" not as individual achievement but communal flourishing under divine blessing. Psalm 145's position as David's final psalm before the concluding Hallelujahs makes it transitional: the human voice that has dominated the Psalter now calls all creation to join. The psalm's use in Jewish liturgy (three times daily) testifies to its ongoing significance. The section's progression from evening prayer (141) through crisis (142-143) to victory celebration (144) and comprehensive praise (145) traces faith's journey from petition through deliverance to doxology.

### Psalms Chapters 146-150: Contextual Analysis

**Narrative Summary:** The Psalter concludes with five Hallelujah psalms that form a magnificent crescendo of universal praise. Each begins and ends with "Hallelujah" (*hallělû yāh*), creating a doxological envelope for the entire book. Psalm 146 warns against trusting human rulers ("Put not your trust in princes, in a son of man, in whom there is no salvation") while celebrating God who "executes justice for the oppressed... gives food to the hungry... sets the prisoners free." Psalm 147 celebrates both cosmic creation and Jerusalem's restoration: "He heals the brokenhearted... he determines the number of the stars; he gives to all of them their names." Psalm 148 summons all creation to praise—celestial beings, heavenly bodies, sea creatures, weather, mountains, trees, animals, humans: "Let them praise the name of the LORD, for his name alone is exalted." Psalm 149 calls Israel to "sing to the LORD a new song" with dancing and instruments, anticipating eschatological victory. Psalm 150's final comprehensive summons—"Praise him with trumpet sound... with lute and harp... with tambourine and dance... with strings and pipe... with sounding cymbals"—culminates in the Psalter's final verse: "Let everything that has breath praise the LORD! Praise the LORD!"

**Historical and Archaeological Context:** The final Hallel collection (146-150) represents the Psalter's latest editorial layer, deliberately positioned as conclusion. The Greek Septuagint titles Psalms 146-147 as "of Haggai and Zechariah," connecting them to post-exilic prophets and Jerusalem's restoration—though this attribution is not in the Hebrew. Psalm 147's reference to God "building up Jerusalem" and "gathering the outcasts of Israel" directly addresses the return from Babylon and Nehemiah's wall-rebuilding (compare Nehemiah 12:27-47). Psalm 148's cosmic praise catalogue—sun, moon, stars, highest heavens, waters above heavens, sea creatures, fire and hail, snow and mist, mountains, trees, animals—represents systematic coverage of creation categories similar to Genesis 1's organization. Psalm 149's victory celebration with "a two-edged sword in their hands, to execute vengeance on the nations" may reference Maccabean hopes or eschatological expectations. Psalm 150's instrument catalogue—shofar, psaltery (*nēbel*), harp (*kinnôr*), timbrel (*tōp*), strings (*minnîm*), pipe (*'ûgāb*), cymbals (*ṣelṣəlîm*)—documents Second Temple worship's orchestral richness, confirmed by depictions in ancient Near Eastern art.

**Cultural Practices Reflected:** The five concluding psalms model comprehensive worship: individual commitment (146), communal celebration (147), cosmic participation (148), eschatological anticipation (149), and instrumental praise (150). Psalm 146's beatitude on helping the poor ("Blessed is he whose help is the God of Jacob") reflects Jewish social ethics emphasizing care for oppressed, hungry, imprisoned, blind, and orphaned. Psalm 147's coupling of cosmic power ("he determines the number of the stars") with tender compassion ("he heals the brokenhearted") models Israel's distinctive theology combining transcendence and immanence. Psalm 148's call for "young men and maidens together, old men and children" to praise demonstrates worship's inclusiveness across age and gender. Psalm 149's instruction to "praise his name with dancing" (*bəmāḥôl*) confirms dance's liturgical role—something later Jewish and Christian traditions both embraced and restricted. Psalm 150's temple focus ("Praise God in his sanctuary") alongside cosmic scope ("praise him in his mighty heavens") holds together particular and universal worship.

**Political Situation:** Psalm 146's warning against trusting princes addresses post-exilic Judah's temptation to seek security through political alliances rather than divine faithfulness. The assertion that "when his breath departs he returns to his earth; on that very day his plans perish" provides theological realism about human leadership's limitations—crucial for communities subject to Persian (later Greek) imperial rule. Psalm 147's celebration of Jerusalem's rebuilding and Israel's gathering speaks directly to the restoration community's experience and ongoing hopes. The declaration that God "has not dealt thus with any other nation" affirms Israel's distinctive election despite lack of political autonomy. Psalm 148's cosmic vision relativizes political concerns: if sun, moon, kings, and common people all equally owe praise to YHWH, earthly power differentials become secondary. Psalm 149's victory imagery—executing vengeance on nations, binding kings with chains—voices hope for eschatological reversal when Israel's oppressors face divine judgment. The post-exilic community lived under foreign rule; such psalms sustained hope for ultimate vindication without authorizing political violence.

**Theological Themes:** The final Hallel summarizes and culminates Psalter theology. Psalm 146 develops theology of divine help versus human unreliability: YHWH "keeps faith forever" while human plans perish at death. The catalogue of divine activities—executing justice, giving food, setting prisoners free, opening blind eyes, lifting the bowed down, loving the righteous—provides comprehensive portrait of God's character. Psalm 147 holds together creation and redemption theology: the God who numbers stars and heals hearts is one. The assertion that God "delights not in the strength of the horse" nor "takes pleasure in the legs of a man" but "takes pleasure in those who fear him" grounds hope in divine grace rather than human capacity. Psalm 148's theology of praise includes all creation as worshipers—not merely metaphorically but actually. If YHWH created and commands all, all appropriately respond with praise. Psalm 149 develops eschatological theology: the "new song" anticipates final victory, "glory" reserved for the faithful. Psalm 150's theology reduces to simplest expression: everything exists to praise YHWH. The sevenfold "praise him" (*hallělûhû*) achieves completeness. "Everything that has breath" (*kōl hannəšāmâ*) includes all life, making praise the purpose of existence.

**Connection to Broader Narrative:** The final Hallel brings the Psalter to completion in pure doxology. From Psalm 1's individual meditation on Torah through Psalm 150's cosmic praise, the entire collection moves toward comprehensive worship. The five concluding Hallelujahs parallel the Psalter's five-book structure, providing fitting conclusion to each theme developed throughout. Psalm 146-150 became the "Daily Hallel" (*Pesukei d'Zimrah*) in Jewish morning liturgy, ensuring these psalms begin each day's worship. Psalm 148's cosmic praise influenced the Benedicite (Song of the Three Young Men) and Christian canticle traditions. Psalm 150's instrument catalogue shaped both Jewish and Christian understanding of music's liturgical role—debates about which instruments are appropriate often reference this psalm. The final command—"Let everything that has breath praise the LORD"—provides the Psalter's ultimate theological conclusion: existence itself finds meaning and purpose in doxology. All the struggles, laments, confessions, thanksgivings, and celebrations throughout the Psalter culminate here. The human voice that has cried from the depths, questioned divine justice, celebrated victory, and confessed sin now joins all creation in undivided praise. The Psalter begins with the blessed individual meditating on Torah (Psalm 1) and ends with everything that breathes praising YHWH (Psalm 150)—the proper response to covenant relationship from individual reading to cosmic worship.

## Proverbs

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Proverbs is a collection compiled over several centuries, with material spanning from the early monarchy (10th century BCE) through the post-exilic period (5th-4th centuries BCE). The book explicitly identifies multiple historical layers: "The proverbs of Solomon son of David, king of Israel" (1:1) attributes the core collection to Solomon's era (c. 970-930 BCE). Solomon's reputation for wisdom (1 Kings 3:16-28; 4:29-34) and international cultural exchange established him as Israel's quintessential sage, though whether he personally authored these proverbs or patronized their collection remains debated. Proverbs 25:1 notes "These are more proverbs of Solomon, copied by the men of Hezekiah king of Judah," indicating editorial activity during Hezekiah's reign (late 8th century BCE), a period of literary renaissance and reform. Additional collections attribute material to "the wise" (22:17; 24:23), "Agur son of Jakeh" (30:1), and "King Lemuel" (31:1)—figures whose identity and dating remain uncertain but suggest non-Israelite or international sources, reflecting wisdom's cosmopolitan character. The striking parallels between Proverbs 22:17-24:22 and the Egyptian "Instruction of Amenemope" (dated 13th-11th centuries BCE) indicate international wisdom exchange during the late Bronze Age or early Iron Age. Most scholars view Proverbs' final redaction occurring during the post-exilic period (5th-4th centuries BCE) when scribes compiled and organized earlier collections into the current 31-chapter form, creating a wisdom textbook for Second Temple Judaism.

**Author and Audience:** Proverbs credits multiple authors, reflecting its composite nature. **Solomon** receives primary attribution (1:1; 10:1; 25:1), based on his legendary wisdom, extensive proverbs (1 Kings 4:32 claims 3,000 proverbs), and royal court patronage of learning. However, Solomonic attribution may represent honorific association (like attributing psalms to David or law to Moses) rather than literal authorship. Critical scholarship sees much material as post-Solomonic, compiled by wisdom schools over centuries. **The Wise** are credited in 22:17 and 24:23, referring to professional sages or teachers in Israel's educational institutions. **Agur son of Jakeh** (30:1) and **King Lemuel** (31:1) represent unknown figures, possibly non-Israelite, emphasizing wisdom's international scope. Lemuel's teaching from "his mother" (31:1) is unusual, acknowledging women's role in wisdom transmission. The **men of Hezekiah** (25:1) served as royal scribes and editors during Judah's literary flourishing. The intended audience was primarily young men being educated for administrative, commercial, or religious leadership roles. The repeated address "my son" (1:8, 10; 2:1; 3:1, etc.) reflects the pedagogical context of wisdom schools where teachers instructed students. Content addresses concerns of urban, educated males: avoiding prostitutes and adulteresses (2:16-19; 5:1-23; 6:20-35; 7:1-27), proper speech and conduct in royal courts (16:10-15; 25:2-7), business ethics, financial prudence, and social relationships. However, Proverbs concludes with the "woman of noble character" poem (31:10-31), celebrating feminine wisdom and virtue. The broader audience included all Israelites seeking to live skillfully and righteously, making wisdom accessible beyond elite education.

**Key Themes:** Proverbs develops practical theology through pithy sayings teaching the art of living well. **The fear of the LORD** is the foundational theme, declared as "the beginning of knowledge" (1:7) and "the beginning of wisdom" (9:10), establishing that true wisdom is fundamentally theological, grounded in reverent relationship with Yahweh. **Wisdom versus folly** provides the central contrast: wisdom leads to life, prosperity, and honor; folly leads to destruction, poverty, and shame. Wisdom is personified as a woman calling people to understanding (1:20-33; 8:1-36; 9:1-6), while folly is also personified as a seductive adulteress leading to death (7:6-27; 9:13-18). **Retribution theology** dominates: righteous actions produce good consequences; wicked actions bring bad consequences. This moral order is embedded in creation, not merely imposed externally. However, Proverbs acknowledges exceptions (occasional prosperity of the wicked, suffering of the righteous) without fully resolving the tension—something Job and Ecclesiastes will explore more deeply. **Practical ethics** address speech (power of tongue, honest vs. deceptive words), work (diligence vs. laziness), wealth (proper and improper acquisition, generosity vs. greed), family (honor parents, discipline children, faithful marriage), friendship (choosing companions, loyalty), justice (fair dealings, concern for the poor), and self-control (anger, appetites, sexual purity). **Parental instruction** emphasizes training children in wisdom (22:6). **The power of words** is repeatedly stressed—speech can heal or harm, build up or destroy. **Social responsibility** includes concern for the poor and vulnerable (14:31; 19:17; 21:13; 22:22-23), fair business practices, and honest governance. **The personification of Wisdom** in chapters 1-9 presents Wisdom as existing before creation, participating in God's creative work (8:22-31), inviting people to feast at her table (9:1-6), and offering life to those who embrace her.

**Archaeological Relevance:** Proverbs reflects and parallels international wisdom traditions documented archaeologically throughout the ancient Near East. The most significant parallel is **The Instruction of Amenemope**, an Egyptian wisdom text from the Ramesside period (13th-11th centuries BCE), showing striking similarities to Proverbs 22:17-24:22 in structure, vocabulary, and content. This demonstrates cultural exchange between Israel and Egypt during the late Bronze Age or early Iron Age. Other **Egyptian instruction texts** include: The Instruction of Ptahhotep (Old Kingdom, c. 2400 BCE), Teaching of Ani (New Kingdom, c. 1300 BCE), and Instruction of Ankhsheshonq (Ptolemaic period), all addressing similar themes of wisdom, proper conduct, speech, and social relationships. **Mesopotamian wisdom** includes: The Instructions of Shuruppak (Sumerian, 3rd millennium BCE), Akkadian proverb collections from various periods, and the Counsels of Wisdom. **Sumerian proverb collections** discovered at Nippur and other sites contain sayings parallel in form and content to biblical proverbs. Archaeological evidence confirms **scribal schools** in Egypt and Mesopotamia where young men trained as administrators, learning reading, writing, mathematics, and wisdom literature—providing the institutional context for books like Proverbs. **Israelite inscriptions** like the Gezer Calendar, Siloam Inscription, and various ostraca demonstrate widespread literacy among administrative classes in monarchic Judah and Israel, supporting the existence of similar educational institutions. The **30 sayings** structure mentioned in Proverbs 22:20 ("Have I not written thirty sayings") parallels the thirty chapters in Amenemope, confirming literary borrowing or shared traditions. These parallels don't diminish Proverbs' uniqueness but situate it within international wisdom while emphasizing distinctive Israelite theology centered on Yahweh-fear.

**Structure:** Proverbs contains 31 chapters organized into distinct collections with different literary styles and editorial frameworks. **Prologue (1:1-7):** Introduces the book's purpose, audience, and foundational principle ("The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge"). **Part I: Wisdom's Instructions (1:8-9:18):** Extended discourses from father to son, featuring personified Wisdom calling people to understanding and contrasting wisdom with folly. Includes warnings against sinful enticements, adultery, and foolishness, while celebrating Wisdom's role in creation. This section uses longer pedagogical speeches rather than short proverbs. **Part II: Proverbs of Solomon (10:1-22:16):** 375 individual proverbs, predominantly two-line sayings using antithetical parallelism (contrasting righteous and wicked, wise and foolish). Attributes to Solomon. No apparent topical organization; sayings seem randomly arranged, requiring readers to discern patterns and applications. **Part III: Sayings of the Wise (22:17-24:22):** Thirty sayings (22:20) closely paralleling Egyptian Instruction of Amenemope, using instruction format ("Do not..." commands). Focuses on social justice, proper conduct, and avoiding wickedness. **Part IV: Additional Sayings of the Wise (24:23-34):** Brief collection emphasizing justice, diligence, and honest testimony. **Part V: More Proverbs of Solomon (25:1-29:27):** Second major Solomonic collection, copied by Hezekiah's scribes. Includes extended comparison proverbs, royal sayings, and practical wisdom. Shows more topical grouping than chapters 10-22. **Part VI: Sayings of Agur (30:1-33):** Numerical sayings ("three things... four") and observations about the natural world and human behavior. **Part VII: Sayings of King Lemuel (31:1-9):** Instructions from Lemuel's mother about kingship, justice, and avoiding vice. **Epilogue: The Woman of Noble Character (31:10-31):** Acrostic poem (each verse begins with successive Hebrew alphabet letters) celebrating the virtuous woman, personifying wisdom in practical form and concluding the book by demonstrating that true wisdom is embodied, not merely theoretical.

### Proverbs Chapter 15

A soft answer turneth away wrath: but grievous words stir up anger.
The tongue of the wise useth knowledge aright: but the mouth of fools poureth out foolishness.
The eyes of the LORD
are in every place, beholding the evil and the good.
A wholesome tongue
is a tree of life: but perverseness therein
is a breach in the spirit.
A fool despiseth his father’s instruction: but he that regardeth reproof is prudent.
In the house of the righteous
is much treasure: but in the revenues of the wicked is trouble.
The lips of the wise disperse knowledge: but the heart of the foolish
doeth not so.
The sacrifice of the wicked
is an abomination to the LORD: but the prayer of the upright
is his delight.
The way of the wicked
is an abomination unto the LORD: but he loveth him that followeth after righteousness.
Correction
is grievous unto him that forsaketh the way:
and he that hateth reproof shall die.
Hell and destruction
are before the LORD: how much more then the hearts of the children of men?
A scorner loveth not one that reproveth him: neither will he go unto the wise.
A merry heart maketh a cheerful countenance: but by sorrow of the heart the spirit is broken.
The heart of him that hath understanding seeketh knowledge: but the mouth of fools feedeth on foolishness.
All the days of the afflicted
are evil: but he that is of a merry heart
hath a continual feast.
Better
is little with the fear of the LORD than great treasure and trouble therewith.
Better
is a dinner of herbs where love is, than a stalled ox and hatred therewith.
A wrathful man stirreth up strife: but
he that is slow to anger appeaseth strife.
The way of the slothful
man is as an hedge of thorns: but the way of the righteous
is made plain.
A wise son maketh a glad father: but a foolish man despiseth his mother.
Folly
is joy to
him that is destitute of wisdom: but a man of understanding walketh uprightly.
Without counsel purposes are disappointed: but in the multitude of counsellors they are established.
A man hath joy by the answer of his mouth: and a word
spoken
 in due season, how good
is it!
The way of life
is above to the wise, that he may depart from hell beneath.
The LORD will destroy the house of the proud: but he will establish the border of the widow.
The thoughts of the wicked
are an abomination to the LORD: but
the words of the pure
are pleasant words.
He that is greedy of gain troubleth his own house; but he that hateth gifts shall live.
The heart of the righteous studieth to answer: but the mouth of the wicked poureth out evil things.
The LORD
is far from the wicked: but he heareth the prayer of the righteous.
The light of the eyes rejoiceth the heart:
and a good report maketh the bones fat.
The ear that heareth the reproof of life abideth among the wise.
He that refuseth instruction despiseth his own soul: but he that heareth reproof getteth understanding.
The fear of the LORD
is the instruction of wisdom; and before honour
is humility.

### Proverbs Chapter 16

The preparations of the heart in man, and the answer of the tongue,
is from the LORD.
All the ways of a man
are clean in his own eyes; but the LORD weigheth the spirits.
Commit thy works unto the LORD, and thy thoughts shall be established.
The LORD hath made all
things for himself: yea, even the wicked for the day of evil.
Every one
that is proud in heart
is an abomination to the LORD:
though hand
join in hand, he shall not be unpunished.
By mercy and truth iniquity is purged: and by the fear of the LORD
men depart from evil.
When a man’s ways please the LORD, he maketh even his enemies to be at peace with him.
Better
is a little with righteousness than great revenues without right.
A man’s heart deviseth his way: but the LORD directeth his steps.
A divine sentence
is in the lips of the king: his mouth transgresseth not in judgment.
A just weight and balance
are the LORD’S: all the weights of the bag
are his work.
It is an abomination to kings to commit wickedness: for the throne is established by righteousness.
Righteous lips
are the delight of kings; and they love him that speaketh right.
The wrath of a king
is as messengers of death: but a wise man will pacify it.
In the light of the king’s countenance
is life; and his favour
is as a cloud of the latter rain.
How much better
is it to get wisdom than gold! and to get understanding rather to be chosen than silver!
The highway of the upright
is to depart from evil: he that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.
Pride
goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall.
Better
it is to be of an humble spirit with the lowly, than to divide the spoil with the proud.
He that handleth a matter wisely shall find good: and whoso trusteth in the LORD, happy
is he.
The wise in heart shall be called prudent: and the sweetness of the lips increaseth learning.
Understanding
is a wellspring of life unto him that hath it: but the instruction of fools
is folly.
The heart of the wise teacheth his mouth, and addeth learning to his lips.
Pleasant words
are as an honeycomb, sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.
There is a way that seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof
are the ways of death.
He that laboureth laboureth for himself; for his mouth craveth it of him.
An ungodly man diggeth up evil: and in his lips
there is
 as a burning fire.
A froward man soweth strife: and a whisperer separateth chief friends.
A violent man enticeth his neighbour, and leadeth him into the way
that is not good.
He shutteth his eyes to devise froward things: moving his lips he bringeth evil to pass.
The hoary head
is a crown of glory,
if it be found in the way of righteousness.
He that is slow to anger
is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit than he that taketh a city.
The lot is cast into the lap; but the whole disposing thereof
is of the LORD.


### Proverbs Chapter 17

Better
is a dry morsel, and quietness therewith, than an house full of sacrifices
with strife.
A wise servant shall have rule over a son that causeth shame, and shall have part of the inheritance among the brethren.
The fining pot
is for silver, and the furnace for gold: but the LORD trieth the hearts.
A wicked doer giveth heed to false lips;
and a liar giveth ear to a naughty tongue.
Whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker:
and he that is glad at calamities shall not be unpunished.
Children’s children
are the crown of old men; and the glory of children
are their fathers.
Excellent speech becometh not a fool: much less do lying lips a prince.
A gift
is as a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it: whithersoever it turneth, it prospereth.
He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeateth a matter separateth
very friends.
A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.
An evil
man seeketh only rebellion: therefore a cruel messenger shall be sent against him.
Let a bear robbed of her whelps meet a man, rather than a fool in his folly.
Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
The beginning of strife
is as when one letteth out water: therefore leave off contention, before it be meddled with.
He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just, even they both
are abomination to the LORD.
Wherefore
is there a price in the hand of a fool to get wisdom, seeing
he hath no heart
to it?
A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
A man void of understanding striketh hands,
and becometh surety in the presence of his friend.
He loveth transgression that loveth strife:
and he that exalteth his gate seeketh destruction.
He that hath a froward heart findeth no good: and he that hath a perverse tongue falleth into mischief.
He that begetteth a fool
doeth it to his sorrow: and the father of a fool hath no joy.
A merry heart doeth good
like a medicine: but a broken spirit drieth the bones.
A wicked
man taketh a gift out of the bosom to pervert the ways of judgment.
Wisdom
is before him that hath understanding; but the eyes of a fool
are in the ends of the earth.
A foolish son
is a grief to his father, and bitterness to her that bare him.
Also to punish the just
is not good,
nor to strike princes for equity.
He that hath knowledge spareth his words:
and a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit.
Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise:
and
 he that shutteth his lips
is esteemed a man of understanding.


### Proverbs Chapter 18

Through desire a man, having separated himself, seeketh
and
 intermeddleth with all wisdom.
A fool hath no delight in understanding, but that his heart may discover itself.
When the wicked cometh,
then cometh also contempt, and with ignominy reproach.
The words of a man’s mouth
are as deep waters,
and
 the wellspring of wisdom
as a flowing brook.
It is not good to accept the person of the wicked, to overthrow the righteous in judgment.
A fool’s lips enter into contention, and his mouth calleth for strokes.
A fool’s mouth
is his destruction, and his lips
are
 the snare of his soul.
The words of a talebearer
are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
He also that is slothful in his work is brother to him that is a great waster.
The name of the LORD
is a strong tower: the righteous runneth into it, and is safe.
The rich man’s wealth
is his strong city, and as an high wall in his own conceit.
Before destruction the heart of man is haughty, and before honour
is humility.
He that answereth a matter before he heareth
it, it
is folly and shame unto him.
The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity; but a wounded spirit who can bear?
The heart of the prudent getteth knowledge; and the ear of the wise seeketh knowledge.
A man’s gift maketh room for him, and bringeth him before great men.
He that is first in his own cause
seemeth just; but his neighbour cometh and searcheth him.
The lot causeth contentions to cease, and parteth between the mighty.
A brother offended
is harder to be won than a strong city: and
their contentions
are like the bars of a castle.
A man’s belly shall be satisfied with the fruit of his mouth;
and with the increase of his lips shall he be filled.
Death and life
are in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.
Whoso findeth a wife findeth a good
thing, and obtaineth favour of the LORD.
The poor useth intreaties; but the rich answereth roughly.
A man
that hath friends must shew himself friendly: and there is a friend
that sticketh closer than a brother.


### Proverbs Chapter 19

Better
is the poor that walketh in his integrity, than
he that is perverse in his lips, and is a fool.
Also,
that the soul
be without knowledge,
it is
 not good; and he that hasteth with
his feet sinneth.
The foolishness of man perverteth his way: and his heart fretteth against the LORD.
Wealth maketh many friends; but the poor is separated from his neighbour.
A false witness shall not be unpunished, and
he that speaketh lies shall not escape.
Many will intreat the favour of the prince: and every man
is
 a friend to him that giveth gifts.
All the brethren of the poor do hate him: how much more do his friends go far from him? he pursueth
them with words,
yet they
are wanting
to him.
He that getteth wisdom loveth his own soul:
he that keepeth understanding shall find good.
A false witness shall not be unpunished, and he that speaketh lies shall perish.
Delight is not seemly for a fool; much less for a servant to have rule over princes.
The discretion of a man deferreth his anger; and
it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
The king’s wrath
is as the roaring of a lion; but his favour
is as dew upon the grass.
A foolish son
is the calamity of his father: and the contentions of a wife
are a continual dropping.
House and riches
are the inheritance of fathers and a prudent wife
is from the LORD.
Slothfulness casteth into a deep sleep; and an idle soul shall suffer hunger.
He that keepeth the commandment keepeth his own soul;
but
 he that despiseth his ways shall die.
He that hath pity upon the poor lendeth unto the LORD; and that which he hath given will he pay him again.
Chasten thy son while there is hope, and let not thy soul spare for his crying.
A man of great wrath shall suffer punishment: for if thou deliver
him, yet thou must do it again.
Hear counsel, and receive instruction, that thou mayest be wise in thy latter end.
There are many devices in a man’s heart; nevertheless the counsel of the LORD, that shall stand.
The desire of a man
is his kindness: and a poor man
is better than a liar.
The fear of the LORD
tendeth to life: and
he that hath it shall abide satisfied; he shall not be visited with evil.
A slothful
man hideth his hand in
his bosom, and will not so much as bring it to his mouth again.
Smite a scorner, and the simple will beware: and reprove one that hath understanding,
and he will understand knowledge.
He that wasteth
his father,
and chaseth away
his mother,
is a son that causeth shame, and bringeth reproach.
Cease, my son, to hear the instruction
that causeth to err from the words of knowledge.
An ungodly witness scorneth judgment: and the mouth of the wicked devoureth iniquity.
Judgments are prepared for scorners, and stripes for the back of fools.


### Proverbs Chapter 20

Wine
is a mocker, strong drink
is raging: and whosoever is deceived thereby is not wise.
The fear of a king
is as the roaring of a lion:
whoso
 provoketh him to anger sinneth
against his own soul.
It is an honour for a man to cease from strife: but every fool will be meddling.
The sluggard will not plow by reason of the cold;
therefore
 shall he beg in harvest, and
have nothing.
Counsel in the heart of man
is like deep water; but a man of understanding will draw it out.
Most men will proclaim every one his own goodness: but a faithful man who can find?
The just
man walketh in his integrity: his children
are
 blessed after him.
A king that sitteth in the throne of judgment scattereth away all evil with his eyes.
Who can say, I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin?
Divers weights,
and divers measures, both of them
are
 alike abomination to the LORD.
Even a child is known by his doings, whether his work
be
 pure, and whether
it be right.
The hearing ear, and the seeing eye, the LORD hath made even both of them.
Love not sleep, lest thou come to poverty; open thine eyes,
and
 thou shalt be satisfied with bread.
It is naught,
it is naught, saith the buyer: but when he is gone his way, then he boasteth.
There is gold, and a multitude of rubies: but the lips of knowledge
are a precious jewel.
Take his garment that is surety
for a stranger: and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.
Bread of deceit
is sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.
Every purpose is established by counsel: and with good advice make war.
He that goeth about
as a talebearer revealeth secrets: therefore meddle not with him that flattereth with his lips.
Whoso curseth his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in obscure darkness.
An inheritance
may be gotten hastily at the beginning; but the end thereof shall not be blessed.
Say not thou, I will recompense evil;
but wait on the LORD, and he shall save thee.
Divers weights
are an abomination unto the LORD; and a false balance
is not good.
Man’s goings
are of the LORD; how can a man then understand his own way?
It is a snare to the man
who devoureth
that which is holy, and after vows to make enquiry.
A wise king scattereth the wicked, and bringeth the wheel over them.
The spirit of man
is the candle of the LORD, searching all the inward parts of the belly.
Mercy and truth preserve the king: and his throne is upholden by mercy.
The glory of young men
is their strength: and the beauty of old men
is the grey head.
The blueness of a wound cleanseth away evil: so
do stripes the inward parts of the belly.

### Proverbs Chapter 21

The king’s heart
is in the hand of the LORD,
as
 the rivers of water: he turneth it whithersoever he will.
Every way of a man
is right in his own eyes: but the LORD pondereth the hearts.
To do justice and judgment
is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
An high look, and a proud heart,
and the plowing of the wicked,
is sin.
The thoughts of the diligent
tend only to plenteousness; but of every one
that is hasty only to want.
The getting of treasures by a lying tongue
is a vanity tossed to and fro of them that seek death.
The robbery of the wicked shall destroy them; because they refuse to do judgment.
The way of man
is froward and strange: but
as for
 the pure, his work
is right.
It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop, than with a brawling woman in a wide house.
The soul of the wicked desireth evil: his neighbour findeth no favour in his eyes.
When the scorner is punished, the simple is made wise: and when the wise is instructed, he receiveth knowledge.
The righteous
man wisely considereth the house of the wicked:
but God overthroweth the wicked for
their wickedness.
Whoso stoppeth his ears at the cry of the poor, he also shall cry himself, but shall not be heard.
A gift in secret pacifieth anger: and a reward in the bosom strong wrath.
It is joy to the just to do judgment: but destruction
shall be to the workers of iniquity.
The man that wandereth out of the way of understanding shall remain in the congregation of the dead.
He that loveth pleasure
shall be a poor man: he that loveth wine and oil shall not be rich.
The wicked
shall be a ransom for the righteous, and the transgressor for the upright.
It is better to dwell in the wilderness, than with a contentious and an angry woman.
There is treasure to be desired and oil in the dwelling of the wise; but a foolish man spendeth it up.
He that followeth after righteousness and mercy findeth life, righteousness, and honour.
A wise
man scaleth the city of the mighty, and casteth down the strength of the confidence thereof.
Whoso keepeth his mouth and his tongue keepeth his soul from troubles.
Proud
and haughty scorner
is his name, who dealeth in proud wrath.
The desire of the slothful killeth him; for his hands refuse to labour.
He coveteth greedily all the day long: but the righteous giveth and spareth not.
The sacrifice of the wicked
is abomination: how much more,
when he bringeth it with a wicked mind?
A false witness shall perish: but the man that heareth speaketh constantly.
A wicked man hardeneth his face: but
as for the upright, he directeth his way.
There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the LORD.
The horse
is prepared against the day of battle: but safety
is of the LORD.


### Proverbs Chapter 22

A
good name
is rather to be chosen than great riches,
and loving favour rather than silver and gold.
The rich and poor meet together: the LORD
is the maker of them all.
A prudent
man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself: but the simple pass on, and are punished.
By humility
and the fear of the LORD
are riches, and honour, and life.
Thorns
and snares
are in the way of the froward: he that doth keep his soul shall be far from them.
Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old, he will not depart from it.
The rich ruleth over the poor, and the borrower
is servant to the lender.
He that soweth iniquity shall reap vanity: and the rod of his anger shall fail.
He that hath a bountiful eye shall be blessed; for he giveth of his bread to the poor.
Cast out the scorner, and contention shall go out; yea, strife and reproach shall cease.
He that loveth pureness of heart,
for the grace of his lips the king
shall be his friend.
The eyes of the LORD preserve knowledge, and he overthroweth the words of the transgressor.
The slothful
man saith,
There is a lion without, I shall be slain in the streets.
The mouth of strange women
is a deep pit: he that is abhorred of the LORD shall fall therein.
Foolishness
is bound in the heart of a child;
but
 the rod of correction shall drive it far from him.
He that oppresseth the poor to increase his
riches, and he that giveth to the rich,
shall surely
come to want.
Bow down thine ear, and hear the words of the wise, and apply thine heart unto my knowledge.
For
it is a pleasant thing if thou keep them within thee; they shall withal be fitted in thy lips.
That thy trust may be in the LORD, I have made known to thee this day, even to thee.
Have not I written to thee excellent things in counsels and knowledge,
That I might make thee know the certainty of the words of truth; that thou mightest answer the words of truth to them that send unto thee?
Rob not the poor, because he
is poor: neither oppress the afflicted in the gate:
For the LORD will plead their cause, and spoil the soul of those that spoiled them.
Make no friendship with an angry man; and with a furious man thou shalt not go:
Lest thou learn his ways, and get a snare to thy soul.
Be not thou
one of them that strike hands,
or of them that are sureties for debts.
If thou hast nothing to pay, why should he take away thy bed from under thee?
Remove not the ancient landmark, which thy fathers have set.
Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before mean
men.
