### 2 Corinthians Chapter 6

We then,
as workers together
with him, beseech
you also that ye receive not the grace of God in vain.
(For he saith, I have heard thee in a time accepted, and in the day of salvation have I succoured thee: behold, now
is the accepted time; behold, now
is the day of salvation.)
Giving no offence in any thing, that the ministry be not blamed:
But in all
things approving ourselves as the ministers of God, in much patience, in afflictions, in necessities, in distresses,
In stripes, in imprisonments, in tumults, in labours, in watchings, in fastings;
By pureness, by knowledge, by longsuffering, by kindness, by the Holy Ghost, by love unfeigned,
By the word of truth, by the power of God, by the armour of righteousness on the right hand and on the left,
By honour and dishonour, by evil report and good report: as deceivers, and
yet true;
As unknown, and
yet well known; as dying, and, behold, we live; as chastened, and not killed;
As sorrowful, yet alway rejoicing; as poor, yet making many rich; as having nothing, and
yet possessing all things.
O
ye Corinthians, our mouth is open unto you, our heart is enlarged.
Ye are not straitened in us, but ye are straitened in your own bowels.
Now for a recompence in the same, (I speak as unto
my children,) be ye also enlarged.
Be ye not unequally yoked together with unbelievers: for what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness? and what communion hath light with darkness?
And what concord hath Christ with Belial? or what part hath he that believeth with an infidel?
And what agreement hath the temple of God with idols? for ye are the temple of the living God; as God hath said, I will dwell in them, and walk in
them; and I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
Wherefore come out from among them, and be ye separate, saith the Lord, and touch not the unclean
thing; and I will receive you,
And will be a Father unto you, and ye shall be my sons and daughters, saith the Lord Almighty.


### 2 Corinthians Chapter 7

Having therefore these promises, dearly beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.
Receive us; we have wronged no man, we have corrupted no man, we have defrauded no man.
I speak not
this to condemn
you: for I have said before, that ye are in our hearts to die and live with
you.
Great
is my boldness of speech toward you, great
is
 my glorying of you: I am filled with comfort, I am exceeding joyful in all our tribulation.
For, when we were come into Macedonia, our flesh had no rest, but we were troubled on every side; without
were fightings, within
were
 fears.
Nevertheless God, that comforteth those that are cast down, comforted us by the coming of Titus;
And not by his coming only, but by the consolation wherewith he was comforted in you, when he told us your earnest desire, your mourning, your fervent mind toward me; so that I rejoiced the more.
For though I made you sorry with a letter, I do not repent, though I did repent: for I perceive that the same epistle hath made you sorry, though
it were but for a season.
Now I rejoice, not that ye were made sorry, but that ye sorrowed to repentance: for ye were made sorry after a godly manner, that ye might receive damage by us in nothing.
For godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of: but the sorrow of the world worketh death.
For behold this selfsame thing, that ye sorrowed after a godly sort, what carefulness it wrought in you, yea,
what clearing of yourselves, yea,
what indignation, yea,
what fear, yea,
what vehement desire, yea,
what zeal, yea,
what
 revenge! In all
things ye have approved yourselves to be clear in this matter.
Wherefore, though I wrote unto you,
I did it not for his cause that had done the wrong, nor for his cause that suffered wrong, but that our care for you in the sight of God might appear unto you.
Therefore we were comforted in your comfort: yea, and exceedingly the more joyed we for the joy of Titus, because his spirit was refreshed by you all.
For if I have boasted any thing to him of you, I am not ashamed; but as we spake all things to you in truth, even so our boasting, which
I made
 before Titus, is found a truth.
And his inward affection is more abundant toward you, whilst he remembereth the obedience of you all, how with fear and trembling ye received him.
I rejoice therefore that I have confidence in you in all
things.


### 2 Corinthians Chapter 8

Moreover, brethren, we do you to wit of the grace of God bestowed on the churches of Macedonia;
How that in a great trial of affliction the abundance of their joy and their deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality.
For to
their power, I bear record, yea, and beyond
their
 power
they were willing of themselves;
Praying us with much intreaty that we would receive the gift, and
take upon us the fellowship of the ministering to the saints.
And
this they did, not as we hoped, but first gave their own selves to the Lord, and unto us by the will of God.
Insomuch that we desired Titus, that as he had begun, so he would also finish in you the same grace also.
Therefore, as ye abound in every
thing, in faith, and utterance, and knowledge, and
in all diligence, and
in
 your love to us,
see that ye abound in this grace also.
I speak not by commandment, but by occasion of the forwardness of others, and to prove the sincerity of your love.
For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that, though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, that ye through his poverty might be rich.
And herein I give
my advice: for this is expedient for you, who have begun before, not only to do, but also to be forward a year ago.
Now therefore perform the doing
of it; that as
there was
 a readiness to will, so
there may be a performance also out of that which ye have.
For if there be first a willing mind,
it is accepted according to that a man hath,
and not according to that he hath not.
For
I mean not that other men be eased, and ye burdened:
But by an equality,
that now at this time your abundance
may be a supply for their want, that their abundance also may be
a supply for your want: that there may be equality:
As it is written, He that
had gathered much had nothing over; and he that
had gathered little had no lack.
But thanks
be to God, which put the same earnest care into the heart of Titus for you.
For indeed he accepted the exhortation; but being more forward, of his own accord he went unto you.
And we have sent with him the brother, whose praise is in the gospel throughout all the churches;
And not
that only, but who was also chosen of the churches to travel with us with this grace, which is administered by us to the glory of the same Lord, and
declaration of your ready mind:
Avoiding this, that no man should blame us in this abundance which is administered by us:
Providing for honest things, not only in the sight of the Lord, but also in the sight of men.
And we have sent with them our brother, whom we have oftentimes proved diligent in many things, but now much more diligent, upon the great confidence which
I have in you.
Whether
any do enquire of Titus,
he is my partner and fellowhelper concerning you: or our brethren
be enquired of, they are the messengers of the churches,
and the glory of Christ.
Wherefore shew ye to them, and before the churches, the proof of your love, and of our boasting on your behalf.


### 2 Corinthians Chapter 9

For as touching the ministering to the saints, it is superfluous for me to write to you:
For I know the forwardness of your mind, for which I boast of you to them of Macedonia, that Achaia was ready a year ago; and your zeal hath provoked very many.
Yet have I sent the brethren, lest our boasting of you should be in vain in this behalf; that, as I said, ye may be ready:
Lest haply if they of Macedonia come with me, and find you unprepared, we (that we say not, ye) should be ashamed in this same confident boasting.
Therefore I thought it necessary to exhort the brethren, that they would go before unto you, and make up beforehand your bounty, whereof ye had notice before, that the same might be ready, as
a matter of bounty, and not as
of covetousness.
But this
I say, He which soweth sparingly shall reap also sparingly; and he which soweth bountifully shall reap also bountifully.
Every man according as he purposeth in his heart,
so let him give;
 not grudgingly, or of necessity: for God loveth a cheerful giver.
And God
is able to make all grace abound toward you; that ye, always having all sufficiency in all
things, may abound to every good work:
(As it is written, He hath dispersed abroad; he hath given to the poor: his righteousness remaineth for ever.
Now he that ministereth seed to the sower both minister bread for
your food, and multiply your seed sown, and increase the fruits of your righteousness;)
Being enriched in every thing to all bountifulness, which causeth through us thanksgiving to God.
For the administration of this service not only supplieth the want of the saints, but is abundant also by many thanksgivings unto God;
Whiles by the experiment of this ministration they glorify God for your professed subjection unto the gospel of Christ, and for
your liberal distribution unto them, and unto all
men;
And by their prayer for you, which long after you for the exceeding grace of God in you.
Thanks
be unto God for his unspeakable gift.


### 2 Corinthians Chapter 10

Now I Paul myself beseech you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ, who in presence
am base among you, but being absent am bold toward you:
But I beseech
you, that I may not be bold when I am present with that confidence, wherewith I think to be bold against some, which think of us as if we walked according to the flesh.
For though we walk in the flesh, we do not war after the flesh:
(For the weapons of our warfare
are not carnal, but mighty through God to the pulling down of strong holds;)
Casting down imaginations, and every high thing that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ;
And having in a readiness to revenge all disobedience, when your obedience is fulfilled.
Do ye look on things after the outward appearance? If any man trust to himself that he is Christ’s, let him of himself think this again, that, as he
is Christ’s, even so
are we Christ’s.
For though I should boast somewhat more of our authority, which the Lord hath given us for edification, and not for your destruction, I should not be ashamed:
That I may not seem as if I would terrify you by letters.
For
his letters, say they,
are weighty and powerful; but
his bodily presence
is weak, and
his speech contemptible.
Let such an one think this, that, such as we are in word by letters when we are absent, such
will we be also in deed when we are present.
For we dare not make ourselves of the number, or compare ourselves with some that commend themselves: but they measuring themselves by themselves, and comparing themselves among themselves, are not wise.
But we will not boast of things without
our measure, but according to the measure of the rule which God hath distributed to us, a measure to reach even unto you.
For we stretch not ourselves beyond
our measure, as though we reached not unto you: for we are come as far as to you also in
preaching
 the gospel of Christ:
Not boasting of things without
our measure,
that is,
 of other men’s labours; but having hope, when your faith is increased, that we shall be enlarged by you according to our rule abundantly,
To preach the gospel in the
regions beyond you,
and
 not to boast in another man’s line of things made ready to our hand.
But he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord.
For not he that commendeth himself is approved, but whom the Lord commendeth.

### 2 Corinthians Chapter 11

Would to God ye could bear with me a little in
my folly: and indeed bear with me.
For I am jealous over you with godly jealousy: for I have espoused you to one husband, that I may present
you as a chaste virgin to Christ.
But I fear, lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ.
For if he that cometh preacheth another Jesus, whom we have not preached, or
if ye receive another spirit, which ye have not received, or another gospel, which ye have not accepted, ye might well bear with
him.
For I suppose I was not a whit behind the very chiefest apostles.
But though
I be rude in speech, yet not in knowledge; but we have been throughly made manifest among you in all things.
Have I committed an offence in abasing myself that ye might be exalted, because I have preached to you the gospel of God freely?
I robbed other churches, taking wages
of them, to do you service.
And when I was present with you, and wanted, I was chargeable to no man: for that which was lacking to me the brethren which came from Macedonia supplied: and in all
things I have kept myself from being burdensome unto you, and so will I keep
myself.
As the truth of Christ is in me, no man shall stop me of this boasting in the regions of Achaia.
Wherefore? because I love you not? God knoweth.
But what I do, that I will do, that I may cut off occasion from them which desire occasion; that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we.
For such
are false apostles, deceitful workers, transforming themselves into the apostles of Christ.
And no marvel; for Satan himself is transformed into an angel of light.
Therefore
it is no great thing if his ministers also be transformed as the ministers of righteousness; whose end shall be according to their works.
I say again, Let no man think me a fool; if otherwise, yet as a fool receive me, that I may boast myself a little.
That which I speak, I speak
it not after the Lord, but as it were foolishly, in this confidence of boasting.
Seeing that many glory after the flesh, I will glory also.
For ye suffer fools gladly, seeing ye
yourselves are wise.
For ye suffer, if a man bring you into bondage, if a man devour
you, if a man take
of you, if a man exalt himself, if a man smite you on the face.
I speak as concerning reproach, as though we had been weak. Howbeit whereinsoever any is bold, (I speak foolishly,) I am bold also.
Are they Hebrews? so
am I. Are they Israelites? so
am
 I. Are they the seed of Abraham? so
am I.
Are they ministers of Christ? (I speak as a fool) I
am more; in labours more abundant, in stripes above measure, in prisons more frequent, in deaths oft.
Of the Jews five times received I forty
stripes save one.
Thrice was I beaten with rods, once was I stoned, thrice I suffered shipwreck, a night and a day I have been in the deep;
In journeyings often,
in perils of waters,
in perils of robbers,
in perils by
mine own
 countrymen,
in perils by the heathen,
in perils in the city,
in perils in the wilderness,
in perils in the sea,
in perils among false brethren;
In weariness and painfulness, in watchings often, in hunger and thirst, in fastings often, in cold and nakedness.
Beside those things that are without, that which cometh upon me daily, the care of all the churches.
Who is weak, and I am not weak? who is offended, and I burn not?
If I must needs glory, I will glory of the things which concern mine infirmities.
The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, which is blessed for evermore, knoweth that I lie not.
In Damascus the governor under Aretas the king kept the city of the Damascenes with a garrison, desirous to apprehend me:
And through a window in a basket was I let down by the wall, and escaped his hands.


### 2 Corinthians Chapter 12

It is not expedient for me doubtless to glory. I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord.
I knew a man in Christ above fourteen years ago, (whether in the body, I cannot tell; or whether out of the body, I cannot tell: God knoweth;) such an one caught up to the third heaven.
And I knew such a man, (whether in the body, or out of the body, I cannot tell: God knoweth;)
How that he was caught up into paradise, and heard unspeakable words, which it is not lawful for a man to utter.
Of such an one will I glory: yet of myself I will not glory, but in mine infirmities.
For though I would desire to glory, I shall not be a fool; for I will say the truth: but
now I forbear, lest any man should think of me above that which he seeth me
to be, or
that he heareth of me.
And lest I should be exalted above measure through the abundance of the revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I should be exalted above measure.
For this thing I besought the Lord thrice, that it might depart from me.
And he said unto me,
My grace is sufficient for thee: for my strength is made perfect in weakness. Most gladly therefore will I rather glory in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me.
Therefore I take pleasure in infirmities, in reproaches, in necessities, in persecutions, in distresses for Christ’s sake: for when I am weak, then am I strong.
I am become a fool in glorying; ye have compelled me: for I ought to have been commended of you: for in nothing am I behind the very chiefest apostles, though I be nothing.
Truly the signs of an apostle were wrought among you in all patience, in signs, and wonders, and mighty deeds.
For what is it wherein ye were inferior to other churches, except
it be that I myself was not burdensome to you? forgive me this wrong.
Behold, the third time I am ready to come to you; and I will not be burdensome to you: for I seek not yours, but you: for the children ought not to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children.
And I will very gladly spend and be spent for you; though the more abundantly I love you, the less I be loved.
But be it so, I did not burden you: nevertheless, being crafty, I caught you with guile.
Did I make a gain of you by any of them whom I sent unto you?
I desired Titus, and with
him I sent a brother. Did Titus make a gain of you? walked we not in the same spirit?
walked we not in the same steps?
Again, think ye that we excuse ourselves unto you? we speak before God in Christ: but
we do all things, dearly beloved, for your edifying.
For I fear, lest, when I come, I shall not find you such as I would, and
that I shall be found unto you such as ye would not: lest
there be debates, envyings, wraths, strifes, backbitings, whisperings, swellings, tumults:
And lest, when I come again, my God will humble me among you, and
that I shall bewail many which have sinned already, and have not repented of the uncleanness and fornication and lasciviousness which they have committed.


### 2 Corinthians Chapter 13

This
is the third
time I am coming to you. In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established.
I told you before, and foretell you, as if I were present, the second time; and being absent now I write to them which heretofore have sinned, and to all other, that, if I come again, I will not spare:
Since ye seek a proof of Christ speaking in me, which to you-ward is not weak, but is mighty in you.
For though he was crucified through weakness, yet he liveth by the power of God. For we also are weak in him, but we shall live with him by the power of God toward you.
Examine yourselves, whether ye be in the faith; prove your own selves. Know ye not your own selves, how that Jesus Christ is in you, except ye be reprobates?
But I trust that ye shall know that we are not reprobates.
Now I pray to God that ye do no evil; not that we should appear approved, but that ye should do that which is honest, though we be as reprobates.
For we can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth.
For we are glad, when we are weak, and ye are strong: and this also we wish,
even your perfection.
Therefore I write these things being absent, lest being present I should use sharpness, according to the power which the Lord hath given me to edification, and not to destruction.
Finally, brethren, farewell. Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace shall be with you.
Greet one another with an holy kiss.
All the saints salute you.
The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Ghost,
be with you all. Amen.

## Galatians

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Galatians' dating depends on identifying its recipients and Paul's visits to Jerusalem. Two main theories exist: **North Galatian Theory** identifies recipients as ethnic Galatians in northern Asia Minor (Ancyra, Pessinus, Tavium), placing composition c. 53-57 CE after Paul's second/third missionary journeys. **South Galatian Theory** (more widely accepted) identifies recipients as churches in southern Galatia (Pisidian Antioch, Iconium, Lystra, Derbe) founded during Paul's first journey (Acts 13-14, c. 47-48 CE), placing composition c. 48-49 CE (before Jerusalem Council, Acts 15) or c. 49-50 CE (shortly after). Early dating (48-49 CE) makes Galatians Paul's earliest letter, written from Syrian Antioch in response to "Judaizers" (Jewish-Christian teachers insisting Gentile converts must be circumcised and keep Torah). Paul's heated tone ("O foolish Galatians!" 3:1; "I wish those who unsettle you would emasculate themselves!" 5:12) reflects crisis urgency: Gentile converts were accepting circumcision (5:2-3, 6:12-13), abandoning Paul's Law-free gospel. The letter addresses fundamental questions: Must Gentiles become Jews to follow the Jewish Messiah? What role does Mosaic Law play in Christian life? How are people justified before God? Galatians articulates Paul's mature theology of justification by faith apart from works of Law, predating and anticipating Romans' fuller treatment. The crisis occasioning Galatians involved traveling teachers undermining Paul's authority and gospel, possibly appealing to Jerusalem apostles' authority, prompting Paul's spirited defense (chs. 1-2) and theological argument (chs. 3-4) before ethical application (chs. 5-6).

**Author and Audience:** Pauline authorship is universally accepted. Paul identifies himself (1:1, "Paul an apostle"), includes autobiographical details (1:13-2:14), and exhibits characteristic passionate argumentation. Paul addresses "the churches of Galatia" (1:2), either northern ethnic Galatians (Celts/Gauls who migrated to central Asia Minor in 3rd century BCE) or southern cities in Roman Galatia province. South Galatian theory better explains: Acts narrates Paul founding churches in southern Galatia (Pisidian Antioch, Iconium, Lystra, Derbe, Acts 13:13-14:23), no northern Galatian mission is recorded, and southern cities were on major roads facilitating Judaizer travel. Paul's audience consists of predominantly Gentile converts ("formerly... enslaved to beings that by nature are not gods," 4:8; "you who were Gentiles in the flesh," probably implied in 5:2-3's circumcision discussion) who received the Spirit through hearing with faith (3:2-5), experienced miracles (3:5), and initially welcomed Paul enthusiastically (4:13-15) despite his physical illness. The Galatians now face pressure from "agitators" (1:7, 5:10, 12) teaching circumcision necessity (5:2-3, 6:12-13), Torah observance including festivals and dietary laws (4:10, implied 2:11-14), and questioning Paul's apostolic authority (implied 1:1, 11-12, 2:6-9). These Judaizers likely claimed Jerusalem apostles' authorization, appealing to Jesus's Jewish identity and Torah observance, arguing Paul's Law-free gospel diluted authentic Christianity. Paul counters by asserting his gospel came directly from Christ (1:11-12), defending his apostolic independence while maintaining Jerusalem apostles approved his Gentile mission (2:1-10).

**Key Themes:** **Justification by Faith Apart from Works of Law**: Galatians' theological heart declares people are "justified by faith in Christ and not by works of the law" (2:16), repeated three times in one verse for emphasis. Abraham's faith-righteousness predated circumcision (3:6-9), demonstrating justification's faith-basis. Law-works cannot justify because Law brings curse through inability to keep all commandments (3:10-14). **Gospel vs. "Different Gospel"**: Paul pronounces anathema (curse) on anyone—even angels—preaching "a different gospel" (1:6-9), declaring his gospel came by Christ's revelation, not human tradition (1:11-12). The Judaizers' circumcision requirement perverts the gospel (5:2-4). **Freedom in Christ**: Christ freed believers from Law's curse (3:13, 4:5), slavery (4:1-7), and elemental spirits (4:3, 8-9). This freedom isn't license for flesh but loving service (5:13-14). **Life in the Spirit vs. Works of Flesh**: Believers live by Spirit's power (5:16-26), producing fruit (love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control, 5:22-23) rather than flesh's works (5:19-21). **Abraham's True Children**: Faith, not ethnicity or circumcision, makes one Abraham's seed (3:7-9, 29). The promise to Abraham's "offspring" (singular) refers to Christ (3:16), and those in Christ inherit the promise. **Law's Temporary Role**: Law served as "guardian" (paidagōgos, tutor/custodian) until Christ (3:23-25), revealing sin (3:19) but unable to give life (3:21). Christ's coming ended Law's custodial role. **Paul's Apostolic Authority**: Chapters 1-2 defend Paul's gospel as divinely revealed (1:11-17), independent of Jerusalem apostles (1:18-24), yet approved by them (2:1-10). Paul even opposed Peter's hypocrisy regarding Gentile table fellowship (2:11-14).

**Archaeological Relevance:** Galatians' mid-1st century CE Asia Minor setting receives archaeological corroboration. **South Galatian Cities**: Extensive archaeological work at **Pisidian Antioch** reveals Roman colony with temple of Augustus, aqueduct, and theater; **Iconium** (modern Konya) preserves Roman-era remains; **Lystra** inscriptions confirm Roman colony status; **Derbe** site identified at Kerti Hüyük. These excavations contextualize Acts 13-14's missionary accounts. **Roman Roads**: Via Sebaste connected Pisidian Antioch to Lystra and Derbe, facilitating travel for Paul and Judaizers. Milestones and road stations evidence 1st century transportation infrastructure enabling early Christian mission. **Temple of Augustus** (Ancyra/Ankara, northern Galatia): Preserves Res Gestae Divi Augusti inscription, documenting emperor worship context within which Christians proclaimed "Jesus is Lord" (contrast imperial cult's "Caesar is Lord"). **Synagogue Inscriptions**: Various Asia Minor synagogue remains and Jewish inscriptions evidence diaspora Jewish communities Paul initially addressed before turning to Gentiles (Acts 13:14, 44-46). **Circumcision**: Jewish practice documented in texts and art, contextualizing Galatians' central controversy. Paul's argument that requiring circumcision obligates keeping entire Law (5:3) reflects Jewish understanding. **Roman Citizenship**: Paul's likely Roman citizenship (Acts 22:25-28) and Tarsus origin (Acts 21:39) evidence cultural tensions between Jewish, Greek, and Roman identities navigated in Galatians' argument. **Slavery and Adoption Practices**: Roman legal practices of slavery manumission and adoption illustrate Paul's metaphors: believers freed from slavery (4:1-7), adopted as sons (4:5), receiving inheritance rights (3:29, 4:7).

**Structure:** Galatians' 6 chapters follow classic Greco-Roman letter structure with passionate argumentation. **Opening (1:1-10)**: Salutation emphasizing Paul's divine apostolic commission (1:1-5), rebuke: "I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting" (1:6-10), double anathema on false gospel preachers. **Part I: Paul's Gospel and Apostolic Authority (1:11-2:21)**: Gospel received by revelation, not human teaching (1:11-17), limited Jerusalem contact (1:18-24), Jerusalem apostles approved Paul's Gentile mission (2:1-10), Paul opposed Peter's hypocrisy at Antioch (2:11-14), justification by faith thesis stated (2:15-21, "if righteousness were through law, then Christ died for no purpose"). **Part II: Theological Argument from Scripture (3:1-4:31)**: Galatians received Spirit by faith, not Law-works (3:1-5), Abraham justified by faith (3:6-9), Law brings curse, Christ redeemed from curse (3:10-14), promise predates Law by 430 years (3:15-18), Law's temporary custodial role (3:19-25), baptismal unity formula "neither Jew nor Greek... slave nor free... male and female" (3:26-29), adoption as sons/heirs (4:1-7), warning against returning to bondage (4:8-11), personal appeal recalling initial reception (4:12-20), Hagar-Sarah allegory contrasting slavery (Sinai covenant) and freedom (promise covenant, 4:21-31). **Part III: Ethical Exhortation (5:1-6:10)**: Stand firm in freedom (5:1), circumcision obligates keeping entire Law (5:2-12), freedom serves through love (5:13-15), Spirit vs. flesh (5:16-26), burden-bearing and restoring sinners (6:1-6), sowing and reaping (6:7-10). **Conclusion (6:11-18)**: Paul's large handwriting autograph (6:11), final warning against Judaizers' motives (6:12-13), boasting only in Christ's cross (6:14-16), Paul's stigmata (marks of Jesus, 6:17), benediction (6:18). Galatians' passionate tone and sharp rhetoric reflect crisis urgency, making it Christianity's "Magna Carta of spiritual freedom" (Luther).

## 1 Thessalonians

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** 1 Thessalonians is widely considered Paul's earliest surviving letter, dated c. 49-51 CE during his ministry in Corinth (Acts 18:1-18). The letter was written shortly after Paul, Silas, and Timothy established the Thessalonian church during the second missionary journey (Acts 17:1-9), likely only months after their hasty departure due to Jewish opposition. Paul's reference to Timothy's recent return from Thessalonica (3:6) and his own presence in Athens and Corinth (3:1-2) align with the Acts chronology. The Gallio inscription from Delphi, mentioning Gallio's proconsulship of Achaia (51-52 CE), provides a fixed point confirming Paul's Corinthian ministry around this time. This early dating makes 1 Thessalonians one of the first Christian documents, predating the Gospels by approximately 15-20 years. The letter's undisputed Pauline authorship, simple eschatology, and lack of developed church structure support its primitive date.

**Author and Audience:** The letter identifies "Paul, Silvanus [Silas], and Timothy" as senders (1:1), though Paul's first-person singular throughout (2:18, 3:5, 5:27) indicates his primary authorship. The recipients are "the church of the Thessalonians in God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ" (1:1). Thessalonica (modern Thessaloniki, Greece) was the capital of the Roman province of Macedonia, a major port on the Via Egnatia (the main east-west highway), and home to perhaps 100,000-200,000 people. Acts 17:1-9 describes how Paul preached in the synagogue for three Sabbaths, converting some Jews and "a great many of the devout Greeks and not a few of the leading women" (Acts 17:4). The congregation was predominantly Gentile (1:9: "turned to God from idols"), though including Jewish believers. Paul's brief ministry (perhaps only a few weeks to a few months) before being driven out by a riot makes the Thessalonians' rapid spiritual growth remarkable. The "politarchs" (city officials) mentioned in Acts 17:6 were confirmed by inscriptions from Thessalonica's Vardar Gate.

**Key Themes:** **Resurrection Hope**: Paul addresses anxiety about believers who had died before Christ's return (4:13-18), assuring that "the dead in Christ will rise first" and believers will be "caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord." This passage provides the earliest written Christian teaching on resurrection and Parousia. **Sanctification**: Living "to please God" (4:1) involves sexual purity (4:3-8), brotherly love (4:9-10), quiet industry (4:11-12), distinguishing Christians from pagan culture. **Imitation of Christ and Apostles**: The Thessalonians "became imitators of us and of the Lord" (1:6), themselves becoming models for all believers in Macedonia and Achaia (1:7-8). **Suffering and Persecution**: Paul affirms that persecution is expected ("we are destined for this," 3:3-4), connecting Thessalonian suffering to that of Judean churches and ultimately to Christ himself (2:14-16). **Day of the Lord**: Coming "like a thief in the night" (5:2), requiring readiness, sobriety, and faithful living (5:1-11).

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Thessalonica Excavations**: Extensive remains document first-century Thessalonica's prominence. The Roman forum (agora) has been excavated, along with sections of the Via Egnatia running through the city center. The second-century Arch of Galerius replaced an earlier Roman arch, marking the city's importance. **Politarch Inscriptions**: Acts 17:6, 8 refers to "politarchs" (city rulers), a term skeptics once questioned as Luke's error. However, at least 32 inscriptions (19 from Thessalonica itself) confirm "politarch" as the precise title for Macedonian city officials in the Roman period. The most famous, from the Vardar Gate (now in the British Museum), lists six politarchs from Thessalonica, potentially including some who dealt with Paul's opponents. **Jewish Presence**: Inscriptions and archaeological remains confirm a significant Jewish community in Thessalonica, corroborating Acts 17:1's reference to a synagogue. Samareia inscription and other Jewish epitaphs demonstrate continuous Jewish presence from the Hellenistic period through the Roman era. **Economic Activity**: Archaeological evidence of Thessalonica's bustling port and commercial activity illuminates Paul's commendation of "working with your own hands" (4:11) - the congregation's economic context contrasts with idleness some were tempted toward while awaiting Christ's return. **Papyrus Evidence**: Early manuscripts include important witnesses like Papyrus 30 (3rd century, containing portions of 1-2 Thessalonians), demonstrating the letter's early circulation and copying.

**Structure:** **Opening (1:1-10)**: Greeting (1:1), thanksgiving for the Thessalonians' exemplary faith, love, and hope demonstrated in their conversion from idols to serve the living God and await his Son from heaven (1:2-10). **Paul's Ministry Among Them (2:1-3:13)**: Defense of Paul's conduct and motives during his founding visit (2:1-12), thanksgiving for their reception of the gospel despite persecution (2:13-16), Paul's desire to visit again, thwarted by Satan (2:17-20), sending Timothy instead (3:1-5), Timothy's encouraging report (3:6-10), prayer for reunion and love (3:11-13). **Ethical Instructions (4:1-12)**: Exhortation to please God (4:1-2), sexual purity in contrast to pagan lust (4:3-8), brotherly love and productive work (4:9-12). **Eschatological Teaching (4:13-5:11)**: Assurance about believers who have died - they will rise first at Christ's coming (4:13-18), watchfulness for the Day of the Lord that comes like a thief (5:1-11). **Final Exhortations and Closing (5:12-28)**: Respect for leaders (5:12-13), various community instructions (5:14-22), prayer for sanctification (5:23-24), requests for prayer (5:25), holy kiss (5:26), charge to read the letter to all (5:27), benediction (5:28).

## 2 Thessalonians

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** 2 Thessalonians is traditionally dated shortly after 1 Thessalonians, c. 50-51 CE, during Paul's continued ministry in Corinth. However, this letter faces significant scholarly debate regarding authorship and date. Arguments for Pauline authenticity include: explicit claim to Paul's authorship with authenticating signature (3:17), similarities to 1 Thessalonians, and early manuscript attestation. Arguments for pseudonymity cite: dependence on 1 Thessalonians yet contradictory eschatology (imminent vs delayed Parousia), formal tone lacking 1 Thessalonians' warmth, developed apocalyptic scheme (man of lawlessness, restrainer), vocabulary differences, and the signature emphasis (3:17) possibly protesting too much against forgeries. Those accepting Pauline authorship suggest composition weeks or months after 1 Thessalonians, responding to misunderstandings about the Day of the Lord. Those positing pseudonymity date the letter to 70-90 CE, after Jerusalem's fall and during persecution, written by a Pauline disciple addressing later concerns using the apostle's authority. The letter's canonical acceptance was early and widespread, appearing in Marcion's canon (c. 140 CE) and consistently attested in early lists.

**Author and Audience:** The letter names "Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy" as senders (1:1), addressing "the church of the Thessalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ" (1:1) - identical to 1 Thessalonians' opening. The situation addressed differs from the first letter: while 1 Thessalonians confronted grief over deceased believers and watchfulness for Christ's coming, 2 Thessalonians addresses confusion and alarm ("not to be quickly shaken in mind or alarmed," 2:2) over teaching that "the day of the Lord has already come" (2:2), possibly based on a forged letter claiming Paul's authority (2:2, 3:17). Some Thessalonians had abandoned work, becoming "idle" (3:6-12) - perhaps believing Christ's imminent return made labor pointless. Whether written by Paul shortly after the first letter or by a later disciple, the letter addresses a specific crisis: false teaching about realized eschatology prompting social disruption and theological confusion in the Thessalonian congregation.

**Key Themes:** **Delayed Parousia**: Contrary to claims that the Day of the Lord had arrived, Paul insists certain signs must first occur: "the rebellion" (apostasia, 2:3), the revelation of "the man of lawlessness" (2:3), removal of "what is restraining him" (2:6-7), and the lawless one's destruction by Christ (2:8). This apocalyptic timetable provides assurance that believers have not missed Christ's return. **Divine Justice**: God's righteous judgment will grant "relief" to persecuted believers and "affliction" to afflicters (1:5-10), revealing Christ "in flaming fire, inflicting vengeance on those who do not know God" (1:8). This theodicy addresses suffering Christians' need for assurance that justice will prevail. **Restrainer Mystery**: The enigmatic "restraining" force (2:6-7) holding back the man of lawlessness has generated numerous interpretations (Roman Empire, Holy Spirit, angelic power, Paul's mission, law and order), reflecting apocalyptic literature's coded language. **Church Discipline**: Disorderly, idle believers must be warned and, if unrepentant, shunned as discipline ("do not associate with him," 3:14), though treated as brothers, not enemies (3:15). **Work Ethic**: "If anyone is not willing to work, let him not eat" (3:10) counters eschatologically-motivated idleness, insisting Christian waiting involves productive labor, not passive dependence.

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Thessalonica Context**: Archaeological evidence for 2 Thessalonians is identical to 1 Thessalonians, as both address the same congregation: politarch inscriptions confirming Acts' accuracy, Jewish synagogue evidence, commercial port remains, and Via Egnatia highway sections. The letter's concern with work ethics finds context in Thessalonica's commercial economy where idleness would burden the Christian community. **Imperial Cult**: First-century inscriptions from Thessalonica document emperor worship and civic religion. Paul's reference to the man of lawlessness "proclaiming himself to be God" and "taking his seat in the temple of God" (2:4) may allude to imperial pretensions (cf. Caligula's attempt to place his statue in Jerusalem's temple, 40 CE) or broader Roman religious claims, providing political-theological critique encoded in apocalyptic language. **Persecution Evidence**: While explicit archaeological evidence for Christian persecution in 50s Thessalonica is lacking, inscriptions documenting imperial loyalty, civic pride in Roman alliance, and Jewish community tensions provide context for hostility toward Christians preaching another king (Acts 17:7). **Manuscript Evidence**: Same early manuscripts as 1 Thessalonians preserve 2 Thessalonians (especially Papyrus 30, 3rd century), with early canonical inclusion in Muratorian Canon, Marcion's list, and patristic citations.

**Structure:** **Opening (1:1-12)**: Greeting (1:1-2), thanksgiving for the Thessalonians' growing faith and love amid persecutions (1:3-4), assurance of God's righteous judgment at Christ's revelation, bringing relief to persecuted believers and punishment to persecutors (1:5-10), prayer for their calling and glorification (1:11-12). **The Day of the Lord (2:1-17)**: Exhortation not to be alarmed by claims that the Day has arrived (2:1-2), signs that must first occur: rebellion, man of lawlessness revealed, restrainer removed (2:3-12), thanksgiving that God chose the Thessalonians for salvation (2:13-14), exhortation to stand firm in apostolic traditions (2:15-17). **Request and Discipline (3:1-15)**: Request for prayer for the gospel's advance (3:1-2), assurance of God's faithfulness and protection from evil (3:3-5), command to keep away from idle brothers (3:6), Paul's example of hard work (3:7-9), rule that the unwilling worker should not eat (3:10-12), instruction not to grow weary in doing good and to discipline the disobedient while treating them as brothers (3:13-15). **Conclusion (3:16-18)**: Prayer for peace (3:16), authenticating signature in Paul's own hand (3:17), benediction (3:18).

## Part 14: Later New Testament Writings

### Historical and Cultural Background: Later New Testament Writings

**Historical Context (Second Generation Christianity: 60-95 CE)**

The Later New Testament period encompasses writings from Christianity's second generation, addressing increasingly organized churches, emerging leadership structures, developing theology, false teaching threats, and persecution realities. Traditional dating places the Prison Epistles (Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians, Philemon) in Paul's Roman imprisonment (60-62 CE), though some scholars propose Caesarean or Ephesian imprisonment, or pseudonymous authorship (especially Ephesians) from the post-Pauline period (70-90 CE). The Pastoral Epistles (1-2 Timothy, Titus) claim Pauline authorship but face scholarly debate, with critical scholarship often dating them to 80-100 CE as pseudonymous works addressing second-generation concerns using Paul's authority. Hebrews (authorship unknown, written to Jewish Christians, possibly before 70 CE or 80s-90s CE) addresses apostasy threats and interprets Christ through priestly/sacrificial categories. The General Epistles (James, 1-2 Peter, 1-3 John, Jude) address diverse communities facing persecution, false teaching, and moral challenges, with dating ranging from James (possibly 40s-60s CE if by Jesus' brother) through 2 Peter (possibly 80-100 CE). This period witnessed: Jerusalem's destruction (70 CE) removing Christianity's Jewish center; apostolic generation's deaths (Paul c. 64-68 CE, Peter c. 64-68 CE, James 62 CE per Josephus); Neronian persecution (64-68 CE); Domitian's reign (81-96 CE) with possible localized persecutions; and Christianity's transformation from apostolic founding to institutionalized structures, canonical consciousness, and increasingly Gentile identity.

**Geographic Setting**

Later NT writings address churches throughout the Roman Empire's eastern Mediterranean and beyond. The Prison Epistles reference Ephesus (major Pauline center in Asia Minor), Philippi (Macedonia), Colossae (Phrygia, Asia Minor threatened by syncretistic teaching), and Rome (Paul's imprisonment location). The Pastoral Epistles address Ephesus (Timothy's location) and Crete (Titus's mission field), reflecting Paul's alleged travels between imprisonments (disputed historically). Hebrews' destination remains uncertain—possibly Rome (based on "those from Italy send greetings," Heb 13:24), Jerusalem-area Jewish Christians, or Alexandria. James addresses the "twelve tribes in the Dispersion," suggesting diaspora Jewish Christians throughout the Mediterranean. 1 Peter explicitly addresses believers scattered throughout "Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia" (1:1)—regions in Asia Minor experiencing persecution. 2 Peter and Jude address general Christian audiences facing false teaching. The Johannine epistles (1-3 John) likely originate from Ephesus (traditional association with John the Elder/Apostle) addressing Asian churches. By this period, Christianity had spread throughout the empire's urban centers and rural regions, with major concentrations in Asia Minor, Syria, Egypt, Greece, Italy, and possibly Gaul and North Africa according to later tradition. The Jerusalem church's destruction (70 CE) shifted Christianity's center westward to Antioch, Ephesus, Alexandria, and Rome.

**Cultural Context**

Second-generation Christians navigated increasing tensions between Christian identity and Greco-Roman society, developing institutional structures and confronting syncretism. **Household codes** (Haustafel) appear in Ephesians, Colossians, and the Pastorals, addressing Christian family structures (husbands/wives, parents/children, masters/slaves) within Greco-Roman patriarchal contexts, sometimes accommodating, sometimes subverting cultural norms. **Church organization** developed: bishops/overseers (episkopoi), elders (presbyteroi), and deacons (diakonoi) emerged as distinct offices (1 Timothy 3; Titus 1), replacing charismatic leadership with institutional authority. **Widows** received institutional support (1 Timothy 5:3-16). **Women's roles** faced increasing restriction in some contexts (1 Timothy 2:11-15) while maintaining leadership in others (Phoebe, Priscilla). **Sound doctrine** concerns proliferated as the apostolic generation died, requiring written authoritative teachings to combat heresies. **Greco-Roman philosophical influence** appears in cosmic Christology (Colossians), Logos theology (John), and engagement with Greek categories while maintaining Jewish monotheism. **Honor-shame dynamics** continued: persecution brought shame, reinterpreted as sharing Christ's sufferings and securing future honor. **Social stratification** in churches is addressed: rich and poor (James 2:1-7), slaves and masters (Philemon, Ephesians 6:5-9), requiring unity across social boundaries. **Persecution experiences** vary from social marginalization (1 Peter) to martyrdom threats (Hebrews), requiring theological frameworks for suffering.

**Political Context**

The Later NT period witnessed increasing Christian-Roman tensions culminating in persecutions and Christianity's separation from Judaism's legal protections. Nero's persecution (64-68 CE) following Rome's great fire (64 CE) blamed Christians, resulting in Peter and Paul's martyrdoms (traditional dating 64-68 CE). 1 Clement (c. 95-96 CE) references these deaths. Domitian (81-96 CE) is traditionally associated with persecution, though extent is debated—possible emperor cult enforcement, execution of aristocratic Christians (Flavius Clemens, Domitilla), and localized Asian persecutions. 1 Peter addresses suffering "as a Christian" (4:16), suggesting the name itself was criminalized. Pliny the Younger's letter to Trajan (c. 112 CE) confirms Christianity's illegal status and execution of confessing Christians. Christians faced charges of atheism (refusing traditional gods), disloyalty (refusing emperor worship), immorality (misunderstood "love feasts"), and antisocial behavior (separating from civic religion). The NT response varies: Romans 13:1-7 advocates submission to governing authorities; Revelation portrays Rome as Babylon, oppressive beast, and whore, calling for resistance. 1 Peter counsels patient endurance and honorable conduct to shame false accusations (2:12-17). The Jewish Revolt's failure (70 CE) and Bar Kokhba revolt (132-135 CE) further separated Christianity from Judaism politically, removing Christianity's inherited legal status (religio licita) as Christianity became increasingly Gentile and distinct.

**Economic Context**

Economic concerns in Later NT writings reflect maturing churches addressing wealth distribution, support systems, and Christian engagement with commercial life. The Prison Epistles show Paul supported by churches (Philippians' gifts, 4:10-19) and hosting visitors during imprisonment, requiring financial resources. Philemon addresses slavery economically: Onesimus, a runaway slave, possibly owing Philemon financial restitution, is sent back with Paul's plea for forgiveness and reception as brother rather than property—neither abolishing slavery institutionally nor supporting it theologically. The Pastoral Epistles address wealthy church members: avoiding materialism (1 Timothy 6:9-10, "love of money is root of all evil"), being generous (6:17-19), and supporting church leaders financially ("double honor" for elders, 1 Timothy 5:17-18). Institutional widow support required means testing and family responsibility parameters (1 Timothy 5:3-16). James strongly critiques wealth inequality: condemning rich oppressors (5:1-6), warning against favoritism toward wealthy (2:1-7), and emphasizing practical charity as true religion (1:27; 2:14-17). 1 Peter addresses slaves experiencing suffering under harsh masters (2:18-25), providing theological framework. Hebrews references property confiscation during persecution (10:32-34), requiring economic solidarity. The emerging institutional church required funding for clergy, widows, hospitality to traveling ministers, and relief for persecuted believers, necessitating economic organization and patron support while maintaining prophetic critique of wealth.

**Religious Context**

Later NT writings address second-generation challenges: maintaining apostolic teaching amid false teachings, developing institutional structures, articulating Christology, and navigating persecution theologically. **False teaching threats**: Colossians confronts proto-Gnostic syncretism combining Jewish, pagan, and Christian elements (angel worship, asceticism, cosmic powers). The Pastorals combat teachings forbidding marriage, requiring vegetarianism, and denying future resurrection (1 Timothy 4:1-5; 2 Timothy 2:16-18). 2 Peter and Jude address libertine false teachers denying Christ's return and living immorally. 1 John confronts Docetism (denying Christ came in flesh, 4:2-3) and antinomian ethics. **Christological development**: Colossians presents cosmic Christ ("image of invisible God, firstborn of creation," 1:15-20); Hebrews interprets Christ as eternal high priest superseding Levitical priesthood; Johannine literature affirms Christ's deity and incarnation against Docetic denials. **Church structure**: Pastoral Epistles formalize qualifications for bishops/overseers, elders, and deacons (1 Timothy 3; Titus 1), shifting from charismatic to institutional authority. **Canon consciousness**: 2 Peter 3:15-16 references Paul's letters as Scripture, indicating canonical recognition. Jude references 1 Enoch, showing fluid canonical boundaries. **Apostasy concerns**: Hebrews warns against falling away (6:4-8; 10:26-31); 2 Peter and Jude combat scoffers denying Christ's return. **Persecution theology**: 1 Peter reframes suffering as participation in Christ's sufferings (4:12-19); Hebrews encourages perseverance through Christ's high priestly intercession and heavenly reality. **Ethics**: James emphasizes faith-works integration (2:14-26); the Pastorals stress godliness and sound doctrine; 1 John emphasizes love as Christian identity marker (3:11-18; 4:7-21). **Eschatology**: 2 Peter addresses "delay" of parousia (3:3-13), reinterpreting as patience not delay.

## Ephesians

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Ephesians is traditionally dated to Paul's Roman imprisonment (c. 60-62 CE), part of the "Prison Epistles" with Philippians, Colossians, and Philemon (1:1, 3:1, 4:1, 6:20). However, authorship remains debated: traditional view defends Pauline authorship, while many modern scholars propose a Pauline disciple wrote it (c. 80-95 CE) using Paul's theology but adapting it for later church needs. Arguments for pseudonymous authorship include: different vocabulary/style from undisputed Pauline letters (42 hapax legomena), theological development (more cosmic/universal ecclesiology, realized eschatology), literary dependence on Colossians (sharing 1/3 of content), and lack of personal greetings despite Paul's extended Ephesian ministry (Acts 19). Arguments for authenticity include: ancient unanimous attribution, strong manuscript evidence, amanuensis explaining style differences, and theological continuity with Paul's thought. Regardless of authorship, Ephesians addresses established churches, likely as circular letter (earliest manuscripts omit "in Ephesus," 1:1; Paul wouldn't need to introduce himself to Ephesians after 3-year ministry). The letter synthesizes Paul's theology, emphasizing church unity, cosmic Christology, and Christian ethics flowing from salvation.

**Author and Audience:** Traditional attribution to Paul is contested. The letter claims Pauline authorship (1:1, 3:1) but lacks personal touches expected after Paul's 3-year Ephesian ministry (Acts 19:8-10, 20:31). The address "to the saints in Ephesus" is absent from earliest manuscripts (P46, Codex Vaticanus, Codex Sinaiticus), suggesting circular letter to Asia Minor churches. Recipients are Gentile Christians ("you Gentiles," 2:11, 3:1; formerly "dead in trespasses and sins," 2:1-3) now incorporated into God's household with Jewish believers (2:11-22). The audience knows Paul's ministry reputation (3:2-4) but may not know him personally, explaining lack of greetings. Ephesians addresses mature Christians needing ecclesiological teaching: church as Christ's body (1:22-23, 4:15-16), unity amid diversity (4:1-16), and cosmic battle requiring spiritual armor (6:10-20). The letter's elevated, liturgical style suggests use in worship contexts, teaching new converts about their identity in Christ and ethical implications.

**Key Themes:** **Salvation in Christ**: Believers chosen before foundation (1:4), predestined for adoption (1:5), redeemed through Christ's blood (1:7), sealed with the Spirit (1:13), saved by grace through faith (2:8-9), created for good works (2:10). **Church as Christ's Body**: Ecclesiology emphasizes church as universal body with Christ as head (1:22-23), growing into Christ (4:15-16), requiring unity (4:3-6). **Unity of Jew and Gentile**: Christ abolished dividing wall between Jew and Gentile (2:14-16), creating "one new man" (2:15), both accessing Father through one Spirit (2:18). **Cosmic Christology**: Christ fills all in all (1:23), sits above all rule and authority (1:20-21), unites all things under his headship (1:10). **Walk Worthy**: Ethical exhortations emphasize "walking" worthy of calling (4:1), in love (5:2), as children of light (5:8), wisely (5:15). **Spiritual Warfare**: Believers battle not flesh and blood but spiritual forces, requiring God's armor (6:10-20). **Household Codes**: Mutual submission structures marriages (5:21-33), families (6:1-4), and master-slave relations (6:5-9).

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Ephesus Excavations**: Extensive remains include Temple of Artemis site, theater (Acts 19:29), library of Celsus, agora, and harbor street, contextualizing Ephesians' original audience. Paul's 3-year ministry (Acts 19) established Ephesus as mission center. **Artemis Cult**: Archaeological evidence of Diana/Artemis worship (one of Seven Wonders) contextualizes Ephesians' spiritual warfare imagery (6:10-20) and rejection of idolatry. **Imperial Cult**: Temples and inscriptions evidencing emperor worship in Ephesus contrast with Ephesians' Christ as supreme over all powers (1:20-21). **Manumission Inscriptions**: Evidence of slavery practices illuminates Ephesians 6:5-9's household codes and spiritual freedom metaphors.

**Structure:** **Doctrinal Section (1-3)**: Blessings in Christ (1:3-14), prayer for wisdom (1:15-23), salvation by grace (2:1-10), Jew-Gentile unity (2:11-22), Paul's ministry to Gentiles (3:1-13), prayer for strengthening (3:14-21). **Ethical Section (4-6)**: Unity and gifts (4:1-16), new life (4:17-32), love and purity (5:1-20), household codes (5:21-6:9), spiritual warfare (6:10-20), conclusion (6:21-24). Ephesians presents high Pauline theology with practical application for church life.

## Philippians

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Philippians is dated to Paul's imprisonment, debated between Ephesian (c. 54-55 CE), Caesarean (58-60 CE), or Roman (60-62 CE) imprisonment. Most scholars favor Roman imprisonment based on: references to "whole imperial guard" (praetorium, 1:13), "Caesar's household" (4:22), developed theological reflection, and proximity to death (1:20-26, 2:17). However, Ephesian imprisonment advocates note: frequent communication implied (4:18, suggesting geographic proximity), threat of imminent death (1:20-23, less likely during Roman house arrest), and Timothy's anticipated travel (2:19-24). The letter responds to Epaphroditus's visit bringing financial support (4:10-20), his illness and recovery (2:25-30), and reports of church challenges: external opposition (1:27-30), internal disunity (2:1-4, 4:2-3), and Judaizer infiltration (3:2-11). Paul writes from chains (1:7, 13-14, 17) with uncertain outcome, expressing joy (16 times) despite circumstances, encouraging unity, and warning against legalistic teachers.

**Author and Audience:** Pauline authorship is undisputed. Paul and Timothy send greetings (1:1) to "all the saints in Christ Jesus who are at Philippi, with the overseers and deacons" (1:1). Philippi, a Roman colony in Macedonia (Acts 16:12), was Paul's first European convert community (c. 49-50 CE), including Lydia the purple merchant, the Philippian jailer, and others (Acts 16:11-40). The church demonstrated exceptional generosity, supporting Paul's mission multiple times (4:15-16) and sending Epaphroditus with gifts (4:18). Paul addresses a beloved, supportive church facing persecution (1:27-30), internal conflict between Euodia and Syntyche (4:2-3), and external threat from "dogs... evil workers... mutilators" (3:2, likely Judaizers). The letter's warm, personal tone contrasts with Galatians' severity, reflecting Paul's affectionate relationship with Philippians.

**Key Themes:** **Joy in Suffering**: Despite imprisonment and possible death, Paul exhorts "rejoice" (1:18, 2:18, 3:1, 4:4). Joy transcends circumstances, rooted in Christ's presence and gospel advance (1:18-26). **Christ Hymn**: Philippians 2:6-11 presents Christ's self-emptying (kenosis): though in God's form, he emptied himself, taking servant form, humbling himself to death, therefore God exalted him, giving him the name above every name. This hymn grounds Christian humility and unity. **Imitation of Christ**: Believers should have Christ's mindset (2:5), Paul's example (3:17, 4:9), Timothy's selflessness (2:19-24), and Epaphroditus's sacrificial service (2:25-30). **Unity and Humility**: Paul pleads for same mind, love, accord (2:2), doing nothing from selfish ambition (2:3), considering others (2:4). **Righteousness Through Faith**: Paul renounces former confidence in flesh (3:4-6: circumcised, Pharisee, Law-zealous), counting all as loss for Christ (3:7-8), pursuing righteousness through faith not Law (3:9). **Press Toward the Goal**: Christian life is forward-looking race (3:12-14), not static achievement but pressing toward upward call. **Contentment**: Paul learned contentment in all circumstances (4:11-13), able to do all things through Christ strengthening him (4:13).

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Philippi Excavations**: Extensive remains include Roman forum, Via Egnatia road, theater, and prison (traditional site where Paul/Silas were imprisoned, Acts 16:23-24). The city's Roman colony status (Acts 16:12) is confirmed archaeologically. **Purple Trade**: Inscriptions evidence purple-dye industry (Lydia's occupation, Acts 16:14). **Praetorian Guard**: References to praetorium (1:13) and Caesar's household (4:22) fit Roman imperial context, though could refer to provincial governors' headquarters. **Roman Citizenship**: Philippi's Roman colony status meant many inhabitants held citizenship, contextualizing Acts 16:37-39's appeal to citizen rights and Philippians' engagement with Roman imperial cult (Paul's "Lord" language subverts Caesar).

**Structure:** **Opening (1:1-11)**: Greeting (1:1-2), thanksgiving for partnership (1:3-8), prayer for love and discernment (1:9-11). **Paul's Circumstances (1:12-26)**: Gospel advances despite chains (1:12-18), life or death both gain (1:19-26). **Exhortations (1:27-2:18)**: Stand firm (1:27-30), unity and humility (2:1-4), Christ hymn (2:5-11), work out salvation (2:12-18). **Travel Plans (2:19-30)**: Timothy's anticipated visit (2:19-24), Epaphroditus's return (2:25-30). **Warning and Testimony (3:1-21)**: Beware dogs/evil workers (3:2-3), Paul's former credentials now loss (3:4-11), press toward goal (3:12-16), beware enemies of cross (3:17-21). **Final Exhortations (4:1-9)**: Stand firm (4:1), Euodia/Syntyche reconciliation (4:2-3), rejoice always (4:4-7), think on excellent things (4:8-9). **Thanksgiving (4:10-20)**: Gratitude for support, contentment learned (4:10-13), generous partnership praised (4:14-20). **Closing (4:21-23)**: Greetings, benediction. Philippians radiates joy and partnership despite adversity.

### Philippians Chapter 3

Finally, my brethren, rejoice in the Lord. To write the same things to you, to me indeed
is not grievous, but for you
it is
 safe.
Beware of dogs, beware of evil workers, beware of the concision.
For we are the circumcision, which worship God in the spirit, and rejoice in Christ Jesus, and have no confidence in the flesh.
Though I might also have confidence in the flesh. If any other man thinketh that he hath whereof he might trust in the flesh, I more:
Circumcised the eighth day, of the stock of Israel,
of the tribe of Benjamin, an Hebrew of the Hebrews; as touching the law, a Pharisee;
Concerning zeal, persecuting the church; touching the righteousness which is in the law, blameless.
But what things were gain to me, those I counted loss for Christ.
Yea doubtless, and I count all things
but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them
but dung, that I may win Christ,
And be found in him, not having mine own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith:
That I may know him, and the power of his resurrection, and the fellowship of his sufferings, being made conformable unto his death;
If by any means I might attain unto the resurrection of the dead.
Not as though I had already attained, either were already perfect: but I follow after, if that I may apprehend that for which also I am apprehended of Christ Jesus.
Brethren, I count not myself to have apprehended: but
this
 one thing
I do, forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth unto those things which are before,
I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.
Let us therefore, as many as be perfect, be thus minded: and if in any thing ye be otherwise minded, God shall reveal even this unto you.
Nevertheless, whereto we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule, let us mind the same thing.
Brethren, be followers together of me, and mark them which walk so as ye have us for an ensample.
(For many walk, of whom I have told you often, and now tell you even weeping,
that they are the enemies of the cross of Christ:
Whose end
is destruction, whose God
is their belly, and
whose glory
is in their shame, who mind earthly things.)
For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ:
Who shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body, according to the working whereby he is able even to subdue all things unto himself.


### Philippians Chapter 4

Therefore, my brethren dearly beloved and longed for, my joy and crown, so stand fast in the Lord,
my dearly beloved.
I beseech Euodias, and beseech Syntyche, that they be of the same mind in the Lord.
And I intreat thee also, true yokefellow, help those women which laboured with me in the gospel, with Clement also, and
with other my fellowlabourers, whose names
are in the book of life.
Rejoice in the Lord alway:
and again I say, Rejoice.
Let your moderation be known unto all men. The Lord
is at hand.
Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.
And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus.
Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things
are honest, whatsoever things
are just, whatsoever things
are pure, whatsoever things
are lovely, whatsoever things
are of good report; if
there be any virtue, and if
there be any praise, think on these things.
Those things, which ye have both learned, and received, and heard, and seen in me, do: and the God of peace shall be with you.
But I rejoiced in the Lord greatly, that now at the last your care of me hath flourished again; wherein ye were also careful, but ye lacked opportunity.
Not that I speak in respect of want: for I have learned, in whatsoever state I am,
therewith to be content.
I know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound: every where and in all things I am instructed both to be full and to be hungry, both to abound and to suffer need.
I can do all things through Christ which strengtheneth me.
Notwithstanding ye have well done, that ye did communicate with my affliction.
Now ye Philippians know also, that in the beginning of the gospel, when I departed from Macedonia, no church communicated with me as concerning giving and receiving, but ye only.
For even in Thessalonica ye sent once and again unto my necessity.
Not because I desire a gift: but I desire fruit that may abound to your account.
But I have all, and abound: I am full, having received of Epaphroditus the things
which were sent from you, an odour of a sweet smell, a sacrifice acceptable, wellpleasing to God.
But my God shall supply all your need according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus.
Now unto God and our Father
be glory for ever and ever. Amen.
Salute every saint in Christ Jesus. The brethren which are with me greet you.
All the saints salute you, chiefly they that are of Caesar’s household.
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ
be with you all. Amen.

## Colossians

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Colossians is traditionally dated to Paul's Roman imprisonment (c. 60-62 CE), though some scholars debate Ephesian imprisonment (54-55 CE) or pseudonymous authorship (70-80 CE). Arguments for Pauline authorship include: personal references to Paul's imprisonment (4:3, 10, 18), connection to Philemon (Onesimus and Archippus mentioned in both), Timothy as co-sender (1:1), and similarities to undisputed Pauline letters. Arguments for pseudonymity cite: developed Christology, cosmic emphasis, realized eschatology, household codes, and linguistic differences from undisputed letters. The letter addresses a specific crisis in Colossae involving syncretistic teachings combining Jewish practices, angelic worship, and proto-Gnostic elements (2:8-23), suggesting composition during a period when such philosophies threatened early Christian communities.

**Author and Audience:** The letter claims authorship by "Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, and Timothy our brother" (1:1), addressed "to the saints and faithful brothers in Christ at Colossae" (1:2). Colossae was a city in the Lycus River valley of Phrygia (southwestern Asia Minor), about 100 miles east of Ephesus. By the first century, Colossae had declined from earlier prominence, overshadowed by nearby Laodicea and Hierapolis (4:13). Paul had apparently not personally visited Colossae (2:1), but the church was founded through his ministry influence, likely by Epaphras (1:7, 4:12-13). The congregation included both Jewish and Gentile believers (1:27, 2:11-13, 3:11). Archaeological evidence shows Colossae was destroyed by earthquake c. 60-64 CE and never fully rebuilt, making early dating more plausible if recipients needed to receive the letter.

**Key Themes:** **Christ's Cosmic Supremacy**: The magnificent Christ hymn (1:15-20) declares Jesus as "image of the invisible God, firstborn of all creation," through whom "all things were created" and in whom "all things hold together" - a direct refutation of any teaching that would subordinate Christ to angelic intermediaries or cosmic powers. **Fullness in Christ**: Against syncretistic philosophies requiring additional spiritual practices, Paul insists believers have been "brought to fullness" in Christ (2:9-10), who is "the fullness of the Deity in bodily form." **New Humanity**: The gospel creates a renewed humanity where "there is no Gentile or Jew, circumcised or uncircumcised, barbarian, Scythian, slave or free, but Christ is all, and is in all" (3:11). **Mystery Revealed**: The "mystery hidden for ages" is now revealed: "Christ in you, the hope of glory" (1:26-27), extending salvation to Gentiles. **Victory Over Powers**: Through the cross, Christ "disarmed the powers and authorities" and "made a public spectacle of them, triumphing over them" (2:15), establishing his sovereignty over all spiritual forces.

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Colossae Excavations**: Unlike nearby Laodicea and Hierapolis, Colossae (modern Honaz, Turkey) has never been systematically excavated. Surface surveys identify the ancient site on a mound near the Lycus River, with visible remains including a theater and necropolis. The lack of excavation ironically confirms the city's decline after the earthquake, never achieving the prominence that would attract later building or modern archaeological attention. **Laodicea and Hierapolis**: Extensive excavations at these nearby cities mentioned in Colossians (4:13, 15-16) provide cultural context. Laodicea, seven miles west, was a wealthy banking center (cf. Rev 3:17) with a medical school famous for eye ointment. The Plutonium (gate to the underworld) at Hierapolis, ten miles north, attracted worshippers of Cybele and Apollo, illustrating the syncretistic religious environment. The three cities formed a close cluster of Christian communities sharing apostolic letters. **Lycus Valley Inscriptions**: Numerous inscriptions from the region document mystery cults, angelic veneration, and Jewish communities, corroborating the religious milieu Paul addresses. Jewish inscriptions confirm significant Jewish presence in Phrygia (cf. Acts 2:10), explaining Jewish elements in the Colossian heresy. **Papyrus Evidence**: No early manuscripts of Colossians alone survive, but it appears in major codices (Sinaiticus, Vaticanus, Alexandrinus, 4th-5th centuries) as part of the Pauline corpus, demonstrating early canonical acceptance.

**Structure:** **Opening (1:1-14)**: Greeting (1:1-2), thanksgiving for the Colossians' faith and love (1:3-8), prayer for spiritual wisdom and fruitful living (1:9-14). **Doctrinal Section (1:15-2:23)**: Christ hymn asserting his supremacy over all creation and reconciliation (1:15-23), Paul's ministry to reveal the mystery of Christ in Gentiles (1:24-2:5), warning against deceptive philosophy and human traditions (2:6-23) including regulations about food, festivals, and worship of angels. **Ethical Section (3:1-4:6)**: Seeking things above (3:1-4), putting to death earthly nature and sins of the old self (3:5-11), putting on virtues of the new self (3:12-17), household code for wives/husbands, children/parents, slaves/masters (3:18-4:1), prayer and evangelistic wisdom (4:2-6). **Conclusion (4:7-18)**: Commendation of Tychicus and Onesimus (4:7-9), greetings from Paul's companions (4:10-14), instructions regarding letter circulation and Laodicean letter (4:15-17), personal greeting in Paul's hand (4:18).
