### Colossians Chapter 1

Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and Timotheus
our brother,
To the saints and faithful brethren in Christ which are at Colosse: Grace
be unto you, and peace, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
We give thanks to God and the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, praying always for you,
Since we heard of your faith in Christ Jesus, and of the love
which ye have to all the saints,
For the hope which is laid up for you in heaven, whereof ye heard before in the word of the truth of the gospel;
Which is come unto you, as
it is in all the world; and bringeth forth fruit, as
it doth also in you, since the day ye heard
of it, and knew the grace of God in truth:
As ye also learned of Epaphras our dear fellowservant, who is for you a faithful minister of Christ;
Who also declared unto us your love in the Spirit.
For this cause we also, since the day we heard
it, do not cease to pray for you, and to desire that ye might be filled with the knowledge of his will in all wisdom and spiritual understanding;
That ye might walk worthy of the Lord unto all pleasing, being fruitful in every good work, and increasing in the knowledge of God;
Strengthened with all might, according to his glorious power, unto all patience and longsuffering with joyfulness;
Giving thanks unto the Father, which hath made us meet to be partakers of the inheritance of the saints in light:
Who hath delivered us from the power of darkness, and hath translated
us into the kingdom of his dear Son:
In whom we have redemption through his blood,
even the forgiveness of sins:
Who is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of every creature:
For by him were all things created, that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible, whether
they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers: all things were created by him, and for him:
And he is before all things, and by him all things consist.
And he is the head of the body, the church: who is the beginning, the firstborn from the dead; that in all
things he might have the preeminence.
For it pleased
the Father that in him should all fulness dwell;
And, having made peace through the blood of his cross, by him to reconcile all things unto himself; by him,
I say, whether
they be things in earth, or things in heaven.
And you, that were sometime alienated and enemies in
your
 mind by wicked works, yet now hath he reconciled
In the body of his flesh through death, to present you holy and unblameable and unreproveable in his sight:
If ye continue in the faith grounded and settled, and
be
 not moved away from the hope of the gospel, which ye have heard,
and which was preached to every creature which is under heaven; whereof I Paul am made a minister;
Who now rejoice in my sufferings for you, and fill up that which is behind of the afflictions of Christ in my flesh for his body’s sake, which is the church:
Whereof I am made a minister, according to the dispensation of God which is given to me for you, to fulfil the word of God;
Even the mystery which hath been hid from ages and from generations, but now is made manifest to his saints:
To whom God would make known what
is the riches of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles; which is Christ in you, the hope of glory:
Whom we preach, warning every man, and teaching every man in all wisdom; that we may present every man perfect in Christ Jesus:
Whereunto I also labour, striving according to his working, which worketh in me mightily.


### Colossians Chapter 2

For I would that ye knew what great conflict I have for you, and
for them at Laodicea, and
for as many as have not seen my face in the flesh;
That their hearts might be comforted, being knit together in love, and unto all riches of the full assurance of understanding, to the acknowledgement of the mystery of God, and of the Father, and of Christ;
In whom are hid all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.
And this I say, lest any man should beguile you with enticing words.
For though I be absent in the flesh, yet am I with you in the spirit, joying and beholding your order, and the stedfastness of your faith in Christ.
As ye have therefore received Christ Jesus the Lord,
so walk ye in him:
Rooted and built up in him, and stablished in the faith, as ye have been taught, abounding therein with thanksgiving.
Beware lest any man spoil you through philosophy and vain deceit, after the tradition of men, after the rudiments of the world, and not after Christ.
For in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily.
And ye are complete in him, which is the head of all principality and power:
In whom also ye are circumcised with the circumcision made without hands, in putting off the body of the sins of the flesh by the circumcision of Christ:
Buried with him in baptism, wherein also ye are risen with
him
 through the faith of the operation of God, who hath raised him from the dead.
And you, being dead in your sins and the uncircumcision of your flesh, hath he quickened together with him, having forgiven you all trespasses;
Blotting out the handwriting of ordinances that was against us, which was contrary to us, and took it out of the way, nailing it to his cross;
And having spoiled principalities and powers, he made a shew of them openly, triumphing over them in it.
Let no man therefore judge you in meat, or in drink, or in respect of an holyday, or of the new moon, or of the sabbath
days:
Which are a shadow of things to come; but the body
is of Christ.
Let no man beguile you of your reward in a voluntary humility and worshipping of angels, intruding into those things which he hath not seen, vainly puffed up by his fleshly mind,
And not holding the Head, from which all the body by joints and bands having nourishment ministered, and knit together, increaseth with the increase of God.
Wherefore if ye be dead with Christ from the rudiments of the world, why, as though living in the world, are ye subject to ordinances,
(Touch not; taste not; handle not;
Which all are to perish with the using;) after the commandments and doctrines of men?
Which things have indeed a shew of wisdom in will worship, and humility, and neglecting of the body; not in any honour to the satisfying of the flesh.


### Colossians Chapter 3

If ye then be risen with Christ, seek those things which are above, where Christ sitteth on the right hand of God.
Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth.
For ye are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God.
When Christ,
who is our life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with him in glory.
Mortify therefore your members which are upon the earth; fornication, uncleanness, inordinate affection, evil concupiscence, and covetousness, which is idolatry:
For which things’ sake the wrath of God cometh on the children of disobedience:
In the which ye also walked some time, when ye lived in them.
But now ye also put off all these; anger, wrath, malice, blasphemy, filthy communication out of your mouth.
Lie not one to another, seeing that ye have put off the old man with his deeds;
And have put on the new
man, which is renewed in knowledge after the image of him that created him:
Where there is neither Greek nor Jew, circumcision nor uncircumcision, Barbarian, Scythian, bond
nor free: but Christ
is all, and in all.
Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness of mind, meekness, longsuffering;
Forbearing one another, and forgiving one another, if any man have a quarrel against any: even as Christ forgave you, so also
do ye.
And above all these things
put on charity, which is the bond of perfectness.
And let the peace of God rule in your hearts, to the which also ye are called in one body; and be ye thankful.
Let the word of Christ dwell in you richly in all wisdom; teaching and admonishing one another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing with grace in your hearts to the Lord.
And whatsoever ye do in word or deed,
do all in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God and the Father by him.
Wives, submit yourselves unto your own husbands, as it is fit in the Lord.
Husbands, love
your wives, and be not bitter against them.
Children, obey
your parents in all things: for this is well pleasing unto the Lord.
Fathers, provoke not your children
to anger, lest they be discouraged.
Servants, obey in all things
your masters according to the flesh; not with eyeservice, as menpleasers; but in singleness of heart, fearing God:
And whatsoever ye do, do
it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men;
Knowing that of the Lord ye shall receive the reward of the inheritance: for ye serve the Lord Christ.
But he that doeth wrong shall receive for the wrong which he hath done: and there is no respect of persons.


### Colossians Chapter 4

Masters, give unto
your servants that which is just and equal; knowing that ye also have a Master in heaven.
Continue in prayer, and watch in the same with thanksgiving;
Withal praying also for us, that God would open unto us a door of utterance, to speak the mystery of Christ, for which I am also in bonds:
That I may make it manifest, as I ought to speak.
Walk in wisdom toward them that are without, redeeming the time.
Let your speech
be alway with grace, seasoned with salt, that ye may know how ye ought to answer every man.
All my state shall Tychicus declare unto you,
who is a beloved brother, and a faithful minister and fellowservant in the Lord:
Whom I have sent unto you for the same purpose, that he might know your estate, and comfort your hearts;
With Onesimus, a faithful and beloved brother, who is
one
 of you. They shall make known unto you all things which
are done
 here.
Aristarchus my fellowprisoner saluteth you, and Marcus, sister’s son to Barnabas, (touching whom ye received commandments: if he come unto you, receive him;)
And Jesus, which is called Justus, who are of the circumcision. These only
are my fellow workers unto the kingdom of God, which have been a comfort unto me.
Epaphras, who is
one of you, a servant of Christ, saluteth you, always labouring fervently for you in prayers, that ye may stand perfect and complete in all the will of God.
For I bear him record, that he hath a great zeal for you, and them
that are in Laodicea, and them in Hierapolis.
Luke, the beloved physician, and Demas, greet you.
Salute the brethren which are in Laodicea, and Nymphas, and the church which is in his house.
And when this epistle is read among you, cause that it be read also in the church of the Laodiceans; and that ye likewise read the
epistle
 from Laodicea.
And say to Archippus, Take heed to the ministry which thou hast received in the Lord, that thou fulfil it.
The salutation by the hand of me Paul. Remember my bonds. Grace
be with you. Amen.

## 1 Timothy

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** 1 Timothy is one of three "Pastoral Epistles" (with 2 Timothy and Titus) that face the New Testament's most intense authorship debates. Traditional dating places the letter during Paul's release from Roman imprisonment (Acts 28), followed by renewed missionary activity (c. 62-64 CE) before his martyrdom under Nero (c. 64-68 CE). This scenario, not recorded in Acts, would have Paul leaving Timothy in Ephesus (1:3) while traveling to Macedonia, planning to return soon (3:14-15). However, many scholars argue for pseudonymous authorship (written by a Pauline disciple c. 80-100 CE) based on: vocabulary and style differences from undisputed Pauline letters (306 words not found elsewhere in Paul, formal bureaucratic tone), developed church structure (bishops, deacons, elders, enrollment of widows), combating second-generation heresies (gnostic-flavored teaching, 6:20's "gnosis"), and theological emphases (orthodoxy, good citizenship, respectability) reflecting institutional consolidation. Traditional scholars counter that Paul could write differently for pastoral purposes, church structures develop quickly, and second imprisonment is historically plausible. The debate significantly affects interpretation: traditional view sees Paul's personal instructions to his delegate; critical view sees later church using Paul's authority to address emerging challenges.

**Author and Audience:** The letter claims "Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by command of God our Savior and of Christ Jesus our hope" (1:1) writing to "Timothy, my true child in the faith" (1:2). Timothy, from Lystra with Jewish mother Eunice and Greek father (Acts 16:1, 2 Tim 1:5), became Paul's trusted companion and co-worker, mentioned in six Pauline letters. The letter addresses Timothy's ministry in Ephesus (1:3), where Paul had spent three years (Acts 19-20). However, the personal references (Timothy's youth, 4:12; stomach ailment, 5:23; need for encouragement) sit uneasily with Timothy being approximately 35-50 years old by the 60s and a well-established leader. Critical scholars suggest these may be literary devices ("verisimilitude") making pseudonymous composition more convincing. The letter's concern with false teachers who "teach any different doctrine" (1:3), practice asceticism (4:3), and engage in "meaningless talk" (1:6) may reflect proto-gnostic movements. References to "genealogies" (1:4), "what is falsely called 'knowledge' (gnosis)" (6:20), and forbidding marriage/certain foods (4:3) suggest a Jewish-gnostic syncretism similar to what Colossians addresses, though more developed.

**Key Themes:** **Church Order**: Detailed qualifications for overseers/bishops (3:1-7) and deacons (3:8-13), with structured leadership replacing charismatic spontaneity - suggesting institutional development or Paul's concern to establish stable structures. **Sound Doctrine**: Repeated emphasis on "sound teaching" (1:10, 6:3), "the faith" (1:19, 3:9, 4:1), "truth" (2:4, 3:15, 4:3, 6:5), and "good doctrine" (4:6) against false teachers and myths, reflecting theological consolidation. **Godliness and Respectability**: The word "godliness" (eusebeia) appears 8 times (vs once in undisputed Paul), associated with contentment, propriety, and social respectability. Church members should live "peaceful and quiet" lives (2:2), women should dress modestly (2:9-15), and leaders must have good reputations with outsiders (3:7). **Care for Widows**: Detailed instructions about enrolling widows for support (5:3-16), distinguishing genuine widows from those with family or younger widows who should remarry, reflects social welfare systems. **Economic Ethics**: Warnings against love of money (6:6-10: "the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil"), instructions for the rich (6:17-19), and Paul's contentment with food and clothing establish Christian economic values. **Salvation Universalism**: God "desires all people to be saved" (2:4), with Christ Jesus as "mediator between God and men" who "gave himself as a ransom for all" (2:5-6), affirming universal salvific scope.

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Ephesus Context**: As with Ephesians and Revelation, 1 Timothy's Ephesian setting benefits from extensive archaeological documentation. The city's prominence as Asia's capital, temple of Artemis (one of seven ancient wonders), theater seating 25,000, marble streets, Library of Celsus, and commercial agora provide backdrop for church development. Inscriptions document various religious cults, social structures, and civic offices that informed church organization. **Church Structure Inscriptions**: While direct archaeological evidence for first-century Christian offices is sparse, Greco-Roman associations, synagogue structures, and religious guilds documented in inscriptions provide analogues for understanding bishops, deacons, and elders. Inscriptions referring to benefactors, patrons, and officials illuminate church leadership patterns. **Women's Roles**: The letter's controversial instructions about women (2:9-15, 5:3-16) reflect first-century Greco-Roman household codes documented in papyri and inscriptions. Archaeological evidence shows some women held significant public roles (priestesses, benefactors, business owners), while cultural norms generally restricted women's public teaching - the letter navigates these tensions. **Economic Context**: References to the rich (6:17-19), contentment vs greed (6:6-10), and care for widows reflect economic stratification documented archaeologically. Most early Christians were lower class, but some wealthy patrons (like Corinth's Erastus) supported communities. **Manuscript Evidence**: Early manuscripts include P129 (3rd century, containing 1 Tim 3:13-4:8), demonstrating the Pastoral Epistles' early circulation. However, Marcion's canon (c. 140 CE) omitted the Pastorals, fueling debates about dating and authorship.

**Structure:** **Opening and Charge to Timothy (1:1-20)**: Greeting (1:1-2), charge to combat false teachers in Ephesus (1:3-11), thanksgiving for Paul's conversion as pattern (1:12-17), commission to Timothy (1:18-20) mentioning Hymenaeus and Alexander. **Instructions on Worship (2:1-15)**: Prayer for all people and authorities (2:1-7), men and women in worship with controversial instructions on women's dress, silence, and learning (2:8-15). **Qualifications for Leaders (3:1-16)**: Overseers/bishops (3:1-7), deacons (3:8-13), purpose statement about conduct in God's household (3:14-15), Christ hymn (3:16). **False Teaching and Godliness (4:1-16)**: Prophecy about apostasy (4:1-5), instructions for Timothy's ministry (4:6-16). **Various Groups (5:1-6:2)**: Treatment of older/younger men and women (5:1-2), care for widows (5:3-16), honor for elders and discipline procedures (5:17-25), instructions for slaves (6:1-2). **False Teaching and Contentment (6:3-21)**: Warning against false teachers motivated by greed (6:3-10), charge to Timothy (6:11-16), instructions for the rich (6:17-19), final warning against "falsely called knowledge" (6:20-21).

### 1 Timothy Chapter 1

Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the commandment of God our Saviour, and Lord Jesus Christ,
which is our hope;
Unto Timothy,
my own son in the faith: Grace, mercy,
and peace, from God our Father and Jesus Christ our Lord.
As I besought thee to abide still at Ephesus, when I went into Macedonia, that thou mightest charge some that they teach no other doctrine,
Neither give heed to fables and endless genealogies, which minister questions, rather than godly edifying which is in faith:
so do.
Now the end of the commandment is charity out of a pure heart, and
of a good conscience, and
of faith unfeigned:
From which some having swerved have turned aside unto vain jangling;
Desiring to be teachers of the law; understanding neither what they say, nor whereof they affirm.
But we know that the law
is good, if a man use it lawfully;
Knowing this, that the law is not made for a righteous man, but for the lawless and disobedient, for the ungodly and for sinners, for unholy and profane, for murderers of fathers and murderers of mothers, for manslayers,
For whoremongers, for them that defile themselves with mankind, for menstealers, for liars, for perjured persons, and if there be any other thing that is contrary to sound doctrine;
According to the glorious gospel of the blessed God, which was committed to my trust.
And I thank Christ Jesus our Lord, who hath enabled me, for that he counted me faithful, putting me into the ministry;
Who was before a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious: but I obtained mercy, because I did
it ignorantly in unbelief.
And the grace of our Lord was exceeding abundant with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus.
This
is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief.
Howbeit for this cause I obtained mercy, that in me first Jesus Christ might shew forth all longsuffering, for a pattern to them which should hereafter believe on him to life everlasting.
Now unto the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God,
be honour and glory for ever and ever. Amen.
This charge I commit unto thee, son Timothy, according to the prophecies which went before on thee, that thou by them mightest war a good warfare;
Holding faith, and a good conscience; which some having put away concerning faith have made shipwreck:
Of whom is Hymenaeus and Alexander; whom I have delivered unto Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme.


### 1 Timothy Chapter 2

I exhort therefore, that, first of all, supplications, prayers, intercessions,
and giving of thanks, be made for all men;
For kings, and
for all that are in authority; that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life in all godliness and honesty.
For this
is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour;
Who will have all men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth.
For
there is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus;
Who gave himself a ransom for all, to be testified in due time.
Whereunto I am ordained a preacher, and an apostle, (I speak the truth in Christ,
and lie not;) a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and verity.
I will therefore that men pray every where, lifting up holy hands, without wrath and doubting.
In like manner also, that women adorn themselves in modest apparel, with shamefacedness and sobriety; not with broided hair, or gold, or pearls, or costly array;
But (which becometh women professing godliness) with good works.
Let the woman learn in silence with all subjection.
But I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence.
For Adam was first formed, then Eve.
And Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in the transgression.
Notwithstanding she shall be saved in childbearing, if they continue in faith and charity and holiness with sobriety.

## 2 Timothy

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** 2 Timothy presents itself as Paul's final letter, written from prison in Rome (1:8, 16-17, 2:9) facing imminent execution (4:6-8). Traditional dating places it c. 64-67 CE during a second Roman imprisonment under Nero's persecution following the great fire of Rome (64 CE). Unlike the first imprisonment's relative freedom (Acts 28), this imprisonment is harsher (1:16-17: Onesiphorus had to search diligently to find Paul; 2:9: "bound with chains as a criminal"). Paul expects death soon (4:6: "the time of my departure has come"), recounts his first defense (4:16-17), and urgently summons Timothy before winter (4:9, 21). However, as with other Pastoral Epistles, many scholars favor pseudonymous authorship (c. 80-100 CE) for similar reasons: vocabulary/style differences, developed theology, and institutional concerns. Yet 2 Timothy differs from 1 Timothy and Titus in its intensely personal tone, specific details (Paul's cloak left at Troas, 4:13; individuals named, 4:9-21), and lack of church organization emphasis, leading some critical scholars to posit authentic Pauline fragments incorporated into a later pseudonymous letter. The emotional power of Paul facing death - whether authentic or literary device - profoundly shapes interpretation.

**Author and Audience:** The letter claims "Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God" (1:1) writing to "Timothy, my beloved child" (1:2). Timothy's background is detailed: grandmother Lois and mother Eunice were believers (1:5), he received "prophecies" at ordination (1:18; cf. 1 Tim 1:18, 4:14), and he suffers from timidity requiring encouragement (1:6-8, 2:1). The letter's occasion is Paul's imminent death and desire for Timothy to come quickly (4:9, 21), bringing Mark and Paul's cloak and parchments (4:11, 13). Paul reports that all in Asia deserted him except Onesiphorus (1:15-18), Demas has abandoned him for love of this world (4:10), Alexander the coppersmith did great harm (4:14), and only Luke remains (4:11). These personal details create verisimilitude, though critical scholars debate whether they're authentic memories or literary construction. The letter addresses Timothy's situation amid false teaching and apostasy (2:14-26, 3:1-9, 4:3-4), preparing him for ministry after Paul's death. If authentic, this represents Christianity's first generation transitioning to the second; if pseudonymous, it uses Paul's authority to guide that later generation.

**Key Themes:** **Suffering and Perseverance**: The letter's dominant theme is enduring suffering for the gospel. Paul exemplifies suffering (1:8, 12; 2:9; 3:10-11; 4:6-8), exhorts Timothy to "share in suffering as a good soldier" (2:3), and warns "all who desire to live a godly life in Christ Jesus will be persecuted" (3:12). Seven examples of endurance appear: soldier, athlete, farmer (2:3-6), Jesus Christ (2:8), Paul himself (2:9-10), the "trustworthy saying" (2:11-13), and elect endurance (2:10). **Guarding the Deposit**: Timothy must "guard the good deposit entrusted to you" (1:14), the gospel tradition received from Paul (1:13, 2:2), passing it to "faithful men who will be able to teach others also" (2:2) - establishing apostolic succession of teaching. **False Teaching**: Detailed warnings against those who "swerve from the truth" (2:18: Hymenaeus and Philetus claim resurrection already occurred), engage in "irreverent babble" (2:16), are "lovers of self, lovers of money" (3:2), and "accumulate teachers to suit their own passions" (4:3). **Scripture's Authority**: The famous declaration that "All Scripture is breathed out by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof, for correction, and for training in righteousness, that the man of God may be complete, equipped for every good work" (3:16-17) establishes biblical authority. **Paul's Legacy**: Paul's swan song (4:6-8) declares "I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith" and anticipates "the crown of righteousness."

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Roman Imprisonment**: Archaeological evidence of Roman prisons, including the Mamertine Prison in Rome (traditional site of Paul's second imprisonment), illuminates harsh conditions. References to chains (1:16, 2:9), searching for prisoners (1:17), and restricted access document prison realities. Inscriptions and literary sources describe Neronian persecution following the 64 CE fire. **Asian Churches**: References to "all in Asia" deserting Paul (1:15) and mentions of Ephesus, Troas, Miletus (1:18, 4:13, 20) connect to extensively excavated cities. Ephesus's role as Asia's leading Christian center makes the desertion particularly poignant. **Travel and Communication**: Paul's request for his cloak left at Troas, books, and parchments (4:13) reflects travel realities and material culture documented archaeologically: winter clothing needs, scroll transportation, and literacy practices. References to Corinth, Galatia, Dalmatia, and Thessalonica (4:10, 20) document missionary network's geographic scope. **Individuals Named**: The letter's numerous personal references - Timothy, Lois, Eunice, Onesiphorus, Demas, Crescens, Titus, Luke, Mark, Tychicus, Carpus, Alexander, Priscilla, Aquila, Erastus, Trophimus, Eubulus, Pudens, Linus, Claudia (1:5; 4:9-21) - create social networks, though few are archaeologically attested beyond New Testament texts. Erastus of Corinth may be the same mentioned in the Erastus inscription. **Manuscript Evidence**: P30 (3rd century) contains portions of 2 Timothy, though fewer early manuscripts exist compared to undisputed Paulines, contributing to authenticity debates.

**Structure:** **Opening and Encouragement (1:1-18)**: Greeting (1:1-2), thanksgiving for Timothy's sincere faith passed from Lois and Eunice (1:3-5), exhortation to fan the gift into flame and not be ashamed of the gospel or Paul's chains (1:6-14), contrast between those who deserted Paul and faithful Onesiphorus (1:15-18). **Pattern of Sound Teaching (2:1-26)**: Call to be strong in grace, passing teachings to faithful people (2:1-2), suffering examples: soldier, athlete, farmer (2:3-13), handling word of truth rightly and avoiding irreverent babble (2:14-19), noble vessels in a great house (2:20-21), instructions for the Lord's servant (2:22-26). **Last Days Difficulties (3:1-17)**: Prophecy of terrible times with vice lists (3:1-9), Paul's persecutions as example (3:10-13), exhortation to continue in what Timothy learned, remembering the sacred writings and Scripture's God-breathed nature (3:14-17). **Solemn Charge and Farewell (4:1-22)**: Charge before God and Christ to preach the word in season and out (4:1-5), Paul's departure and crown awaiting (4:6-8), request for Timothy to come soon with various personal notes about companions (4:9-18), final greetings and benediction (4:19-22).

## Titus

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Titus is dated, like 1 Timothy, to Paul's alleged post-Acts ministry (c. 62-64 CE) following release from first Roman imprisonment. According to the letter, Paul left Titus in Crete to complete organizational work (1:5), while Paul himself traveled (perhaps to Dalmatia, 2 Tim 4:10) planning to winter at Nicopolis (3:12). This scenario assumes a period of renewed missionary activity not recorded in Acts. As with other Pastoral Epistles, critical scholars favor pseudonymous authorship (c. 80-100 CE) based on vocabulary (54% of words not found in undisputed Pauline letters), style, theological emphasis on "sound doctrine" and institutional order, and developed church structures. Titus shares extensive verbal parallels with 1 Timothy (leadership qualifications especially), suggesting common authorship or source. However, Titus's briefer, more concentrated form and lack of personal material found in 2 Timothy make it the most disputed Pastoral Epistle regarding authenticity. Whether Pauline or pseudonymous significantly affects interpretation: either Paul quickly organizing a new mission field or a later generation establishing ecclesiastical structures using apostolic authority.

**Author and Audience:** The letter identifies "Paul, a servant of God and an apostle of Jesus Christ" (1:1) writing to "Titus, my true child in a common faith" (1:4). Titus appears in Paul's letters as a trusted Gentile coworker (Gal 2:1-3: uncircumcised companion to Jerusalem Council; 2 Cor 2:13, 7:6-7, 8:6-23: envoy to Corinth handling the collection), but curiously never appears in Acts - some suggest Luke's reticence reflects Titus being Luke's brother. The letter addresses Christian communities in Crete, the large Mediterranean island south of the Aegean. Paul mentions briefly visiting Crete (Titus 1:5), though Acts only records sailing past it (Acts 27:7-13). According to the letter, Cretan churches needed organizational development (appointing elders, 1:5), doctrinal correction against false teachers ("especially those of the circumcision party," 1:10), and ethical formation to counter the island's bad reputation. Paul quotes "one of their own prophets" (probably the 6th century BCE poet Epimenides): "Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, lazy gluttons" (1:12) - harsh assessment that would be unacceptable today but reflects ancient stereotyping.

**Key Themes:** **Church Order**: Like 1 Timothy, Titus emphasizes proper leadership qualifications. Elders/overseers must be blameless, husband of one wife, with believing children, not arrogant, quick-tempered, drunkard, violent, or greedy, but hospitable, self-controlled, holding firm to the trustworthy word (1:5-9). This structured approach suggests either initial organization or institutional consolidation. **Sound Doctrine**: The phrase "sound doctrine/teaching" appears three times (1:9, 2:1, 2:8), with "sound in the faith" (1:13, 2:2) and contrast to those who are "unfit for any good work" despite professing to know God (1:16). The letter combats false teachers who "upset whole families by teaching for shameful gain what they ought not to teach" (1:11). **Good Works**: Unlike Paul's usual emphasis on faith vs works of Law, Titus repeatedly stresses "good works" (1:16, 2:7, 14, 3:1, 8, 14) - believers should be "zealous for good works" (2:14), "ready for every good work" (3:1), "devoted to good works" (3:8). This raises questions about theological development or different pastoral emphasis. **Household Codes**: Extensive instructions for older men, older women, young women, young men, and slaves (2:2-10) reflect Greco-Roman household management, aimed at making Christianity "attractive" (2:10: "adorn the doctrine"). **Salvation by Grace**: Despite good works emphasis, the theological core affirms salvation by grace: "The grace of God has appeared, bringing salvation for all people" (2:11); "He saved us, not because of works done by us in righteousness, but according to his own mercy" (3:5), through "the washing of regeneration and renewal of the Holy Spirit" (3:5) - possibly early baptismal language.

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Crete in the First Century**: Archaeological evidence documents Crete's role in the Roman Empire. Major cities like Gortyn (perhaps where Titus was based), Knossos, and Cydonia had Roman administrative structures, theaters, aqueducts, and temples. Gortyn's extensive ruins include a basilica traditionally associated with Titus, though archaeological dating shows it's post-Pauline. The famous Gortyn Law Code (5th century BCE), inscribed on stone, demonstrates Crete's legal traditions. **Jewish Presence**: References to "the circumcision party" (1:10) and "Jewish myths" (1:14) presuppose Jewish communities. Archaeological evidence confirms Jewish presence on Crete from Hellenistic period, with Jewish inscriptions and synagogue remains. Acts 2:11 mentions "Cretans" among Pentecost pilgrims, suggesting Jewish diaspora connections. **Cultural Reputation**: The quotation about Cretan character (1:12) reflects ancient stereotypes documented in classical literature. "To Cretanize" (kretizein) meant "to lie" in Greek parlance, showing the island's reputation Paul references. Archaeological evidence of wealth, trade, and cultural sophistication somewhat contradicts negative stereotypes but reflects Roman views of provincial populations. **Church Development**: The letter's emphasis on establishing elders (1:5) in multiple cities suggests Christian penetration across the island, though archaeological evidence of first-century Cretan Christianity is entirely absent - churches became archaeologically visible only from the 4th century. **Manuscript Evidence**: Titus appears in early manuscripts like P32 (c. 200 CE, containing Titus 1:11-15, 2:3-8), demonstrating relatively early circulation, though less attested than undisputed Pauline letters.

**Structure:** **Opening and Church Organization (1:1-16)**: Greeting with expanded theological statement (1:1-4), instructions to appoint elders with specific qualifications (1:5-9), warning against false teachers, especially "the circumcision party" teaching for gain, Cretan reputation, need for rebuke (1:10-16). **Instructions for Various Groups (2:1-15)**: Sound teaching contrasted with false teaching (2:1), instructions for older men (2:2), older women to train younger women in domestic virtues (2:3-5), young men to be self-controlled (2:6-8), slaves to be submissive and honest to adorn the doctrine (2:9-10), theological basis: grace appeared bringing salvation, training us to live godly lives awaiting Christ's appearing (2:11-15). **Christian Conduct and Conclusion (3:1-15)**: Submission to authorities, readiness for good works, gentleness to all (3:1-2), remembering our former sinful state (3:3), salvation by God's mercy through washing of regeneration (3:4-7), stress on good works (3:8), avoiding foolish controversies and divisive people (3:9-11), travel plans and greetings (3:12-15).

## Philemon

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Philemon is dated to Paul's imprisonment, debated between Ephesian (c. 54-55 CE), Caesarean (58-60 CE), or Roman (60-62 CE) captivity. The letter's connection to Colossians (both mention Onesimus, Archippus, Epaphras, Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, Luke) strongly suggests they were written contemporaneously and carried by Tychicus and Onesimus (Col 4:7-9). Traditional Roman imprisonment dating (60-62 CE) fits well: Paul had time for extensive correspondence, Onesimus could plausibly flee to Rome's anonymity, and Paul's hope to visit Philemon (v. 22) aligns with plans to revisit Asia Minor. However, some scholars favor Ephesian imprisonment (inferred from 1 Cor 15:32, 2 Cor 1:8-9, Rom 16:7) as geographically closer to Colossae, making Onesimus's journey more plausible and Paul's intended visit more practical. Caesarean imprisonment is less likely due to distance. Regardless of specific imprisonment location, the letter was written when Paul was a prisoner (vv. 1, 9, 10, 13, 23), creating urgency for Onesimus's situation. Pauline authorship is universally accepted - the letter's brevity, personal nature, and convergence with Colossians make forgery implausible.

**Author and Audience:** The letter identifies "Paul, a prisoner for Christ Jesus, and Timothy our brother" (v. 1) writing to "Philemon our beloved fellow worker and Apphia our sister and Archippus our fellow soldier, and the church in your house" (vv. 1-2). Philemon was a wealthy Christian in Colossae (or nearby Laodicea) who hosted a house church, owned slaves, and had significant resources (v. 22: prepare guest room for Paul). Apphia was likely Philemon's wife, Archippus possibly their son (Col 4:17 mentions Archippus's ministry). The occasion is Paul's appeal regarding Onesimus, Philemon's slave who ran away (possibly stealing, v. 18), encountered Paul in prison, converted to Christianity, and became useful to Paul (v. 11: pun on "Onesimus" meaning "useful"). Paul sends Onesimus back to Philemon with this letter, imploring Philemon to receive him "no longer as a slave but... as a beloved brother" (v. 16). Paul offers to repay any debt (v. 18-19), hints at manumission ("receive him as you would receive me," v. 17), yet doesn't explicitly command Onesimus's freedom, creating interpretive tension about the letter's implications for slavery.

**Key Themes:** **Christian Brotherhood Transcending Social Status**: The letter's revolutionary message is that Onesimus, legally Philemon's property, is now "beloved brother" (v. 16) - social hierarchy yields to spiritual equality in Christ. Paul addresses Philemon not as master exercising absolute rights but as Christian brother choosing love over law. **Intercession and Mediation**: Paul models Christ's mediatorial role: just as Christ intercedes for sinners, Paul intercedes for Onesimus, offering to absorb any debt: "If he has wronged you at all, or owes you anything, charge that to my account" (v. 18) - language echoing substitutionary atonement. **Transformation Through Gospel**: Onesimus transformed from "useless" to "useful" (v. 11, punning on his name), exemplifying conversion's life-changing power. Paul describes him as "my very heart" (v. 12) and "my child" (v. 10), testifying to genuine spiritual birth. **Freedom and Obligation in Christ**: Paul brilliantly balances appeals: he could "command" Philemon (v. 8) but prefers he act from "spontaneous" goodness (v. 14), exercising Christian freedom to do what's right without compulsion. The letter models persuasive Christian ethics - appealing to love, not demanding through authority. **Partnership in Gospel**: References to Philemon as "partner" (v. 17) and coworkers (v. 1, 24) establish foundation for appeal - Christian partnership obligates mutual care and restoration.

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Slavery in the Roman Empire**: Archaeological evidence illuminates first-century slavery's pervasiveness. Inscriptions, legal documents, household arrangements, and literary sources document slavery's economic/social centrality. Perhaps 25-30% of Roman Empire's population were enslaved. Runaway slaves faced severe punishment (branding, crucifixion), making Paul's appeal revolutionary. **Colossae Context**: Though Colossae lacks excavation, nearby Laodicea and Hierapolis document wealthy households with slave-owning capacity. Philemon's house church presupposes significant domestic space, confirmed by excavated houses in Asia Minor cities showing rooms accommodating 30-50 people. **Letter Delivery System**: References to Tychicus carrying Colossians (Col 4:7-9) and presumably Philemon, with Onesimus accompanying, document ancient postal systems relying on personal carriers. Numerous papyri preserve letters of recommendation similar to Philemon's genre. **Manumission Practices**: Inscriptions document slave manumission in the Roman world, including religious manumission (slave "sold" to deity, gaining freedom). Paul's language may hint at manumission - "receive him... as a beloved brother... both in the flesh and in the Lord" (v. 16) - though not explicitly demanded. **Legal Terminology**: Paul's "charge that to my account" (v. 18) uses commercial language (ellogeo), documented in business papyri as technical accounting term. Paul even adds "I, Paul, write this with my own hand, I will repay it" (v. 19) - autograph guaranteeing the debt, mimicking legal documents. **Manuscript Evidence**: Early manuscripts include P87 (3rd century), though Philemon's brevity means fewer manuscript witnesses than longer letters.

**Structure:** **Opening (vv. 1-7)**: Greeting from Paul and Timothy to Philemon, Apphia, Archippus, and house church (vv. 1-3), thanksgiving for Philemon's love and faith, praying his sharing of faith be effective (vv. 4-7). **Appeal for Onesimus (vv. 8-21)**: Though Paul could command, he appeals based on love (vv. 8-9), introducing "my child, Onesimus" begotten in prison (v. 10), wordplay on Onesimus's name - now truly useful (v. 11), Paul's desire to keep him but sends him back as Philemon's decision must be voluntary (vv. 12-14), providential interpretation - separated briefly to have him back forever as brother, not slave (vv. 15-16), appeal to receive him as Paul himself (v. 17), Paul's guarantee to repay any debt (vv. 18-19), reminder Philemon owes Paul his very self (v. 19b), confidence Philemon will do even more than asked (v. 21) - possibly hinting at manumission. **Closing (vv. 22-25)**: Request to prepare guest room as Paul hopes to visit (v. 22), greetings from Epaphras, Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, Luke (vv. 23-24), benediction (v. 25). Though brief, Philemon is a rhetorical masterpiece of persuasive appeal.

## Hebrews

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** Hebrews is dated to 60s-90s CE, before or after Jerusalem's Temple destruction (70 CE). Arguments for pre-70 dating include: present-tense references to temple sacrifices (7:27-28, 8:3-5, 9:6-9, 10:1-3, 13:10-11) suggest ongoing temple cult, though these could be literary present describing Mosaic system; no explicit mention of Temple destruction, though argument from silence is weak. Arguments for post-70 dating include: theological sophistication suggesting later development, awareness of Paul's legacy (implied in 13:23's Timothy reference), and addressing second-generation Christians facing persecution and apostasy (2:3, 10:32-34, 13:7). Most scholars favor 65-85 CE, after Paul's death but addressing communities he influenced. The letter addresses Jewish Christians (or Gentile Christians deeply versed in Hebrew Bible) facing pressure to apostatize—either returning to Judaism or abandoning faith entirely amid persecution. The audience has "endured a hard struggle with sufferings" (10:32), experienced property confiscation (10:34), and needs encouragement not to "shrink back" (10:38-39).

**Author and Audience:** Authorship is anonymous; the text never identifies its author. Early church proposed various candidates: Paul (Eastern church tradition), Barnabas (Tertullian), Apollos (Luther, based on Acts 18:24's "eloquent man, competent in Scriptures"), Priscilla (modern suggestion), or unknown author. Pauline authorship is unlikely: Hebrews' elegant Greek style differs from Paul's, theology (high priest Christology, Melchizedek typology, lack of justification-by-faith language) diverges, and 2:3's statement "attested to us by those who heard" places author among second-generation Christians, not apostolic eyewitnesses. Origen famously concluded "who wrote Hebrews, God knows." The audience consists of Jewish Christians (or Gentile God-fearers) deeply familiar with Septuagint, Levitical cult, and typological interpretation. They face persecution (10:32-34, 12:4), temptation to apostatize (2:1-3, 3:12-14, 6:4-8, 10:26-31), and need encouragement to "hold fast" confession (4:14, 10:23). References to "leaders" who spoke God's word (13:7), Timothy (13:23), and greetings from "those from Italy" (13:24) suggest possible Roman destination, though this remains speculative.

**Key Themes:** **Superiority of Christ**: Hebrews systematically demonstrates Christ's supremacy over angels (1:4-14, 2:5-18), Moses (3:1-6), Joshua (4:8), Aaronic priesthood (5:1-10, 7:1-28), Levitical sacrifices (9:1-10:18), establishing Christianity's fulfillment of Judaism. **High Priest Christology**: Jesus is "merciful and faithful high priest" (2:17) after Melchizedek's order (5:6, 10; 6:20; 7:1-28), offering himself as sacrifice (7:27, 9:12-14), entering heavenly sanctuary (9:11-12, 24), making perfect atonement (10:10, 14), and interceding eternally (7:25). **New Covenant**: Christ mediates "new covenant" (8:6-13, quoting Jeremiah 31:31-34), superior to old covenant, making first obsolete (8:13). **Faith and Perseverance**: Chapter 11's "hall of faith" illustrates faithful endurance; believers must "hold fast" (3:6, 14; 4:14; 10:23) and not "shrink back" (10:38-39). **Warning Passages**: Five severe warnings against apostasy (2:1-4; 3:7-4:13; 5:11-6:12; 10:26-31; 12:25-29) address danger of falling away after enlightenment. **Pilgrimage and Rest**: Believers seek heavenly homeland (11:13-16, 13:14), Sabbath rest (4:1-11), and Mt. Zion (12:22-24). **Suffering and Discipline**: God disciplines children (12:4-11); believers share Christ's sufferings (13:12-13), following his example (12:1-3).

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Temple Cult**: Hebrews' detailed sacrificial system descriptions (9:1-10, 13:11) reflect Second Temple practices documented in archaeology: altar remains, priestly garments, ritual vessels. The **Qumran scrolls** evidence Melchizedek speculation (11QMelch), contextualizing Hebrews 7's unique Christology. **Day of Atonement**: Hebrews 9-10's atonement theology references Yom Kippur practices described in Leviticus 16, central to Second Temple Judaism. **Persecution**: References to suffering (10:32-34, property confiscation) match Roman persecution patterns evidenced in historical sources (Tacitus, Suetonius, Pliny). **Heavenly Tabernacle**: Hebrews' contrast between earthly and heavenly sanctuaries (8:1-5, 9:11-12, 24) reflects Jewish apocalyptic thinking found in Dead Sea Scrolls and Philo.

**Structure:** **Christ's Superiority (1:1-10:18)**: Superior to angels (1-2), Moses (3:1-6), rest giver (3:7-4:13), Aaronic priesthood (4:14-7:28), old covenant (8:1-13), Levitical sacrifices (9:1-10:18). **Exhortations to Faith (10:19-13:25)**: Draw near confidently (10:19-25), warning against apostasy (10:26-39), faith examples (11:1-40), Jesus as faith's pioneer (12:1-3), endure discipline (12:4-17), Mt. Zion vision (12:18-29), practical exhortations (13:1-19), benediction (13:20-25). Hebrews' sermonic style blends exposition and exhortation, presenting sophisticated typological interpretation of Hebrew Bible.

### Hebrews Chapter 11

Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.
For by it the elders obtained a good report.
Through faith we understand that the worlds were framed by the word of God, so that things which are seen were not made of things which do appear.
By faith Abel offered unto God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain, by which he obtained witness that he was righteous, God testifying of his gifts: and by it he being dead yet speaketh.
By faith Enoch was translated that he should not see death; and was not found, because God had translated him: for before his translation he had this testimony, that he pleased God.
But without faith
it is impossible to please
him:
 for he that cometh to God must believe that he is, and
that
 he is a rewarder of them that diligently seek him.
By faith Noah, being warned of God of things not seen as yet, moved with fear, prepared an ark to the saving of his house; by the which he condemned the world, and became heir of the righteousness which is by faith.
By faith Abraham, when he was called to go out into a place which he should after receive for an inheritance, obeyed; and he went out, not knowing whither he went.
By faith he sojourned in the land of promise, as
in a strange country, dwelling in tabernacles with Isaac and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise:
For he looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker
is God.
Through faith also Sara herself received strength to conceive seed, and was delivered of a child when she was past age, because she judged him faithful who had promised.
Therefore sprang there even of one, and him as good as dead,
so many as the stars of the sky in multitude, and as the sand which is by the sea shore innumerable.
These all died in faith, not having received the promises, but having seen them afar off, and were persuaded of
them, and embraced
them, and confessed that they were strangers and pilgrims on the earth.
For they that say such things declare plainly that they seek a country.
And truly, if they had been mindful of that
country from whence they came out, they might have had opportunity to have returned.
But now they desire a better
country, that is, an heavenly: wherefore God is not ashamed to be called their God: for he hath prepared for them a city.
By faith Abraham, when he was tried, offered up Isaac: and he that had received the promises offered up his only begotten
son,
Of whom it was said, That in Isaac shall thy seed be called:
Accounting that God
was able to raise
him up, even from the dead; from whence also he received him in a figure.
By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come.
By faith Jacob, when he was a dying, blessed both the sons of Joseph; and worshipped,
leaning upon the top of his staff.
By faith Joseph, when he died, made mention of the departing of the children of Israel; and gave commandment concerning his bones.
By faith Moses, when he was born, was hid three months of his parents, because they saw
he was a proper child; and they were not afraid of the king’s commandment.
By faith Moses, when he was come to years, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter;
Choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season;
Esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures in Egypt: for he had respect unto the recompence of the reward.
By faith he forsook Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king: for he endured, as seeing him who is invisible.
Through faith he kept the passover, and the sprinkling of blood, lest he that destroyed the firstborn should touch them.
By faith they passed through the Red sea as by dry
land:
 which the Egyptians assaying to do were drowned.
By faith the walls of Jericho fell down, after they were compassed about seven days.
By faith the harlot Rahab perished not with them that believed not, when she had received the spies with peace.
And what shall I more say? for the time would fail me to tell of Gedeon, and
of Barak, and
of Samson, and
of Jephthae;
of David also, and Samuel, and
of the prophets:
Who through faith subdued kingdoms, wrought righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,
Quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, out of weakness were made strong, waxed valiant in fight, turned to flight the armies of the aliens.
Women received their dead raised to life again: and others were tortured, not accepting deliverance; that they might obtain a better resurrection:
And others had trial of
cruel mockings and scourgings, yea, moreover of bonds and imprisonment:
They were stoned, they were sawn asunder, were tempted, were slain with the sword: they wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins; being destitute, afflicted, tormented;
(Of whom the world was not worthy:) they wandered in deserts, and
in mountains, and
in dens and caves of the earth.
And these all, having obtained a good report through faith, received not the promise:
God having provided some better thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect.


### Hebrews Chapter 12

Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us,
Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of
our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.
For consider him that endured such contradiction of sinners against himself, lest ye be wearied and faint in your minds.
Ye have not yet resisted unto blood, striving against sin.
And ye have forgotten the exhortation which speaketh unto you as unto children, My son, despise not thou the chastening of the Lord, nor faint when thou art rebuked of him:
For whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth.
If ye endure chastening, God dealeth with you as with sons; for what son is he whom the father chasteneth not?
But if ye be without chastisement, whereof all are partakers, then are ye bastards, and not sons.
Furthermore we have had fathers of our flesh which corrected
us,
 and we gave
them reverence: shall we not much rather be in subjection unto the Father of spirits, and live?
For they verily for a few days chastened
us after their own pleasure; but he for
our profit, that
we might be partakers of his holiness.
Now no chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous: nevertheless afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousness unto them which are exercised thereby.
Wherefore lift up the hands which hang down, and the feeble knees;
And make straight paths for your feet, lest that which is lame be turned out of the way; but let it rather be healed.
Follow peace with all
men, and holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord:
Looking diligently lest any man fail of the grace of God; lest any root of bitterness springing up trouble
you, and thereby many be defiled;
Lest there
be any fornicator, or profane person, as Esau, who for one morsel of meat sold his birthright.
For ye know how that afterward, when he would have inherited the blessing, he was rejected: for he found no place of repentance, though he sought it carefully with tears.
For ye are not come unto the mount that might be touched, and that burned with fire, nor unto blackness, and darkness, and tempest,
And the sound of a trumpet, and the voice of words;
which
 voice they that heard intreated that the word should not be spoken to them any more:
(For they could not endure that which was commanded, And if so much as a beast touch the mountain, it shall be stoned, or thrust through with a dart:
And so terrible was the sight,
that Moses said, I exceedingly fear and quake:)
But ye are come unto mount Sion, and unto the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to an innumerable company of angels,
To the general assembly and church of the firstborn, which are written in heaven, and to God the Judge of all, and to the spirits of just men made perfect,
And to Jesus the mediator of the new covenant, and to the blood of sprinkling, that speaketh better things than
that of Abel.
See that ye refuse not him that speaketh. For if they escaped not who refused him that spake on earth, much more
shall not we
escape,
 if we turn away from him that
speaketh from heaven:
Whose voice then shook the earth: but now he hath promised, saying, Yet once more I shake not the earth only, but also heaven.
And this
word, Yet once more, signifieth the removing of those things that are shaken, as of things that are made, that those things which cannot be shaken may remain.
Wherefore we receiving a kingdom which cannot be moved, let us have grace, whereby we may serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear:
For our God
is a consuming fire.

Let brotherly love continue.

their conversation.

## James

### Book Introduction

**Historical Timeframe:** James' dating is debated between early (45-50 CE, making it earliest NT document) and late (80-100 CE, pseudonymous work). Early dating arguments include: primitive Christology (Jesus mentioned only twice, 1:1, 2:1), Jewish character (synagogue for assembly, 2:2), no reference to Gentile controversy (suggesting pre-Acts 15 Jerusalem Council), and James the Just's martyrdom (c. 62 CE, Josephus Antiquities 20.200) as terminus ante quem. Late dating arguments propose: literary relationship with Paul's letters (seemingly responding to misunderstood Pauline theology, 2:14-26), sophisticated Greek style, and developed church structure. Most scholars favor 60-100 CE for a Jewish-Christian document addressing practical piety and ethical living.

**Author and Audience:** "James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ" (1:1) traditionally identifies James the Just, Jesus's brother (Matthew 13:55, Mark 6:3, Galatians 1:19), Jerusalem church leader (Acts 15, 21:18, Galatians 2:9-12), and martyr (62 CE). However, excellent Greek, Hellenistic rhetorical style, and lack of Jesus-family references raise questions about direct authorship versus later composition in James's name/tradition. The audience is "the twelve tribes in the Dispersion" (1:1), Jewish Christians scattered throughout Mediterranean, facing trials, economic oppression, and temptation toward nominal faith without works.

**Key Themes:** **Faith and Works**: James's central thesis declares "faith apart from works is dead" (2:26), using Abraham and Rahab as examples (2:21-25). This seemingly contradicts Paul's "justification by faith" but addresses different concerns: Paul combats works-righteousness requiring Torah observance for salvation; James combats dead orthodoxy lacking ethical fruit. **Trials and Temptation**: Trials test faith, producing steadfastness (1:2-4); temptations arise from inner desires, not God (1:13-15). **Wisdom from Above**: True wisdom is "pure, peaceable, gentle, open to reason, full of mercy" (3:17) versus earthly, jealous, selfish wisdom (3:14-16). **Taming the Tongue**: The tongue's power for blessing or cursing requires control (3:1-12). **Rich and Poor**: James champions the poor, condemning rich oppressors (2:1-7, 5:1-6), forbidding partiality (2:1-13). **Prayer**: Believers should pray in faith (1:5-8, 5:13-18), with Elijah as example (5:17-18).

**Archaeological Relevance:** **Synagogue Architecture**: James 2:2's "synagogue" (Greek synagōgē for Christian assembly) reflects Jewish-Christian continuity; archaeological synagogue remains contextualize early church worship practices. **Economic Oppression**: James 5:1-6's condemnation of wealthy landowners exploiting laborers reflects 1st century Palestinian economic conditions documented in historical sources. **Diaspora Judaism**: James's addressees ("twelve tribes in Dispersion") inhabited communities evidenced archaeologically throughout Mediterranean—synagogues, Jewish inscriptions, ritual baths.

**Structure:** James lacks linear argument, presenting wisdom sayings and exhortations. **Opening (1:1)**: Greeting. **Trials, Wisdom, Temptation (1:2-27)**: Joy in trials (1:2-4), ask wisdom (1:5-8), rich-poor reversal (1:9-11), temptation's source (1:12-18), quick to hear, slow to speak (1:19-27). **Partiality and Faith-Works (2:1-26)**: No favoritism to rich (2:1-13), faith without works dead (2:14-26). **Taming the Tongue (3:1-12)**: Tongue's destructive power. **Wisdom and Conflict (3:13-4:12)**: True wisdom (3:13-18), worldly desires cause conflicts (4:1-3), friendship with world is enmity with God (4:4-10), judging others (4:11-12). **Wealth and Planning (4:13-5:6)**: Presumptuous planning (4:13-17), rich warned (5:1-6). **Patience and Prayer (5:7-20)**: Patient endurance (5:7-11), oath-taking (5:12), prayer and anointing (5:13-18), restoring wanderers (5:19-20). James' practical wisdom addresses Christian living with Jewish ethical tradition.

### James Chapter 1

James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are scattered abroad, greeting.
My brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations;
Knowing
this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience.
But let patience have
her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing.
If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all
men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him.
But let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea driven with the wind and tossed.
For let not that man think that he shall receive any thing of the Lord.
A double minded man
is unstable in all his ways.
Let the brother of low degree rejoice in that he is exalted:
But the rich, in that he is made low: because as the flower of the grass he shall pass away.
For the sun is no sooner risen with a burning heat, but it withereth the grass, and the flower thereof falleth, and the grace of the fashion of it perisheth: so also shall the rich man fade away in his ways.
Blessed
is the man that endureth temptation: for when he is tried, he shall receive the crown of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love him.
Let no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God: for God cannot be tempted with evil, neither tempteth he any man:
But every man is tempted, when he is drawn away of his own lust, and enticed.
Then when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin: and sin, when it is finished, bringeth forth death.
Do not err, my beloved brethren.
Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning.
Of his own will begat he us with the word of truth, that we should be a kind of firstfruits of his creatures.
Wherefore, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath:
For the wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of God.
Wherefore lay apart all filthiness and superfluity of naughtiness, and receive with meekness the engrafted word, which is able to save your souls.
But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.
For if any be a hearer of the word, and not a doer, he is like unto a man beholding his natural face in a glass:
For he beholdeth himself, and goeth his way, and straightway forgetteth what manner of man he was.
But whoso looketh into the perfect law of liberty, and continueth
therein, he being not a forgetful hearer, but a doer of the work, this man shall be blessed in his deed.
If any man among you seem to be religious, and bridleth not his tongue, but deceiveth his own heart, this man’s religion
is vain.
Pure religion and undefiled before God and the Father is this, To visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction,
and to keep himself unspotted from the world.


### James Chapter 2

My brethren, have not the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ,
the Lord
 of glory, with respect of persons.
For if there come unto your assembly a man with a gold ring, in goodly apparel, and there come in also a poor man in vile raiment;
And ye have respect to him that weareth the gay clothing, and say unto him, Sit thou here in a good place; and say to the poor, Stand thou there, or sit here under my footstool:
Are ye not then partial in yourselves, and are become judges of evil thoughts?
Hearken, my beloved brethren, Hath not God chosen the poor of this world rich in faith, and heirs of the kingdom which he hath promised to them that love him?
But ye have despised the poor. Do not rich men oppress you, and draw you before the judgment seats?
Do not they blaspheme that worthy name by the which ye are called?
If ye fulfil the royal law according to the scripture, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself, ye do well:
But if ye have respect to persons, ye commit sin, and are convinced of the law as transgressors.
For whosoever shall keep the whole law, and yet offend in one
point, he is guilty of all.
For he that said, Do not commit adultery, said also, Do not kill. Now if thou commit no adultery, yet if thou kill, thou art become a transgressor of the law.
So speak ye, and so do, as they that shall be judged by the law of liberty.
For he shall have judgment without mercy, that hath shewed no mercy; and mercy rejoiceth against judgment.
What
doth it profit, my brethren, though a man say he hath faith, and have not works? can faith save him?
If a brother or sister be naked, and destitute of daily food,
And one of you say unto them, Depart in peace, be ye warmed and filled; notwithstanding ye give them not those things which are needful to the body; what
doth it profit?
Even so faith, if it hath not works, is dead, being alone.
Yea, a man may say, Thou hast faith, and I have works: shew me thy faith without thy works, and I will shew thee my faith by my works.
Thou believest that there is one God; thou doest well: the devils also believe, and tremble.
But wilt thou know, O vain man, that faith without works is dead?
Was not Abraham our father justified by works, when he had offered Isaac his son upon the altar?
Seest thou how faith wrought with his works, and by works was faith made perfect?
And the scripture was fulfilled which saith, Abraham believed God, and it was imputed unto him for righteousness: and he was called the Friend of God.
Ye see then how that by works a man is justified, and not by faith only.
Likewise also was not Rahab the harlot justified by works, when she had received the messengers, and had sent
them out another way?
For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead also.


### James Chapter 3

My brethren, be not many masters, knowing that we shall receive the greater condemnation.
For in many things we offend all. If any man offend not in word, the same
is a perfect man,
and able also to bridle the whole body.
Behold, we put bits in the horses’ mouths, that they may obey us; and we turn about their whole body.
Behold also the ships, which though
they be so great, and
are driven of fierce winds, yet are they turned about with a very small helm, whithersoever the governor listeth.
Even so the tongue is a little member, and boasteth great things. Behold, how great a matter a little fire kindleth!
And the tongue
is a fire, a world of iniquity: so is the tongue among our members, that it defileth the whole body, and setteth on fire the course of nature; and it is set on fire of hell.
For every kind of beasts, and of birds, and of serpents, and of things in the sea, is tamed, and hath been tamed of mankind:
But the tongue can no man tame;
it is an unruly evil, full of deadly poison.
Therewith bless we God, even the Father; and therewith curse we men, which are made after the similitude of God.
Out of the same mouth proceedeth blessing and cursing. My brethren, these things ought not so to be.
Doth a fountain send forth at the same place sweet
water
 and bitter?
Can the fig tree, my brethren, bear olive berries? either a vine, figs? so
can no fountain both yield salt water and fresh.
Who
is a wise man and endued with knowledge among you? let him shew out of a good conversation his works with meekness of wisdom.
But if ye have bitter envying and strife in your hearts, glory not, and lie not against the truth.
This wisdom descendeth not from above, but
is earthly, sensual, devilish.
For where envying and strife
is, there
is confusion and every evil work.
But the wisdom that is from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle,
and easy to be intreated, full of mercy and good fruits, without partiality, and without hypocrisy.
And the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace of them that make peace.


### James Chapter 4

From whence
come wars and fightings among you?
come they
 not hence,
even of your lusts that war in your members?
Ye lust, and have not: ye kill, and desire to have, and cannot obtain: ye fight and war, yet ye have not, because ye ask not.
Ye ask, and receive not, because ye ask amiss, that ye may consume
it upon your lusts.
Ye adulterers and adulteresses, know ye not that the friendship of the world is enmity with God? whosoever therefore will be a friend of the world is the enemy of God.
Do ye think that the scripture saith in vain, The spirit that dwelleth in us lusteth to envy?
But he giveth more grace. Wherefore he saith, God resisteth the proud, but giveth grace unto the humble.
Submit yourselves therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
Draw nigh to God, and he will draw nigh to you. Cleanse
your
 hands,
ye sinners; and purify
your hearts,
ye double minded.
Be afflicted, and mourn, and weep: let your laughter be turned to mourning, and
your joy to heaviness.
Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he shall lift you up.
Speak not evil one of another, brethren. He that speaketh evil of
his brother, and judgeth his brother, speaketh evil of the law, and judgeth the law: but if thou judge the law, thou art not a doer of the law, but a judge.
There is one lawgiver, who is able to save and to destroy: who art thou that judgest another?
Go to now, ye that say, To day or to morrow we will go into such a city, and continue there a year, and buy and sell, and get gain:
Whereas ye know not what
shall be on the morrow. For what
is your life? It is even a vapour, that appeareth for a little time, and then vanisheth away.
For that ye
ought to say, If the Lord will, we shall live, and do this, or that.
But now ye rejoice in your boastings: all such rejoicing is evil.
Therefore to him that knoweth to do good, and doeth
it not, to him it is sin.


### James Chapter 5

Go to now,
ye rich men, weep and howl for your miseries that shall come upon
you.
Your riches are corrupted, and your garments are motheaten.
Your gold and silver is cankered; and the rust of them shall be a witness against you, and shall eat your flesh as it were fire. Ye have heaped treasure together for the last days.
Behold, the hire of the labourers who have reaped down your fields, which is of you kept back by fraud, crieth: and the cries of them which have reaped are entered into the ears of the Lord of sabaoth.
Ye have lived in pleasure on the earth, and been wanton; ye have nourished your hearts, as in a day of slaughter.
Ye have condemned
and killed the just;
and he doth not resist you.
Be patient therefore, brethren, unto the coming of the Lord. Behold, the husbandman waiteth for the precious fruit of the earth, and hath long patience for it, until he receive the early and latter rain.
Be ye also patient; stablish your hearts: for the coming of the Lord draweth nigh.
Grudge not one against another, brethren, lest ye be condemned: behold, the judge standeth before the door.
Take, my brethren, the prophets, who have spoken in the name of the Lord, for an example of suffering affliction, and of patience.
Behold, we count them happy which endure. Ye have heard of the patience of Job, and have seen the end of the Lord; that the Lord is very pitiful, and of tender mercy.
But above all things, my brethren, swear not, neither by heaven, neither by the earth, neither by any other oath: but let your yea be yea; and
your nay, nay; lest ye fall into condemnation.
Is any among you afflicted? let him pray. Is any merry? let him sing psalms.
Is any sick among you? let him call for the elders of the church; and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord:
And the prayer of faith shall save the sick, and the Lord shall raise him up; and if he have committed sins, they shall be forgiven him.
Confess
your faults one to another, and pray one for another, that ye may be healed. The effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much.
Elias was a man subject to like passions as we are, and he prayed earnestly that it might not rain: and it rained not on the earth by the space of three years and six months.
And he prayed again, and the heaven gave rain, and the earth brought forth her fruit.
Brethren, if any of you do err from the truth, and one convert him;
Let him know, that he which converteth the sinner from the error of his way shall save a soul from death, and shall hide a multitude of sins.
